Mail|accessdate=18 August 2012|first=Rob|last=Preece|date=2 August 2012}}{{cite web|title=Ukrainians protest: topless women say "No Sharia" and "Bloody Islamist Regimes"|url=http://www.albawaba.com/blog_roundup/olympics-femen-hijab-437290|website=Al Bawaba|accessdate=7 August 2012}} *On 17 August 2012, [[Inna Shevchenko]] and two other Femen activists [[chainsaw]]ed down a large wooden Christian [[crucifix]] that was dedicated to [[Uniate]] Christian victims of [[Persecution of Christians in the Soviet Union|antireligious Stalinist purges]], near [[Maidan Nezalezhnosti]] in [[Kiev]] in support for the Russian group [[Pussy Riot]]. (Three members of Pussy Riot were to be sentenced by a Russian court later that day.){{#tag:ref|The desecration of the cross was repudiated by [[Maria Alyokhina]] of [[Pussy Riot]], who said "Their surprise displays and protests against authoritarianism are similar to us, but we look at feminism differently, especially the form of speech. We wouldn't take our clothes off, and will not. Their latest action, the sawing of the cross, does not create a feeling of solidarity, unfortunately."{{cite web |title=Pussy Riot засудили акцію FEMEN зі спиленням хреста в Києві ("Pussy Riot condemn FEMEN action of cutting cross in Kiev") |url=http://www.regionews.com.ua/node/55994 |publisher=RegioNews |language=Ukrainian |accessdate=23 August 2012 |date=23 August 2012 |archivedate=2 November 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6BsL2FluH?url=http://regionews.ua/node/55994 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}|group=nb}}{{cite web|url=http://www.rferl.org/content/ukraine-femen-cross-pussy-riot/24679942.html|title= Ukraine, FEMEN shows support for Pussy Riot|accessdate = 19 November 2012}} The action attracted overwhelmingly negative responses.{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/08/17/pussy-riot-trial-femen_n_1798009.html |title=Pussy Riot Trial, FEMEN |accessdate=19 November 2012 | work=Huffington Post |first=Dominique |last=Mosbergen |date=17 August 2012}}{{cite news | url = http://www.1tv.ru/news/world/213629 | title = Киевская милиция ищет активистку движения FEMEN, спилившую поклонный крест | publisher = [[Channel One (Russia)]] | page = | date = 18 August 2012 }}{{cite news |url = http://english.ruvr.ru/2012_08_17/FEMEN-saws-down-cross-for-Stalin-victims/ |title = FEMEN saws down cross for Stalin victims |publisher = The Voice of Russia |page = |date = 17 August 2012 |access-date = 18 August 2012 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20120819235729/http://english.ruvr.ru/2012_08_17/FEMEN-saws-down-cross-for-Stalin-victims/# |archive-date = 19 August 2012 |dead-url = yes |df = dmy-all }}{{cite news|url=http://tvnz.co.nz/world-news/ukrainian-activist-cuts-down-cross-in-pussy-riot-protest-5031717 |title=Ukrainian activist cuts down cross in Pussy Riot protest |publisher=TVNZ |page= |date=17 August 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120820010631/http://tvnz.co.nz/world-news/ukrainian-activist-cuts-down-cross-in-pussy-riot-protest-5031717 |archivedate=20 August 2012 }} A [[criminal case]] was opened against Femen under "Part 2 of Article 296 (hooliganism) of the Criminal Code of Ukraine".{{cite news | url = http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/police-open-criminal-case-on-hooliganism-against-femen-activists-311706.html | title = Police open criminal case on hooliganism against Femen activists | work = Kyiv Post | page = | date = 17 August 2012 }}{{cite news | url = http://www.interfax-religion.com/?act=news&div=9732 | title = Criminal inquiry started into demolition of cross by FEMEN activists in Kiev | publisher = Interfax | page = | date = 17 August 2012 }} Femen stated that after the incident, [[special forces]] troops from the [[Ministry of Internal Affairs (Ukraine)|Ministry of Internal Affairs]] organized a [[blockade]] around FEMEN's headquarters in Kiev.{{cite news | url= http://un.ua/eng/article/406298.html| title= FEMEN Women's Movement Says Police Blocking Organisation's Office In Kiev | publisher= Ukrainian News Service | page= | date = 18 August 2012 }} On 18 August 2012 a new Christian cross was erected at the same site.{{cite news| url= http://nbnews.com.ua/news/53552/| title= На месте спиленного FEMEN креста установили новый| publisher= NB News| date= 18 August 2012| access-date= 18 August 2012| archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20120820224208/http://nbnews.com.ua/news/53552#| archive-date= 20 August 2012| dead-url= yes| df= dmy-all}}{{cite news|url=http://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2012/08/18/6971066// |title=На місці спиляного Femen хреста поставили тимчасовий |publisher=Українська правда |date=18 August 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120820054516/http://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2012/08/18/6971066/|archivedate=20 August 2012 |df=dmy }} * In January 2013 four Ukrainian Femen activists protested topless in favour of [[LGBT adoption]] at the Pope's weekly address in [[St. Peter's Square]], [[Vatican City]].{{cite news |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/world/topless-women-protest-vatican-gay-adoption-criticized-article-1.1239197 |title=Topless women protest Vatican because of gay adoption criticism |newspaper=New York Daily News |date=13 January 2013 |accessdate=13 October 2015}} * Femen activists burned the [[Salafist]] flag in front of the [[Great Mosque of Paris]] on 3 April 2013, as part of a solidarity protest with [[Amina Tyler]].{{cite news |title=Femen Stages a 'Topless Jihad' |first=Alan |last=Taylor |url=https://www.theatlantic.com/infocus/2013/04/femen-stages-a-topless-jihad/100487/ |newspaper=The Atlantic |date=4 April 2013 |accessdate=19 April 2013}} * On 12 September 2015, two Femen protesters attending the conference as Arabs, ripped their cloaks on stage and went topless at a controversial conference near Paris on the role of Muslim women. After being taken off stage by security, several men rushed the stage and began beating one of the protestors.{{cite news |title=Topless protesters disrupt Muslim conference on women |first=David |last=Chazan |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/france/11862220/Topless-protesters-disrupt-Muslim-conference-on-women.html |newspaper=The Telegraph|date= 13 September 2015 |accessdate=14 September 2015}}{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wM-wxU86v8g|title=Topless FEMEN disrupt Muslim conference in France, get kicked|publisher=|accessdate=29 September 2016}} * On 25 December 2017, one topless activist from the group tried to snatch the statue of the infant [[Jesus]] from the [[nativity scene]] in [[St. Peter's Square]] screaming, "God is woman." Before she was able to steal the statue, however, she was tackled to the ground by guards.{{cite news |title=Topless Femen activist arrested trying to snatch Jesus statue from Vatican nativity scene |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/topless-feminist-femen-ukraine-god-is-woman-steal-jesus-statue-vatican-st-peter-s-square-pope-a8128431.html |newspaper=The Independent |accessdate=27 December 2017}} ==Amina Tyler case== [[File:Amina Tyler.jpeg|thumb|right|200px|[[Amina Tyler|Amina "Tyler" Sboui]]]] {{Main article|Amina Tyler}} '''Amina Tyler''' (real name Amina Sboui), a [[Tunisia]]n Femen activist, was arrested on 19 May 2013 in [[Tunis]]. International protests followed for her release from detention. On 12 June 2013 a Tunisian judge convicted two French Femen members and one German Femen member after they were charged with public indecency while protesting for the release of Tyler. Pauline Hillier, Marguerite Stern and [[Josephine Markmann]] were released on 26 June 2013 after a Tunisian court lifted their prison sentence.[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/jun/27/femen-activists-tunisia-retract-apology Femen activists jailed in Tunisia retract apology], [[The Guardian]] (27 June 2013) Amina Tyler was acquitted for contempt and defamation on 29 July 2013; but she remained jailed pending trial on a separate charge of desecrating a cemetery.[http://www.france24.com/en/20130729-tunisia-femen-activist-amina-acquitted-contempt-defamation-charges Tunisian Femen activist ‘acquitted’ of defamation], [[France 24]] (29 July 2013)
[https://archive.is/20130730154531/http://m.timesdaily.com/news/world/article_33b2ca10-7b84-5cf8-8a4b-120a82f47f4d.html?mode=jqm Court dismisses 1 charge against Tunisian feminist], [[TimesDaily]] (29 July 2013)
[http://www.voanews.com/content/tunisian-femen-activist-acquitted-of-defamation-unrest-grows/1712301.html Tunisian Activist Acquitted Amid Growing Unrest], [[Voice of America]] (29 July 2013) {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151105050512/http://www.france24.com/en/20130729-tunisia-femen-activist-amina-acquitted-contempt-defamation-charges |date=5 November 2015 }} Femen had staged protests in front of the [[Grand Mosque of Paris]] burning a [[Tawhid]] flag. Amina upon release in August 2013 from detention in a Tunisian jail declared she was leaving the group in protest adding that she thought FEMEN's actions in Paris were disrespectful to the [[Muslim world]] and because she saw a lack of financial transparency in the organization.https://www.vocativ.com/08-2013/topless-tunisian-teen-activist-dumps-femen-but-still-takes-naked-selfies/
{{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130823023204/https://www.vocativ.com/08-2013/topless-tunisian-teen-activist-dumps-femen-but-still-takes-naked-selfies/ |date=23 August 2013 }}[http://www.france24.com/en/20130820-jailed-tunisia-activist-amina-leaves-islamophobic-femen-organisation Tunisia's Amina quits ‘Islamophobic’ Femen], [[France 24]] (20 August 2013) ==Cultural and political image== Critics have stated Femen members are more interested in self-promotion than real reform, and that their antics are often tacky and undermine the cause of their protests.[http://www.nydailynews.com/news/world/topless-protester-pursues-russia-church-leader-article-1.1122219 Topless protester pursues Russia church leader], [[Nydailynews.com]] (26 July 2012) According to Ukrainian gender studies expert Tetyana Bureychak, most Ukrainian women are unimpressed by Femen.[https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2011/apr/15/ukrainian-feminists-topless-campaign The nude radicals: feminism Ukrainian style], ''[[The Guardian]]'' (15 April 2011) Ukrainian sociologist Oleh Demkiv has spoken out against the controversial nature of FEMEN's protests and in July 2011 he stated they "unfortunately, do not enjoy popular support, or lead to changes in Ukraine's consciousness".{{uk icon}} [http://www.day.Kyiv.ua/212869 Акції FEMEN — наслідок суспільної нечутливості?], ''[[Den (newspaper)|Den]]'' (22 July 2011) In February 2013 Joanna Rohozinska (from [[National Endowment for Democracy]]) stated "there is little evidence of any of Femen's protests having significant impact" and she called FEMEN's decision to set up branches in outside Ukraine "as disingenuous at best and, frankly, somewhat cowardly". Positive remarks in Ukraine about Femen came from Maria Mayerchyk (of [[Lviv University]]), who has spoken about Femen, saying that they are a "positive, radical and important phenomenon that is able to raise social issues", and Larysa Kobelianska (UN-led women's rights program) said the group has succeeded in attracting public attention to women's problems, even if by questionable means.Hankivsky, Olena; Salnykova, Anastasiya. [https://books.google.com/books?id=n9MOMCO5SJ8C&pg=PA444&lpg=PA444&dq=%22Larysa+Kobelianska%22&source=bl&ots=fqElQr9T4J&sig=N8_JcjEBOmKKrYp7IsQedAej3AA&hl=nl&sa=X&ei=d_ETUd-kLcnD0QWCkoGACA&ved=0CFUQ6AEwBQ#v=onepage&q=%22Larysa%20Kobelianska%22&f=false ''Gender, Politics and Society in Ukraine''], [[University of Toronto Press]], 2012 The group is seen more positively abroad.[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-20028797 Ukraine's Femen:Topless protests 'help feminist cause'], [[BBC News]] (23 October 2012) Naomi Westland wrote that "Western countries are more accustomed than those in the Eastern Hemisphere to seeing naked or semi-naked bodies in the media and on the streets. But in countries where nudity is taboo, the protests have more profound impact."{{cite web |url= http://www.firstcoastnews.com/news/local/story.aspx?storyid=279819 |title= Protesters say they achieve more with less clothing |accessdate= 19 November 2012 }}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} [[Jeffrey Tayler]] noted: "Femen originated in Ukraine, born of young women who grew up without exposure to the [[Western world|West]]'s culture of political correctness and who have scant respect for it; from their country's [[Soviet]] past, they know how deleterious the stifling of free speech can be. Now that they have moved to the West, Femen has courageously broken rules and enlivened the debate over religion's role in our world."{{cite web |url= https://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2013/05/topless-jihad-why-femen-is-right/275471/ |title= Topless Jihad: Why Femen Is Right |first= Jeffrey |last=Taylor |website=The Atlantic |date=1 May 2013 |accessdate=1 May 2013}} Femen received a positive reception after opening their location in Paris.{{cite web |url= http://www.dw.de/still-topless-femen-activists-open-hq-in-paris/a-16287153 |title= FEMEN Opens HQ in Paris |accessdate= 19 November 2012}} In September 2013 Femen came under criticism when the Australian documentary film-maker Kitty Green exposed a man named Victor Svyatski as the mastermind behind the group.{{cite news |url= https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/films/news/the-man-who-made-femen-new-film-outs-victor-svyatski-as-the-mastermind-behind-the-protest-group-and-its-breastbaring-stunts-8797042.html |title= The man who made Femen: New film outs Victor Svyatski as the mastermind behind the protest group and its breast-baring stunts |work= The Independent |accessdate= 23 March 2015 |location= London |first= Geoffrey |last=MacNab |date= 3 September 2013}} Svyatski was previously known as only a consultant to the movement.{{cite web |url= https://www.imdb.com/title/tt3136842/ |title= Ukraine Is Not a Brothel (2013) |date= 12 June 2014 |website= IMDb |accessdate= 23 March 2015}} ==Financing== [[File:Ukraine is not a Brothel.jpg|thumb|Femen founder [[Anna Hutsol]] watches a Femen demonstration with [[DJ Hell]] in Kiev on 22 May 2009.]] Femen activists earn funding through the sale of products bearing the Femen logo.{{cite web|url=http://femenshop.com|title=front|publisher=|accessdate=29 September 2016}} Femen also receives donations from individuals{{ru icon}} [http://www.kommersant.ru/doc.aspx?DocsID=1503619 Бюст героев], [[Kommersant]] (20 September 2010) like Helmut Geier (also known as DJ under the alias [[DJ Hell]]),[http://www.spiegel.de/international/europe/0,1518,760697,00.html 'The Entire Ukraine Is a Brothel'], ''[[Der Spiegel]]'' (5 May 2011) [[Germany|German]] businesswoman Beate Schober (who is currently residing in [[Ukraine]]),[http://www.berliner-zeitung.de/archiv/anna-hutsol-kaempft-mit-ihrer-organisation-femen-und-provokanten-aktionen-gegen-sextourismus-und-klischees--die-ukraine-ist-kein-bordell-,10810590,10615762.html "Die Ukraine ist kein Bordell" ''"Ukraine is not a brothel"''], [[Berliner Zeitung]] (26 January 2009) the American businessman [[Jed Sunden]] (founder of Ukrainian [[KP Media]] and former owner of [[Kyiv Post]] newspaper)[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/46203/ Kyiv Post founder reflects on 14 years as newspaper’s owner, reasons for sale], [[Kyiv Post]] (19 November 2009) and [[Ukrainian Canadian]]s. In March 2012 Ukrainian magazine ''[[Focus (Ukrainian magazine)|Focus]]'' said that Femen activists receive royalties for foreign interviews and in the tabloids.{{ru icon}} [http://focus.ua/society/224236/ Игры на раздевание. Femen завоевывает симпатии мужчин и теряет поддержку феминисток "Games on the strip. Femen winning the sympathies of men and losing the support of feminists"], ''[[Focus (Ukrainian magazine)|Focus]]'' (27 March 2012) In the magazine [[Anna Hutsol]] confirmed that a rally in [[Istanbul]] was sponsored by a Turkish company producing underwear. A Ukrainian [[1+1 (channel)|1+1]] journalist, who claimed (in September 2012) to have infiltrated the organisation, says that its office in the Ukrainian capital, [[Kiev]], costs the movement over [[US Dollar|$]]2,500 per month, on top of which each member’s salary was roughly $1,000 per month.[http://rt.com/art-and-culture/femen-topless-activist-feminist-665/ Boob job: FEMEN activist reveals topless protesters’ $1,000 salaries] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131019020542/http://rt.com/art-and-culture/femen-topless-activist-feminist-665/ |date=19 October 2013 }}, [[RT (TV network)|RT]] (21 September 2012) ==See also== {{Portal|Politics|Ukraine|2010s}} * [[Feminism]] * [[Gender equality]] * [[History of feminism]] * [[Nudity and protest]] * [[Postfeminism]] * [[Sex-positive feminism]] * [[Women's Equality Day]] * [[Women's rights in Ukraine]] ==Bibliography== * Ackerman, Galia; et al., ''Femen'', Published by Calmann-Lévy (Paris 2013), 280 pages. {{ISBN|978-2702144589}}. (French language publication){{cite web |title= FEMEN livre (2013) |agency= FEMEN.info |date= 6 March 2013 |url= http://femen.info/books/femen-book-2013/ |accessdate= 23 March 2013 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://www.webcitation.org/6FeNZMha1?url=http://femen.info/books/femen-book-2013/ |archivedate= 5 April 2013 |df= dmy-all }} * {{cite book |last= Ceresa |first= Massimo | title=Femen, Inna e le altre streghe senza Dio |year=2016 |work=Tra le righe libri | isbn =978-8899141370 |location= Lucca}} * {{cite book |last= Goujon |first= Olivier | title=Femen, Histoire d'une trahison |date=2017 | isbn =978-2315008186}} Published by Max Milo Editions (Paris), 364 pages. (French language publication) ==Filmography== * ''Nos seins, nos armes !'' (Our breasts, our weapons!), documentary film (1hour 10 mins), written and directed by [[Caroline Fourest]] and [[Nadia El Fani]], produced by Nilaya Productions, aired on [[France 2]] on 5 March 2013.{{cite web|url=http://television.telerama.fr/tele/programmes-tv/nos-seins-nos-armes,48577030.php |title=Nos seins, nos armes (2012) - Documentaire - L'essentiel |publisher=Télérama |accessdate=2013-11-12}} * ''Everyday Rebellion'', documentary film (1hour 58 mins), written and directed by the Riahi Brothers [[Arash T. Riahi]] and Arman Riahi, Austria / Switzerland / Germany, 2013, world premiere at [[Copenhagen International Documentary Festival]] on 13 November 2013. * ''[[Ukraine Is Not a Brothel]]'' * ''Je Suis Femen'' (I Am Femen), 2014, documentary film, written and directed by Alain Margot.{{Cite web|url = https://www.imdb.com/title/tt3907394/?ref_=fn_al_tt_1|title = Imdb: Je Suis Femen (2014)|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }} ==Notes and references== ===Notes=== {{Reflist|40em|group=nb}} ===References=== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{commons category|Femen}} *{{Official website}} *[http://femenblog.com Femen blog] *[http://blaqswans.org/en/2013/09/feminisme-aux-seins-nus/ ''BlaqSwans.org''] – an analysis of the Femen movement {{Feminism}} {{Religious persecution}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:2008 establishments in Ukraine]] [[Category:Controversies in Ukraine]] [[Category:Femen| ]] [[Category:Feminism in Ukraine]] [[Category:Feminist organisations in Europe]] [[Category:Feminist protests]] [[Category:Nudity and protest]] [[Category:Organisations based in Kiev]] [[Category:Organizations established in 2008]] [[Category:Political controversies]] [[Category:Politics of Ukraine]] [[Category:Radical feminism]] [[Category:Women's rights in Ukraine]] [[Category:Ukrainian nationalism]] [[Category:Organizations based in Paris]]

A '''governance failure''' refers to any [[failure]]s of [[governance]] or ineffectiveness of governance processes.<ref name=Newman>{{cite book|last1=Newman|first1=Joshua|title=Governing Public-Private Partnerships|date=2017|publisher=McGill-Queen's Press - MQUP|isbn=9780773550018|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Pc8mDwAAQBAJ&pg=PT39|accessdate=6 July 2017|language=en}}</ref>
== General == Jessop argues for conceiving governance as a provider of flexibility for decision-making structures opposed to rigid state bureaucracy or market laws. From this approach failures would equate to failures of the governance structure.<ref name=Newman/> According to him new constellations of governance may compensate for state failure.<ref name=Peters/>
Peters and Pierre state that it is the continuous task of government to adapt to growing complexity.<ref name=Peters>{{cite book|last1=Peters|first1=B. Guy|last2=Pierre|first2=Jon|title=Comparative Governance: Rediscovering the Functional Dimension of Governing|date=2016|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=9781316738177|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TFblDAAAQBAJ&pg=PA12|accessdate=6 July 2017|language=en}}</ref>
Dixon and Dogan write that constructive governance discourses are creative opportunities for people with disparate governance perspectives to find solutions to threatening governance failure.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Dixon|first1=John|last2=Dogan|first2=Rhys|title=Hierarchies, Networks and Markets: Responses to Societal Governance Failure|journal=Administrative Theory & Praxis|date=1 May 2002|volume=24|issue=1|pages=175–196|doi=10.1080/10841806.2002.11029344|url=http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/10841806.2002.11029344|accessdate=12 July 2017|issn=1084-1806}}</ref>
== Policy failure == Governance failure may also refer to what can also be described as '''policy failures''' − the effectiveness, efficiency, and resilience of specific [[policies]].<ref name=Newman/> A frequently mentioned example of a policy failure is the [[War on Drugs]].<ref>{{cite web|title=End the Drug War|url=https://foreignpolicy.com/2012/03/20/end-the-drug-war/|publisher=Foreign Policy|accessdate=12 July 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Friesendorf|first1=Cornelius|title=US Foreign Policy and the War on Drugs: Displacing the Cocaine and Heroin Industry|date=2007|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781134123940|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Vxx9AgAAQBAJ&pg=PA19|accessdate=12 July 2017|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Peter|first1=Andreas,|title=A Tale of Two Borders: The U.S.-Mexico and U.S.-Canada Lines After 9/11|journal=Center for Comparative Immigration Studies|date=22 June 2003|url=https://escholarship.org/uc/item/6d09j0n2|accessdate=12 July 2017|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=RONALD REAGAN’S WAR ON DRUGS: A POLICY FAILURE BUT A POLITICAL SUCCESS|url=https://openaccess.leidenuniv.nl/bitstream/handle/1887/21802/Ronald%20Reagan's%20War%20on%20Drugs-A%20Policy%20Failure%20But%20a%20Political%20Success.pdf|accessdate=12 July 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Bagley|first1=Bruce Michael|title=US Foreign Policy and the War on Drugs: Analysis of a Policy Failure|journal=Journal of Interamerican Studies and World Affairs|date=1988|volume=30|issue=2/3|pages=189–212|doi=10.2307/165986|jstor=165986}}</ref> <!--===Institutional failure==-->

The '''Hamas–UNRWA Holocaust dispute''' erupted on 31 August 2009 following a perception in the [[Gaza Strip]] that the [[United Nations Relief and Works Agency]] (UNRWA) planned to include a course on human rights that speaks about the [[Holocaust]] in the eighth-grade curriculum of preparatory schools it runs in the territory. Militant Islamic movement [[Hamas]], which controls the [[Gaza Strip]], protested, calling the Holocaust "a lie made up by the [[Zionist]]s" and demanding the removal of the offending content from the curriculum. Some officials of the United Nations agency initially responded by denying that it teaches the subject of the Holocaust in its schools or that it plans to teach it in its new curriculum.<ref name=argue>{{cite web | url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2009-08/31/content_11973740.htm | title=Hamas, UNRWA argue over "Holocaust" lessons in Gaza | publisher=[[Xinhua News]] |location=Gaza| date=August 31, 2009 | accessdate=January 19, 2018 | author=Saud Ramadan, Emad Drinly| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170314231647/http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2009-08/31/content_11973740.htm| archivedate=March 14, 2017 |deadurl=yes}}</ref><ref name=caught>{{cite web | url=https://www.newsday.com/news/world/un-caught-in-gaza-dispute-over-study-of-holocaust-1.1430963 | title=UN caught in Gaza dispute over study of Holocaust | work=[[Newsday]] | date=September 8, 2009 | accessdate=January 19, 2018 | author=Laub, Karin | agency=[[Associated Press]] | location=Gaza City, Gaza Strip}}</ref><ref name=slams>{{cite web | url=https://www.reuters.com/article/newsMaps/idUSTRE57T1JW20090830 | title=Hamas slams UN over "Holocaust classes" in Gaza | publisher=[[Reuters]] | date=August 31, 2009 | accessdate=January 19, 2018 | author=Nidal al-Mughrabi}}</ref> This denial drew criticism from various groups and individuals.
==Background== UNRWA runs 221 of more than 600 primary and secondary schools in the Gaza Strip, educating some 200,000 children between the ages of 6 and 15.<ref name=argue/> The Gaza Strip has been ruled by Hamas since it seized control of the enclave in June 2007 by defeating Palestinian President [[Mahmoud Abbas]]' security forces. According to the Associated Press, "Hamas has been trying to cement control over Gaza, while the U.N. agency is increasingly emerging as a shadow government, providing services to some 1 million of Gaza's 1.4 million people".<ref name=caught/>
The Holocaust is not taught in U.N.-run schools for Palestinian refugees in the West Bank, Syria, Jordan and Lebanon, nor is it taught in Palestinian government schools in the West Bank or Gaza.<ref name=caught/> There is also no evidence that it was taught in Palestinian schools when these were under Israeli control between 1967 and 1994.
==Hamas protest== Protesting what it said were plans to teach eighth-graders in U.N. schools about the Holocaust, the Hamas-affiliated [[Popular Committee of Palestinian refugees]] sent an open letter to the chief of UNRWA offices calling the Holocaust "a lie made up by the Zionists" and demanding it "immediately" erase the part that speaks about the Holocaust from the Palestinian pupils' curriculum. Husam Ahmed, the Popular Committee's coordinator in the Gaza Strip, said the material, which was to be included in a course on [[human rights]], "was formed in a way that shows sympathy with the Jews".<ref name=argue/>
The interior ministry of the Hamas de facto government in Gaza expressed astonishment over the UNRWA curriculum's acknowledgement of the Holocaust." "We reject teaching our pupils such thoughts that contradicts with our Palestinian beliefs," said the interior ministry statement, which called on the ministry of education "to check if such news is right."<ref name=caught/>
The head of Hamas' education committee in Gaza, [[Abdul Rahman el-Jamal]], said that the Holocaust was a "big lie".<ref name=condemns>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/8230483.stm Hamas condemns Holocaust lessons], BBC News 31-08-2009</ref> Meanwhile, Hamas Education Minister Muhammad Askol criticized UNRWA, saying it was not respecting Hamas's "sovereignty" over Gaza. He said he planned to ask for a meeting with agency officials to "assure the necessary coordination".<ref name=objects/>
Hamas spiritual leader [[Yunis al-Astal]] said teaching children about the Nazi genocide of Jews would be "marketing a lie", and characterized the possible introduction of the subject into Gaza schools as a "war crime".<ref name=objects>{{cite web | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/09/01/AR2009090102496.html?hpid=sec-world | title=Hamas Objects to Possible Lessons on Holocaust in U.N.-Run Schools in Gaza | work=[[Washington Post]] September 2, 2009| accessdate=January 19, 2018 | author=Schneider, Howard}}</ref>
Hamas spokesman [[Sami Abu Zuhri]] said that Hamas rejects any attempt to introduce the Holocaust into the curriculum as "a kind of normalization with Israel and an attempt to bridge the psychological gap between Israel and the Palestinians".<ref name=caught/>
[[Jamila al-Shanti]], a Hamas [[Palestinian Legislative Council|legislative official]], said: "Talk about the Holocaust and the execution of the Jews contradicts and is against our culture, our principles, our traditions, values, heritage and religion".<ref name=objects/>
Mustafa al-Sawwaf, editor of the Hamas-run newspaper [[Filastin (newspaper)|Filastin]], said the U.N. "should also be prevented from implementing this destructive policy that harms our history and civilization as well as our people's culture."<ref name=learn>{{cite web | url=http://washingtontimes.com/news/2009/sep/08/hamas-and-the-holocaust/ | title=EDITORIAL: Hamas and the Holocaust | work=Washington Times | date=September 8, 2009 | accessdate=January 19, 2018}}</ref>
==UNRWA response== UNRWA denied that it teaches the Holocaust in preparatory schools or that the Holocaust is included in the pupils' curriculum. Adnan Abu Hasna, UNRWA spokesman in Gaza, said: "Such reports are totally untrue. The current curriculum that is taught to pupils at UNRWA schools doesn't contain any indication to the subject of the Holocaust".<ref name=argue/>
Similarly, according to the [[Ma'an News Agency]], UNRWA Commissioner-General [[Karen Abu Zayd]] said at a press conference on 1 September, "I can refute allegations that UN school curriculum includes anything about the Holocaust. Anyone can have a look at the school books. Really we focus on human rights in [the] curriculum."<ref>[http://www.maannews.net/eng/ViewDetails.aspx?ID=222848 UNRWA chief: Gaza school curriculum does not include Holocaust], [[Ma'an News Agency]] 01-09-2009</ref> The accuracy of this report was later contested by UNRWA.
The agency also denied that it was planning to include the subject in its new curriculum. Mahmoud al-Hemdeyat, director of education department of UNRWA in the Gaza Strip, said: "UNRWA hasn't finished yet from finalizing the new curriculum... As far as I know, the curriculum doesn't include anything about the Holocaust".<ref name=argue/>
According to the [[Associated Press]] (AP), Karen Abu Zayd suggested information about the Holocaust could be included in later years, but the curriculum being developed was still in draft stage. AP also wrote that UNWRA's website mentioned general plans to include the Holocaust in lessons on the "historical context" that gave rise to the 1948 [[Universal Declaration of Human Rights]].<ref name=caught/>
UNRWA chief in Gaza [[John Ging]] said he believed the dispute over the syllabus had more to do with attempts by Hamas to meddle in the U.N. organization's affairs than with the Holocaust. Ging added that he felt any human rights course is incomplete without discussing the Holocaust, but it would exceed UNWRA's mandate to write texts about the Holocaust and the Palestinian uprooting. According to one UN source, the lessons had been under consideration for the 2009-10 human rights course.<ref name=caught/>
===Disputed quotes=== A statement by UNRWA on 4 September denied unspecified quotes which it said the [[Simon Wiesenthal Center]] had attributed to Karen Abu Zayd and John Ging.<ref>[http://www.unrwa.org/etemplate.php?id=434 Statement by UNRWA on Holocaust Education], UNRWA, 4 September 2009.</ref> The Center had previously quoted Abu Zayd as saying "we focus on human rights in curriculum" and "the murder of 6 million Jews and 5 million other undesirables ... is not a human-rights issue", and Ging as saying "There is no intention to integrate materials and topics [on the Holocaust] that are inconsistent with the desire of Palestinian society." According to one journalist, Abu Zayd's quotes were "untraceable" and Ging's quote was "based on a computer-generated translation of an Arabic-language report by PalToday, a Gaza Strip-based news agency with Islamist sympathies, quoting a Hamas official who purported to quote Ging".<ref>[http://www.jewishexponent.com/article/19543/ UNRWA Denies Holocaust Quotes WASHINGTON (JTA)], Jewish Exponent 10-09-2009</ref>
==Criticism of UNRWA== The United Nations agency was criticized by various parties following initial reports that it would not be introducing discussion of the Holocaust in its human rights education:
United States Congresswoman [[Ileana Ros-Lehtinen]] (R-Fla.) said in a statement that "by disconnecting the Holocaust from human rights, (the U.N. agency) is highlighting the [[antisemitic]] bias that pervades the U.N. system."<ref name=caught/>
The [[Simon Wiesenthal Center]] called for the dismissal of Abu Zayd and Ging and demanded the United States and Canada suspend funding for the U.N. agency pending the resolution of the issue. The United States was the second-largest donor to the agency in 2008, providing nearly $96 million of its $541.8 million budget.<ref name=caught/>
The [[American Jewish Congress]] said in a statement: "It is... discouraging... that the United Nations Relief and Works Agency did not criticize Hamas for denying the children of Gaza knowledge of one of the central events of the 20th century. Instead, it rushed to deny that the Holocaust was being taught in its schools or that it was contemplating teaching it in the future".<ref name=asked>[http://www.jewishtribune.ca/TribuneV2/index.php/200909082049/UNRWA-asked-to-teach-Holocaust-defy-Hamas.html UNRWA asked to teach Holocaust, defy Hamas], Jewish Tribune 08-09-2009</ref>
==Other responses== Jihad Zakarneh, the deputy education minister in the [[West Bank]], said teaching Palestinian children about the Holocaust has to wait until there is a peace agreement with Israel. "When Israel ends its occupation of our land and our people and gives us our right of independence and self-determination, then we discuss this issue with them".<ref name=caught/>
==Aftermath== In October 2009, John Ging told ''[[The Independent]]'' that he was "confident and determined" that the Holocaust would feature in the curriculum, saying, "no human-rights curriculum is complete without the inclusion of the facts of the Holocaust, and its lessons". At the time, the curriculum was expected to be completed within weeks and then put out for consultation with parents and the public.<ref>Donald Macintyre, [https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/un-to-teach-children-about-holocaust-in-gaza-schools-1797763.html "UN to teach children about Holocaust in Gaza schools]," The Independent, 5 October 2009.</ref> In November 2010, Ging confirmed in an interview that the Holocaust was being discussed in UNRWA schools in Gaza, noting "we enrich the curriculum with our human rights program, for all ages. We teach the children about the history of the human rights movement. We grounded our program in the universal declaration of human rights, which is borne out of the horrors of the Second World War. So we teach the children the horrors of the war, including the Holocaust. We are also teaching the kids about the unanimously adopted resolution on Holocaust remembrance, which is a 2005 UN resolution proposed by the state of Israel adopted in the General Assembly".<ref>Adi Schwartz, "[http://www.adi-schwartz.com/unrwas-existence-failure/ UNRWA’s existence is a failure]" (interview with John Ging), Adi Schwartz blog, 15 November 2010.</ref>
UNRWA efforts brought continued criticism from some Palestinian Islamists. One writer for the pro-Hamas [[Palestine Information Center]] warned that "some circles within UNRWA... have been trying to introduce 'the holocaust' {{sic}} into Palestinian school curricula in the Gaza Strip". He suggested that these efforts indicated "a virulent Zionist propensity to brainwash Palestinians, particularly young generations, into accepting or at least understanding Zionism, a hateful fascist political ideology".<ref>Khalid Ameyreh, "[http://www.palestine-info.co.uk/en/default.aspx?xyz=U6Qq7k%2bcOd87MDI46m9rUxJEpMO%2bi1s7uHZEh0iPWAeNUyBMO4MjFv9Au5eS55O7W1IUimwfbTHIB1SRXbZ6ivf8O4STvfR%2fDU2rfcRzzUiB8PGCHwJfENvTsdBBw26fNjv1YTwCB2o%3d We must not accept holocaust propaganda in our schools]," Palestine Information Center, 5 June 2010.</ref>
Further controversy erupted when it became known that UNRWA, as part of a project that brought its top human rights students from Gaza to the United States for a visit, had taken them to an exhibit on the Holocaust at UN headquarters in New York.<ref>No Sharp Objects (documentary, 2010), video excerpts available on "[https://www.theguardian.com/world/video/2010/dec/10/gaza-boys-no-sharp-objects-documentary Documentary follows 15 boys from Gaza on trip to US]," ''The Guardian'', 10 December 2010.</ref><ref>"[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/dec/19/hamas-un-palestinian-trip-holocaust Hamas in dispute with UN over school trips for Palestinian pupils]," The Guardian, 19 December 2010.</ref><ref>"[http://prrnblog.wordpress.com/2010/12/20/hamas-unrwa-and-human-rights-education/ Hamas, UNRWA, and Human Rights Education]," Palestinian Refugee ResearchNet blog, 20 December 2010.</ref> According to a statement issued by the Hamas refugee department, "We denounce this suspicious act in hopes that UNRWA education officials in the Gaza Strip will not repeat it; and we hope the Palestinian Authority will take a national stand to put a stop to ideological corruption on Palestine's youth."<ref>"[http://www.palestine-info.co.uk/En/default.aspx?xyz=U6Qq7k%2bcOd87MDI46m9rUxJEpMO%2bi1s7BHZU4scReZyDBxFz4OdzpiDXqBEyPlODlakAb9ziW3S81rjt02%2fmxJPu3m89trJ5utY7XE1dAj0jhK7WY4wVYVRCVKLHQ2WK0978wpmpSDM%3d Hamas castigates UNRWA for taking students to sightsee holocaust centers]," Palestine Information Center, 18 December 2010.</ref>

{{Orphan|date=July 2015}}
''Infrastructure for Peace'' is a new approach in [[peacebuilding]] which gained momentum after locally led and participatory peacebuilding practices tended to yield effective results in some countries beset by conflicts. It underpins the ideas of [[conflict transformation]] and stresses on under-girding the politically negotiated settlements at top level by peacebuilding efforts at the grassroots.
==Definition== In 2010, governments, political parties, civil society and [[United Nations]] country representatives from 14 African countries in [[Kenya]] agreed upon a working definition of ''infrastructures for peace'' as a ‘dynamic network of interdependent structures, mechanisms, resources, values and skills which, through dialogue and consultation, contribute to conflict prevention and [[peacebuilding]] in a society’.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=JPD Editors|title=The Evolving Landscape of Infrastructures for Peace|journal=Journal of Peacebuilding & Development|date=2012|volume=7|issue=3|pages=1–7|doi=10.1080/15423166.2013.774793|url=http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/15423166.2013.774793#.VXvjcfmqqko}}</ref>
==Examples== Studies exemplify [[National Peace Council (Ghana)]], Department on Ethnic, Religious Policy and Civil Society Interaction (Kyrgyzstan)<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Kumar|first1=Chetan|last2=de la Haye|first2=Jos|title=‘Hybrid Peacemaking: Building National "Infrastructures for Peace"’|journal=Global Governance|date=2012|volume=18|issue=1|pages=13–20|url=http://www.undp.org/content/dam/undp/library/crisis%20prevention/UNDP_BCPR_Chetan%20Kumar_Infrastructures%20for%20Peace.pdf}}</ref> and economical approaches in Guyana, Bolivia and Kenya and the [[United Nations Development Programme]] contributes to about 30 infrastructures for peace projects around the globe.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Ryan|first1=Jordan|title=Infrastructures for Peace as a Path to Resilient Societies: An Institutional Perspective|journal=Journal of Peacebuilding & Development|date=December 2012|volume=7|issue=3|pages=14–24|doi=10.1080/15423166.2013.774806|url=http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/15423166.2013.774806#.VXvk9Pmqqko}}</ref>
==Criticisms== Critical studies on the ''infrastructure for peace'' mainly see this as a fuzzy concept because [[peacebuilding]] cannot be guaranteed only by local efforts. Such local infrastructures are prone to suffer from political upheavals,<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Chuma|first1=Aeneas|last2=Ojielo|first2=Ozonnia|title=Building a Standing National Capacity for Conflict Prevention and Resolution in Kenya|journal=Journal of Peacebuilding & Development|date=December 2012|volume=7|issue=3|pages=25–39|doi=10.1080/15423166.2013.774790}}</ref> they still rely on external funding and cannot do well under strictly autocratic regimes.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Odendaal|first1=Andries|title=The Political Legitimacy of National Peace Committees|journal=Journal of Peacebuilding & Development|date=December 2012|volume=7|issue=3|pages=40–53|doi=10.1080/15423166.2013.767601}}</ref> [http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/21647259.2016.1156813?journalCode=rpcb20 New research works], which conflate infrastructures for peace with [[security sector reform]] have also suggested such architectures need to rise above local boundaries to negotiate on security issues because (in)security has transnational connections.<ref>Ghimire, Safal. 2016. [http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/21647259.2016.1156813?src=recsys&journalCode=rpcb20 Making Security Sector Reform Organic: Infrastructures for Peace as an Entry Point?] In: Peacebuilding, DOI:[[10.1080/21647259.2016.1156813]]</ref>
==Contributions== Academic conferences, special editions of journals, issue-specific books and websites dedicated to this topic have begun to emerge including the [http://www.une.edu.au/about-une/academic-schools/school-of-humanities/study-areas/peace-studies/peace-studies-conference UNE Peace Studies Conference (2015)] on questioning 'peace formation' and 'peace infrastructure' , [http://www.i4pinternational.org/infrastructures-for-peace I4P International website] , [http://www.berghof-foundation.org/training/berghof-handbook-for-conflict-transformation/handbook-dialogues/10-peace-infrastructures/ Berghof Handbook]<ref>{{cite book|last1=Unger|first1=B|last2=Lundström|first2=S|last3=Austin|first3=B|last4=Planta|first4=K|title=Peace Infrastructures: Assessing Concept and Practice (Berghof Handbook Dialogue Series, No. 10)|date=2013|publisher=Berghof Foundation|location=Berlin|url=http://www.berghof-foundation.org/fileadmin/redaktion/Publications/Handbook/Dialogues/dialogue10_peaceinfrastructures_complete.pdf}}</ref> and a [http://www.tandfonline.com/toc/rjpd20/7/3#.VXvabvmqqko Journal of Peacebuilding and Development Special Edition in Vol. 7, No. 3.]

'''Irenicism''' in [[Christian theology]] refers to attempts to unify Christian [[apologetical]] systems by using [[reason]] as an essential attribute. The word is derived from the [[Greek language|Greek]] word ''ειρήνη (eirene)'' meaning [[peace]]. It is a concept related to [[natural theology]] and opposed to [[polemicism]] (war-like argumentation) being rooted in the ideals of [[pacifism]]{{fact|date=June 2017}}. Those who affiliate themselves with irenicism identify the importance of unity in the Christian church, and declare the common bond between all Christians under [[Christ]]. ==Erasmus and his influence== [[Desiderius Erasmus]] was a [[Christian humanist]] and reformer, in the sense of checking clerical abuses, honoring inner [[piety]], considering reason as meaningful in theology as in other ways. He also promoted the notion that Christianity must remain under one church, both theologically and literally; under the body of the [[Catholic Church]]. Since his time, irenicism has postulated removing conflicts between different Christian creeds by way of mediation and gradual amalgamation of theological differences. Erasmus wrote extensively on topics related generally to peace, and an irenic approach is part of the texture of his thought, both on theology and in relation to politics:
Despite the frequency and severity of polemics directed against him, Erasmus continued ... to practice a kind of discourse that is critical and ironic, yet modest and irenic.Terence J. Martin, ''Living Words: Studies in Dialogues about Religion'' (1998), p. 278.
Certain important irenic contributions from Erasmus helped to further the humanist consideration of themes of peace and religious conciliation; these included the ''Inquisitio de fide'' (1524), arguing against the papal opinion that [[Martin Luther]] was a heretic, and ''De sarcienda ecclesiae concordia'' (1533). Erasmus had close associates sharing his views ([[Julius von Pflug]], [[Christoph von Stadion]], and [[Jakob Ziegler]]), and was followed on the Catholic side by [[George Cassander]] and [[Georg Witzel]].Peter G. Bietenholz, Thomas Brian Deutscher, ''Contemporaries of Erasmus: A Biographical Register of the Renaissance and Reformation'' (2003), p. 78, p. 275 and p. 475.http://www.science.uva.nl/~seop/archives/win2008/entries/erasmus/Nick Thompson, ''The Long Reach of Reformation Irenicism: the Considerationes Modestae et Pacificae of William Forbes (1585–1634).'' pp. 124–147 in ''Reforming the Reformation'' (2004); [http://www.abdn.ac.uk/~wad005/documents/forbes.pdf PDF] (at p. 2 and p. 8). The influence of Erasmus was, however, limited, by the virtual exclusion of his works from countries such as France, from 1525, at least in the open; though they did appear in numerous forms and translations. James Hutton speaks of "the surreptitious manner in which Erasmus' peace propaganda reached the French public."James Hutton, ''Themes of Peace in Renaissance Poetry'' (1984), p. 146. [[Franciscus Junius (the elder)|Franciscus Junius]] published in 1593 ''Le paisible Chrestien'' arguing for [[religious tolerance]] and [[Ecumenism]]. He addressed [[Philip II of Spain]], using arguments taken from the French ''[[politique]]'' statesman [[Michel de l'Hôpital]] and reformer [[Sebastian Castellio]].Martin van Gelderen, ''The Political Thought of the Dutch Revolt 1555–1590'' (2002), p. 83; [https://books.google.com/books?id=hXK2fxzn2lAC&pg=PA83 Google Books]. ==17th century: Catholics and Protestants== Irenic movements were influential in the 17th century, and irenicism, for example in the form of [[Gottfried Leibniz]]'s efforts to reunite Catholics and Protestants, is in some ways a forerunner to the more modern [[ecumenical]] movements. The 1589 ''Examen pacifique de la doctrine des Huguenots'' by [[Henry Constable]] proved influential, for example on [[Christopher Potter]] and [[William Forbes (bishop)|William Forbes]]. [[Richard Montagu]] admired Cassander and [[Andreas Fricius]].Anthony Milton, ''Catholic and Reformed: The Roman and Protestant Churches in English Protestant Thought, 1600–1640'' (2002), pp. 248–9; [https://books.google.com/books?id=stwluHDJsQgC&pg=PA248 Google Books]. The 1628 ''Syllabus aliquot synodorum'' was a bibliography of the literature of religious concord, compiled by [[Jean Hotman, Marquis de Villers-St-Paul]] decades earlier, and seen into print by [[Hugo Grotius]] using the pseudonym "Theodosius Irenaeus," with a preface by [[Matthias Bernegger]].W. B. Patterson, ''King James VI and I and the Reunion of Christendom'' (2000), p. 149; [https://books.google.com/books?id=zYK_Czpa1WwC&pg=PA149 Google Books]. It was typical enough, however, for moderate and even irenical writers on the Catholic side to find in this period that their arguments were turned back against Catholicism. This style of arguing developed in England from [[Thomas Bell (priest)|Thomas Bell]] and particularly [[Thomas Morton (bishop)|Thomas Morton]]. It led to [[Thomas James]] mining [[Marcantonio de Dominis]] and [[Paolo Sarpi]], and making efforts to claim Witzel for the Protestant tradition; to the arguments of [[Gallicanism]] being welcomed but also treated as particularly insidious; and an irenist such as [[Francis a Sancta Clara]] being attacked strongly by firm [[Calvinist]]s. The handful of Protestant writers who were convinced in their irenic approach to Catholics included [[William Covell]] and [[Thomas Dove (theologian)|Thomas Dove]].Anthony Milton, ''Catholic and Reformed: The Roman and Protestant Churches in English Protestant Thought, 1600–1640'' (2002), pp. 233–9. ==17th century: Protestant divisions== [[James I of England]] thought that the Bible translation he commissioned might effect some reconciliation between the English Protestant religious factions, and prove an ''irenicon''.{{cite book |first=Adam |last=Nicolson |title=God's Secretaries |year=2003 |page=66}} The Greek ἐιρηνικόν (''eirenikon'') or peace proposal is also seen as ''irenicum'' in its Latin version. An irenic literature developed, relating to divisions within Protestantism, particularly in the twenty years after the [[Peace of Westphalia]]. Examples marked out by title are: *[[David Pareus]], ''Irenicum sive de unione et synodo Evangelicorum'' (1614)http://www.ccel.org/s/schaff/encyc/encyc11/htm/old/0238=218.htm *[[John Forbes (died 1648)|John Forbes]], ''Irenicum Amatoribus Veritatis et Pacis in Ecclesia Scotiana'' (Aberdeen, 1629)http://www.ccel.org/s/schaff/encyc/encyc04/htm/0356=340.htm *[[Jeremiah Burroughs]], ''Irenicum'' (1653) *[[John Dury]], ''Irenicum: in quo casus conscientiæ inter ecclesias evangelicas pacis, breviter proponuntur & decidunter'' (1654) *[[Daniel Zwicker]], ''Irenicum irenicorum'' (1658) *[[Edward Stillingfleet]], ''Irenicum: A Weapon Salve for the Church's Wounds'' (1659 and 1661) *[[Matthew Newcomen]]. ''Irenicum; or, An essay towards a brotherly peace & union, between those of the congregational and presbyterian way'' (1659) *[[Moses Amyraut]], ''Irenicum sive de ratione pacis in religionis negotio inter Evangelicos'' (1662)http://www.ccel.org/ccel/schaff/creeds1.ix.ii.xi.html *[[Samuel Mather (minister)|Samuel Mather]], ''Irenicum: or an Essay for Union'' (1680) [[Isaac Newton]] wrote an ''Irenicum'' (unpublished manuscript); it supported a [[latitudinarian]] position in theology, derived from a review of church history.James E. Force, [[Richard Henry Popkin]], ''Newton and Religion: Context, Nature, and Influence'' (1999), p. 146 and p. 175. ==Evaluation of early modern irenicism== Anthony Milton writes:
[Ecumenical historians] have tended to assume the existence of an irenical 'essentialism' in which the association of Christian unity with peace, toleration and ecumenism is presupposed. [...] In fact, most thinkers of this period accepted that religious unity was a good idea, in the same way that they believed that sin was a bad idea. The problem was that, of course, different people wanted irenicism on different terms. [...] Different interpretations of irenicism could have direct political implications, making the rhetoric of Christian unity an important tool in the political conflicts of the period.Anthony Milton, ''’The Unchanged Peacemaker’? John Dury and the politics of Irenicism in England, 1628–1643'', p. 96 in Mark Greengrass (editor), ''Samuel Hartlib and Universal Reformation: Studies in Intellectual Communication'' (2002).
It is in that light that he comments on the irenists' succession: Erasmus, Cassander, [[Jacob Acontius]], Grotius, then John Dury, who spent much time on a proposed reconciliation of Lutherans and Calvinists. ==Modern usage== ''Irenical'' has become a commonly used adjective to design an idealist and pacific conception, such as the [[democratic peace theory]]. ''False irenicism'' or ''false eirenism'' is an expression used in certain 20th-century documents of the Catholic Church to criticize attempts at ecumenism that would allow Catholic doctrine to be distorted or clouded. Documents using the term include the encyclical ''[[Humani generis]]'', promulgated by [[Pope Pius XII]] in 1950, the [[Second Vatican Council]]'s 1964 Decree on [[Ecumenism]], ''[[Unitatis Redintegratio]],'' and [[Pope John Paul II]]'s 1984 post-synodal apostolic exhortation, ''[[Reconciliatio et paenitentia]]''. ==Notes== {{Reflist}} ==Further reading== *Howard Louthan (1997), ''The Quest for Compromise: Peacemakers in Counter-Reformation Vienna'' *Joris van Eijnatten (1998), ''Mutua Christianorum Tolerantia: Irenicism and Toleration in the Netherlands: The Stinstra Affair, 1740–1745'' *Samuel J. T. Miller, ''Molanus, Lutheran Irenicist (1633–1722)'' Church History, Vol. 22, No. 3 (Sep., 1953), pp. 197–218 *Bodo Nischan, ''John Bergius: Irenicism and the Beginnings of Official Religious Toleration in Brandenburg-Prussia'', Church History, vol. 51 (1982), pp. 389–404 *Michael B. {{Taxation in the Ottoman Empire sidebar}} '''İspençe''' was a tax levied on [[non-Muslim]]s in the [[Ottoman Empire]].<ref>{{cite book|title=ACCOUNTING METHOD USED BY OTTOMANS FOR 500 YEARS: STAIRS (MERDIBAN) METHOD|pages=192|url=http://www.sgb.gov.tr/Publications/Accounting%20Method%20Used%20By%20Ottomans%20For%20500%20Years%20-%20Stairs%20(Merdiban)%20Method.pdf}}</ref><ref name=morea>{{cite book|title=A historical and economic geography of Ottoman Greece: the southwestern Morea in the 18th century|year=2005|publisher=ASCSA|isbn=978-0-87661-534-8|pages=24|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Ju9sKUox3OcC&dq=ispence&source=gbs_navlinks_s}}</ref>
İspençe was a land-tax on non-Muslims in parts of the Ottoman Empire; its counterpart, for Muslim taxpayers, was the resm-i çift - which was set at slightly lower rate.<ref name=Malcolm>{{cite book|last=Malcolm|first=Noel|title=Kosovo: A Short History|year=1999|publisher=Harper Perennial|isbn=978-0-06-097775-7}}</ref> The treasury was well aware of the difference in tax takes, and the incentive to convert; the legal reforms of [[Bayezid II]] halved some criminal penalties on nonmuslim taxpayers "''so that the taxpayers shall not vanish''";<ref>{{cite book|last=Heyd|first=Uriel|title=Studies in old Ottoman criminal law|year=1973|publisher=Clarendon Press|pages=156, 287}}</ref> this rule was reconfimed, a century later, in 1587. In other cases, local taxes were imposed on nonmuslims specifically to encourage conversion.<ref name=Malcolm/>
İspençe had existed in the Balkans before the Ottoman conquest; the Ottoman Empire typically adapted local taxes and institutions in each conquered area, leading to a patchwork of different taxes and rates. The concept of İspençe, theoretically a payment in lieu of [[corvee labour]], was derived from the Byzantine "zeugaratikion", a land tax based on the [[zeugarion]] - the area of farmland which could be ploughed by a pair of oxen. The zeugarion itself was taken up as the Ottoman "[[çift]]", a word meaning "pair".<ref name=Malcolm/>
==Variation== Despite taxes being set centrally, by the [[Ottoman Porte|Porte]], there was some local variance; around 1718. the [[kadı]] of Janjevo complained to Istanbul that the local lord set ispençe at 80 [[akçe]]s per year rather than official rate of 32.<ref name=Malcolm/>
As with other [[Taxation in the Ottoman Empire|Ottoman taxes]], there were various exemptions and loopholes; royal hunters, who provided birds-of-prey to the court, had an exemption from ispençe (and other taxes); they could pass on their job, and the tax exemption, to their sons.<ref name=Acun>{{cite journal|last=Acun|first=Fatma|title=The Other Side of the Coin: Tax Exemptions within the Context of Ottoman Taxation History|journal=Bulgarian Historical Review|year=2002}}</ref> There were also some exemptions for those unable to work their land through disability, although it was expected that the elderly would have children able to work and therefore to pay ispençe.
The tax was paid by adult male heads of households; in the [[Morea]] it increased to 25 akces (from 20) between 1480 and 1512, and stayed at a similar level after that, (for most), confirmed by the tahrir of 1583; but widows may have paid a reduced rate, and Jews may have paid 125 akces.<ref name=morea/>

[[File:Map Languages CH.png|thumb|400px|right|Map of Switzerland showing in purple color the Italian-speaking areas, where Italian irredentism was strongest.]]
'''Italian irredentism in Switzerland''' was a political movement that promoted the unification to [[Italy]] of the Italian-speaking areas of [[Switzerland]] during the [[Risorgimento]].
==History==
In the early 19th century the ideals of unification in a single Nation of all the territories populated by Italian speaking people created the [[Italian irredentism]].
In southern Switzerland those ideals were minimally followed until the creation of the [[Kingdom of Italy (1861–1946)|Kingdom of Italy]] in 1861 and up to [[World War I]].
Following the rise to power of [[Italian Fascism]], however, the initial moderate irredentism started to change to one full of aggression: the same [[Benito Mussolini]] created in the early 1930s the ''Partito Fascista Ticinese'' (Ticino Fascist Party).<ref>[http://www.fpct.ch/pubblicazioni/generale/1986_fraromaeberna.shtml Fra Roma e Berna, di Mauro Cerutti (in Italian)] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110830110602/http://www.fpct.ch/pubblicazioni/generale/1986_fraromaeberna.shtml |date=2011-08-30 }}</ref> The main ideal of this party was to bring the Italian frontier up to the [[Gotthard Pass|Gottardo Pass]] (''Catena mediana delle Alpi'' <ref>[http://www.italiasvizzera150.it/img-schede/8-img1.jpg Map of "Catena mediana delle Alpi" as possible northern Italian border in Switzerland]</ref>) in the Alps through political unrest and possible referendums (supported, in case of need, by the Italian Army).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.italiasvizzera150.it/studenti.cfm?target=8|title=Italia-Svizzera: la storia dal 1861 al 2011|first=Contechnet.it massimo|last=rossi|publisher=|accessdate=12 January 2017}}</ref>
In 1934 was done a small tentative by the Ticino fascists: the March on Bellinzona", similar to the [[March on Rome]]. But it was successfully contrasted by socialist organizations, like "Liberi e Svizzeri" of Guglielmo Canevascini, promoted even by the Swiss government.<ref>M. Cerutti, Fra Roma e Berna. La Svizzera italiana nel ventennio fascista, p. 465.</ref>
Successively, in the 1935 elections the fascists obtained just 2% of the votes and since then their movement faded away to less than 100 members.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wArTkIKE7WAC&pg=PA164&lpg=PA164&dq=marcia%20su%20bellinzona%201934&source=bl&ots=M7NuGyUtLJ&sig=B8Mka8gIAdIpIFTalz1R9NVqWDk&hl=it&ei=UUmFTNraH5qKnAe4v5yTAQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=8&ved=0CDAQ6AEwBw#v=onepage&q=marcia%20su%20bellinzona%201934&f=false|title=Il cattolicesimo ticinese e i fascismi: la Chiesa e il partito conservatore ticinese nel periodo tra le due guerre mondiali|date=1 January 1999|publisher=Saint-Paul|accessdate=12 January 2017|via=Google Books}}</ref> [[Image:RegioniIrredenteItalia.jpg|thumb|right|300px|Map of the Italian areas called "irredente" in 1918. Ticino in green]] Before [[World War II]] the Italian irredentism in Switzerland was reduced to have followers mainly between the descendants of Italians emigrated to Ticino at the end of the 19th century, but was ruled and promoted by a small group of ticino intellectuals with their active newspapers and propaganda.
The most important of these intellectuals was Teresina Bontempi, who created the magazine ''L'Adula''. She denounced in her writings, together with Rosetta Colombi, the [[germanization]] of Canton Ticino promoted by the Swiss government.<ref>[http://www.ps-ticino.ch/sonvico/mondo/pubblicazioni/Crespi,Ticino%20irredento04.htm Il sogno irredentista del Ticino (in Italian)]</ref> Indeed, the German speaking population in Canton Ticino went from 2.6% in 1837 to 5.34% in 1920 and nearly 10% in 1940.
As a consequence of this political activity she was involved in continuous problems with the Swiss government, that finally jailed her in 1936.<ref>Ilse Shneiderfranken.Le industrie del Canton Ticino. Belinzona, 1937</ref> She was forced to move to Italy as a political refugee after some months.
The most renowned fascist born in Canton Ticino was Aurelio Garobbio, who tried to imitate [[Gabriele D'Annunzio]] with his organization called ''Giovani Ticinesi''.<ref>Garobbio, Aurelio. ''Gabriele D'Annunzio e i «Giovani Ticinesi»: le vicende de «L'Adula»'' p. 45</ref> After 1935 Garobbio was the main responsible of the Italian irredentism in Switzerland and was with Mussolini until his death in spring 1945, when tried to organize a last fascist area of defense in [[Valtellina]] next to Ticino.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2m_xg6W8oGUC&pg=PA165&lpg=PA165&dq=aurelio%20garobbio&source=bl&ots=eL5Ipaj9P7&sig=Pn59UpC7B2OtcpxsUeI5toJj08I&hl=it&ei=RG2FTKqQHNOfnQeG4ZTxDg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CBQQ6AEwADgU#v=onepage&q=aurelio%20garobbio&f=false|title=Com'era rossa la mia valle: una storia di antiresistenza in Valtellina|first=Giuseppe|last=Rocco|date=1 January 1992|publisher=GRECO & GRECO Editori|accessdate=12 January 2017|via=Google Books}}</ref>
==See also==
* [[Italia irredenta]] * [[Italian immigration to Switzerland]] * [[Risorgimento]] * [[Swiss Italians]] * [[Teresina Bontempi]]

Dalla battaglia culturale dell'"Adula" ai piani d'invasione''. Edizioni Franco Angeli. Milano, 2004. * Dosi, Davide. ''ll cattolicesimo ticinese e i fascismi: la Chiesa e il partito conservatore ticinese nel periodo tra le due guerre mondiali''. Editore Saint-Paul. Lugano, 1999 {{ISBN|2827108569}} * Garobbio, Aurelio. ''Gabriele D'Annunzio e i «Giovani Ticinesi»: le vicende de «L'Adula»'', Editore Centro Studi Atesini. Trento, 1988. * Lurati, Ottavio. ''Dialetto e italiano regionale nella Svizzera italiana''. Lugano, 1976. * Schneiderfranken, Ilse. ''Le industrie del Canton Ticino''. Bellinzona, 1937. * sulle quattro valli italofone (Mesolcina, Calanca, di Poschiavo, Bregaglia) e su Bivio, Vignoli, Giulio, ''I territori italofoni non appartenenti alla Repubblica Italiana agraristica''. Giuffrè, Milano, 1995.

{{Unreferenced|date=December 2009}} '''Jantantrik Bahujan Samaj Party''' (Democratic Majority Society Party), splinter group of [[Bahujan Samaj Party]] (BSP) formed in 1997 when 19 BSP Members of the Legislative Assembly of [[Uttar Pradesh]] broke away. JBSP allied themselves with [[Bharatiya Janata Party]] (BJP) and joined the [[National Democratic Alliance (India)|National Democratic Alliance]]. In UP they gave their support to [[Kalyan Singh]]'s government. 17 out of the JBSP MLAs were inducted as ministers in the state government. The president of JBSP was DP Yadav ([[Rajya Sabha]] MP) and the general secretary Shahidullah Khan.
JBSP became an unstable party, and suffered various splits. Four MLAs defected to [[Lok Jan Shakti Party]]. Another splinter group was [[Kisan Mazdoor Bahujan Party]].
When JBSP fell apart DP Yadav organized a new party, [[Rashtriya Parivartan Dal]].
JBSP should not be confused with another BSP splinter group, [[Loktantrik Bahujan Samaj Party]].

'''Libertarian anarchism''' may refer to: * [[Anarchism]], a political philosophy that advocates stateless societies, usually considered a radical left-wing ideology * [[Autarchism]], a political philosophy that upholds the principle of individual liberty, rejects compulsory government and supports the elimination of government in favor of ruling oneself and no other * [[Free-market anarchism]], a political philosophy that advocates the elimination of the state in favor of individual sovereignty, private property and open markets ** [[Agorism]], a revolutionary form of free-market anarchism that focuses on employing counter-economic activity to undermine the state ** [[Anarcho-capitalism]], a political philosophy that advocates the elimination of the state in favor of individual sovereignty, private property and open markets (many anarchists dispute this as a form of anarchism and argue it is a misuse of the term) ** [[Left-wing market anarchism]], a political philosophy that strongly affirms the classical liberal ideas of self-ownership and free markets, while maintaining that taken to their logical conclusions these ideas support "anti-capitalist" positions * [[Libertarianism]], an individualist political philosophy that upholds liberty as its primary focus and principal objective * [[Voluntaryism]], a political philosophy which holds that all forms of human association should be voluntary
== See also == * ''Libertarian Anarchy: Against the State'', a book by [[Gerard Casey (philosopher)|Gerard Casey]] that promotes anarcho-capitalism
