{{terrorism}}
'''Right-wing terrorism''' is [[terrorism]] motivated by a variety of ideologies and beliefs, including [[Islamophobia]], [[anti-communism]], [[neo-fascism]] and [[neo-Nazism]]. This type of terrorism has been sporadic, with little or no international cooperation.{{sfn|Aubrey|2004|p= 45}} Modern radical right-wing terrorism first appeared in [[Western Europe]] in the 1970s and it first appeared in [[Eastern Europe]] following the [[dissolution of the Soviet Union]].{{sfn|Moghadam|Eubank|2006|p=57}}
Right-wing terrorists aim to overthrow governments and replace them with [[nationalism|nationalist]] or [[fascism|fascist]]-oriented regimes.{{sfn|Aubrey|2004|p= 45}} The core of this movement includes [[white power skinhead|neo-fascist skinheads]], [[Far-right politics|far-right]] [[Football hooliganism|hooligans]], youth sympathisers and intellectual guides who believe that the state must rid itself of foreign elements in order to protect its ''rightful'' citizens.{{sfn|Moghadam|Eubank|2006|pp=57-58}} However, they usually lack a rigid ideology.{{sfn|Moghadam|Eubank|2006|p=58}} {{toclimit|3}}
== Causes == {{unreferenced section|date=August 2017}} Armin Falk and colleagues suggests that Right-Wing Extremist Crime (REC), which includes anti-foreigner and racist motivations, is associated with unemployment rates (261). Consequently, as unemployment rates increase, REC also increases. This correlation can be found in several countries including Germany, United States, and the United Kingdom. Additionally, this phenomenon is not necessarily associated with individuals, rather unemployment impacts society's humanitarian values of tolerance and altruism. Meaning, as unemployment rates increase, humanitarian values of tolerance and altruism decrease according to Falk. This cause of right-wing terrorism can be associated with a functionalist perspective on employment. Ferrante defines a functionalist approach as "how the parts of society contribute in expected and unexpected way of maintain an existing social order" (26). Work and employment serve several functions for society (University of Minnesota 12.2). The University of Minnesota Library suggests that employment provides workers with an income and also contributes to their self-identity and fulfillment (12.2). When employment is low, this leads to a perceived threat towards self-identity and fulfillment which can then lead to a larger possibility for right-wing terrorism to occur.
A second cause of right-wing terrorism as Thomas Greven suggests, is [[populism]], or more accurately, [[right-wing populism]]. Jan-Werner Muller describes populism as a form of [[identity politics]] that is inherently anti-establishment and anti-pluralist (3). More simply put, populism supports the advancement of 'the average citizen', and it does not support the agendas of the privileged elite. Furthermore, Greven defines right-wing populist as those who support [[ethnocentrism]], and [[opposition to immigration|oppose immigration]] (3). Right-wing populist policies that have recently been covered in the media include the [[Executive Order 13769]], which is the travel ban from Muslim-majority countries to the United States, and the [[Immigration policy of Donald Trump]] which proposes that a wall should be built between the United States and Mexico in order to prevent illegal immigrants from coming to the United States. Greven suggests that immigration policy not only threatens economic competition, but also threatens traditional values and identities (5). Due to the ethnocentric motivations behind these policies, they are classified as right-wing populism. Because right-wing populism creates a climate of 'us versus them', terrorism is more likely to occur according to Greven. This cause of right-wing terrorism can be associated with a conflict perspective. Ferrante explains the conflict perspective as a focus on conflict regarding scarce resources and the strategies advantaged groups used to perpetuate social agreement arrangements from which they benefit (30). When people feel as though their traditional values are being threatened by the social elite who contribute to the rise in immigration, conflict ensues, and terrorism follows.
== Africa == ===South Africa=== In 1993 [[Chris Hani]], the General Secretary of the [[South African Communist Party]] was murdered by Polish-born far-right anti-Communist [[Janusz Waluś]] who had been lent a firearm by far-right pro-Apartheid MP [[Clive Derby-Lewis]]. The [[Afrikaner Weerstandsbeweging]], a neo-Nazi paramilitary organisation, has often been described as terrorist. In 2010 South African authorities foiled a plot by far-right terrorists to commit attacks as revenge for the murder of [[Eugène Terre'Blanche]], seizing explosives and firearms.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/may/07/south-africa-white-extremist-bomb|title=South African police foil white extremist bomb plot|first=David|last=Smith|date=7 May 2010|publisher=|via=The Guardian}}</ref>
== Americas == === Brazil === During [[Brazilian military government|Brazil's military government]], some right-wing military engaged in violent repression. The [[Riocentro#1981 May Day Attack|Riocentro 1981 May Day Attack]] was a bombing attempt that happened on the night of April 30, 1981. Severe casualties were suffered by the terrorists. While an NGO held a fundraiser fighting for democracy and free elections and celebrating the upcoming holiday, a bomb exploded at Riocentro parking area killing army seargent Guilherme Pereira do Rosário and severely wounding captain Wilson Dias Machado, who survived the bomb explosion. The bomb exploded inside a car where both were preparing it. Rosário died instantaneously. They were the only casualties.
The [[Para-SAR]] example<ref name="para-sar2-br">{{cite news|title=Brasileiros magazine|url=http://brasileiros.com.br/2014/03/o-paraquedista-que-evitou-um-banho-de-sangue/}}</ref><ref name="para-sar1-br">{{cite news|title=Fatos magazine|date=June 1, 1985|url=http://www.arqanalagoa.ufscar.br/pdf/recortes/R04927.pdf}}</ref> was revealed by [[Brazilian Air Force]] captain Sérgio Ribeiro Miranda de Carvalho in 1968 before it reached the execution phase as it was made public to the press after a meeting with his superior Brigadier General João Paulo Burnier and chief of Para-SAR unity. Burnier discussed a secret plan to bomb a dense traffic area of [[Rio de Janeiro]] known as "[[Gasômetro]]" during commute and later claim that Communists were the perpetrators. He expected to be able to run a witch-hunt against the growing political military opposition. Burnier also mentioned his intentions on making the Para-SAR, a [[Brazilian Air Force]] rescue unity, a tool for eliminating some military government political oppositors throwing them to the sea at a wide distance of the coast. On both of these events, no military involved on these actions or planning was arrested, charged or faced retaliation from the [[Brazilian military government]]. The only exception is captain Sérgio de Carvalho which had to leave the air force for facing his superiors retaliation after whistleblowing brigadier Burnier's plan.
=== Colombia === [[Anti-guerrilla paramilitarism in Colombia|Colombian paramilitary groups]] were responsible for most of the human rights violations in the latter half of the ongoing [[Colombian conflict]].<ref name="icc-paras">{{cite news|title=International Criminal Court Scrutinises Paramilitary Crimes |author=Constanza Vieira |work=Inter Press Service |date=August 27, 2008 |url=http://ipsnews.net/news.asp?idnews=43696 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110610224121/http://ipsnews.net/news.asp?idnews=43696 |archivedate=June 10, 2011 |df= }}</ref> The first paramilitary terrorist<ref>{{cite journal |first=Dennis M. |last=Rempe |authorlink= |coauthors= |date=Winter 1995 |title=Guerrillas, Bandits, and Independent Republics: US Counter-insurgency Efforts in Colombia 1959–1965 |journal=Small Wars and Insurgencies |volume=6 |issue=3 |pages=304–27 |id= |url=http://www.icdc.com/~paulwolf/colombia/smallwars.htm |doi=10.1080/09592319508423115 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100330101500/http://www.icdc.com/~paulwolf/colombia/smallwars.htm |archivedate=March 30, 2010 }}</ref> groups were organized by U.S. military advisers who were sent during the [[Cold War]] to combat the spread of leftist politicians, activists and guerrillas.<ref name="bandits">[http://www.icdc.com/~paulwolf/colombia/smallwars.htm Rempe, 1995] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100330101500/http://www.icdc.com/~paulwolf/colombia/smallwars.htm |date=March 30, 2010 }}</ref>{{sfn|Livingstone|2003|p= 155}}
According to several international human rights and governmental organizations, right-wing paramilitary groups were responsible for at least 70 to 80% of political murders in Colombia per year.<ref name="icc-paras"/><ref name="hrw-killnet-iii">HRW, 1996: [https://www.hrw.org/reports/1996/killer3.htm "III: The Intelligence Reorganization"]</ref>
This groups were financed and protected by elite landowners, drug traffickers, members of the security forces, right wing politicians and multinational corporations.<ref>{{cite book|last=Schulte-Bockholt|first=Alfredo|title=The Politics of Organized Crime and the Organized Crime of Politics: a study in criminal power|publisher=Lexington|year=2006|page=95}}</ref><ref name="chernick-para-nacla">{{cite journal|title=The paramilitarization of the war in Colombia|author=Marc Chernick|work=NACLA Report on the Americas|date=March–April 1998|volume=31|issue=5|page=28}}</ref>{{Sfn|Brittain|Petras|2010|pp= 129–31}}<ref name="evil-hour-68-69">{{cite book|author=Forrest Hylton|title=Evil Hour in Colombia|publisher=Verso|year=2006|isbn=978-1-84467-551-7|pages=68–69| url={{google books |plainurl=y |id=yF1WxzySuEgC|page=68}}}}</ref>
Paramilitary violence and terrorism there was principally targeted towards peasants, unionists, indigenous people, human rights workers, teachers and left-wing political activists or their supporters.<ref>{{cite book|title=Law in a Lawless Land: Diary of limpieza in Colombia|author=Michael Taussig|year=2004|publisher=New Press}}</ref><ref name="getting-away">{{cite journal|title=Getting Away with Murder: Social Cleansing in Colombia and the Role of the United States|author=Elizabeth F. Schwartz|work=The University of Miami Inter-American Law Review|volume= 27|issue= 2|date=Winter 1995–1996|pages=381–420}}</ref><ref>Lovisa Stannow (1996) [http://ir.lib.sfu.ca/bitstream/1892/8188/1/b17766254.pdf "Social cleansing" in Colombia], MA Thesis, Simon Fraser University</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=The Dispossessed: Chronicles of the desterrados of Colombia|author=Alfredo Molano|publisher=Haymarket|year=2005|page=113}}</ref><ref>''Immigration and Refugee Board of Canada'', "Colombia: Activities of a Colombian social cleansing group known as 'Jóvenes del Bien' and any state efforts to deal with it", 2 April 2004</ref>{{sfn|Brittain|Petras|2010|pp= 132–35}}<ref name="aviles-lowint-380">{{cite journal|title=Paramilitarism and Colombia's Low-Intensity Democracy|author=William Avilés|work=Journal of Latin American Studies|volume= 38|issue=2|date=May 2006|page=380}}</ref>

=== United States === {{see also|Domestic terrorism in the United States}}
====Reconstruction era==== The term "''white terrorism''" is used by scholars to label terrorism committed against [[African Americans]] during the [[Reconstruction era]].<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Schenk|first1=David H.|title=Freedmen with Firearms: White Terrorism and Black Disarmament During Reconstruction|journal=Gettysburg College Journal of the Civil War Era|volume=4|date=April 30, 2014|url=http://cupola.gettysburg.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1027&context=gcjcwe}}</ref><ref>Butchart, Ronald E. "Black hope, white power: emancipation, reconstruction and the legacy of unequal schooling in the US South, 1861–1880." Paedagogica historica 46.1-2 (2010): 33–50.</ref>
====Pre-2001==== According to [[George Michael (professor)|George Michael]], "right-wing terrorism and violence has a long history in America".{{sfn|Michael|2003|p=114}} Right-wing violent incidents began to outnumber [[Marxism|Marxist]] incidents in the United States during the 1980s and 1990s.<ref>International Foundation for Protection Officers. 2003. ''The Protection Officer Training Manual''. Butterworth-Heinemann. {{ISBN|0-750-67456-3}}.</ref>{{rp|29}} Michael observes the waning of [[left-wing terrorism]] accompanying the rise of right-wing terrorism, with a noticeable "convergence" of the goals of [[Islamism|militant Islam]] with those of the [[Far-right politics|extreme right]]. Islamic studies scholar Youssef M. Choueiri classified [[Islamic fundamentalism|Islamic fundamentalist]] movements involving revivalism, reformism, and radicalism as within the scope of "[[right-wing politics]]".<ref>Choueiri, Youssef M. 2010. ''Islamic Fundamentalism: The Story of Islamist Movements''. Continuum International Publishing Group. {{ISBN|0-826-49801-9}}.</ref>{{rp|9}}
During the 1980s, more than 75 right-wing extremists were prosecuted in the United States for acts of terrorism, carrying out six attacks.{{sfn|Smith|1994|pp=25–26}} In 1983, [[Gordon Kahl]], a [[Posse Comitatus (organization)|Posse Comitatus]] activist, killed two federal marshals and he was later killed by police. Also that year, the [[White nationalism|white nationalist]] [[revolutionary]] group [[The Order (white supremacist group)|The Order]] (also known as the Brüder Schweigen or the Silent Brotherhood) robbed banks and armored cars, as well as a [[sex shop]],<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.splcenter.org/intel/intelreport/article.jsp?aid=760 | title=Free the Order Rally | publisher=[[Southern Poverty Law Center]] |date= Spring 2007 | first= | last= | accessdate =2007-08-17}}</ref> bombed a theater and a [[synagogue]] and murdered radio talk show host [[Alan Berg]].<ref>{{cite news | url=https://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F4061FF63D5D0C748DDDA00894DD484D81&n | title=Death List Names Given to US Jury | publisher=New York Times |date=September 17, 1985 | first= | last= | accessdate = 2007-08-25}}</ref><ref>Morris Dees and Steve Fiffer. ''Hate on Trial: The Case Against America's Most Dangerous Neo-Nazi''. Villard Books, 1993. p. xiiv</ref>
The [[Oklahoma City bombing|April 19, 1995 attack]] on the Murrah federal building in Oklahoma by [[Timothy McVeigh]] and [[Terry Nichols]] killed 168 people and it was the deadliest act of domestic terrorism in the history of the United States.{{sfn|Michael|2003|p= 107}} McVeigh stated that it was committed in retaliation for the government's actions at [[Ruby Ridge]] and [[Waco siege|Waco]].<ref name="WacoRubyMcN">{{cite news|agency=Associated Press |title=McVeigh offers little remorse in letters |url=http://www.cjonline.com/stories/061001/new_mcveigh.shtml |date=June 10, 2001 |work=[[The Topeka Capital-Journal]] |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5wovjJCKV?url=http://cjonline.com/stories/061001/new_mcveigh.shtml |archivedate=February 27, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
[[Eric Rudolph]] executed a series of terrorist attacks between 1996 and 1998. He carried out the 1996 [[Centennial Olympic Park bombing]]—which claimed two lives and injured 111—aiming to cancel the games, claiming they promoted global socialism and to embarrass the U.S. government.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=4600480|title=Full Text of Eric Rudolph's Confession|publisher=}}</ref> Rudolph confessed to bombing an abortion clinic in Sandy Springs, an Atlanta suburb, on January 16, 1997, the Otherside Lounge, an Atlanta lesbian bar, on February 21, 1997, injuring five and an [[abortion clinic]] in Birmingham, Alabama on January 29, 1998, killing Birmingham police officer and part-time clinic security guard Robert Sanderson and critically injuring nurse Emily Lyons.

A report in ''[[The Washington Post]]'', published on November 25, 2018, showed violent right-wing-related incidents up, and left-wing-related incidents down. Total domestic terrorism incidents was down to 41 in 2001, from a high of 468 in 1970, but then went up to 65 in 2017. Of those 65 events in 2017, 36 were right-wing-related (with 11 fatalities), 10 were left-wing-related (with 6 fatalities), 7 were related to Islamist extremism (with 16 fatalities), and 12, including the [[2017 Las Vegas shooting]], were categorized as "Other/Unknown" (with 62 fatalities, including 58 from the Las Vegas incident). The report found that 2018 was a particularly deadly year, with 11 people dying in the [[Pittsburgh synagogue shooting]], 2 others in an incident in Kentucky, and two more in a [[2018 Tallahassee shooting|shooting in Tallasshee]]. All three incidents were right-wing related.<ref name=wapo112518>Lowery, Wesley; Kindy, Kimberly; and Ba Tran, Andrew (November 25, 2018) [https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/in-the-united-states-right-wing-violence-is-on-the-rise/2018/11/25/61f7f24a-deb4-11e8-85df-7a6b4d25cfbb_story.html "In the United States, right-wing violence is on the rise"] ''[[The Washington Post]]''</ref>
The ''Post'' reported that the upsurge in right-wing violence began during the [[Barack Obama administration]] and picked up steam under the presidency of [[Donald Trump]], whose remarks after the [[Unite the Right rally]] in [[Charlotteville, Virginia]] in 2017 that there were "some very fine people on both sides" is widely seen as giving confidence to the right that the administration looked favorably on their goals, providing them with "tacit support". A former FBI assistant director for counterintelligence, is quoted as saying that "[political leaders] from the White House down, used to serve as a check on conduct and speech that was abhorrent to most people. I see that eroding. ... The current political rhetoric is at least enabling, and certainly not discouraging, violence."<ref name=wapo112518 />
According to analysis by the newspaper of data from the [[Global Terrorism Database]], 92 of 263 domestic terrorism events – 35% – that occurred from 2010 to 2017 were right-wing related, while 38 (14%) were Islamist extremist-related, and 34 (13%) were left-wing related. Not only that, but a criminologist from [[John Jay College]] stated that right-wing attacks were statistically more likely to result in fatalities.<ref name=wapo112518 />
== Europe ==
===Denmark=== Neo-Nazis were suspected to have perpetrated the [[1992 Copenhagen bombing]], in which the office of a left-wing socialist party was attacked, killing one of its members.<ref>https://www.b.dk/nationalt/afdoed-nynazist-haevdes-at-staa-bag-brevbombe?utm_source=twitterfeed&utm_medium=twitter</ref>
=== France === In the town of [[Toulon]], a far-right extremist group called SOS-France existed. On 18 August 1986, four members were driving a car carrying explosives, apparently in an attempt to bomb the offices of [[SOS Racisme]]. However it exploded while they were still in it, killing all four of them.<ref>https://www.apnews.com/b94eda4f669fd78ae616120b07cf66e8</ref>
Neo-Nazi members of the [[French and European Nationalist Party]] were responsible for a pair of [[1988 Cannes and Nice attacks|anti-immigrant terror bombings]] in 1988. Sonacotra hostels in [[Cagnes-sur-Mer]] and Cannes were bombed, killing Romanian immigrant George Iordachescu and injuring 16 people, mostly Tunisians. In an attempt to [[False flag|frame Jewish extremists]] for the Cagnes-sur-Mer bombing, the terrorists left leaflets bearing [[Star of David|Stars of David]] and the name [[Masada]] at the scene, with the message "To destroy [[Israel]], Islam has chosen the sword. For this choice, Islam will perish."<ref>{{cite news|last1=Greenhouse|first1=Steven|title=Immigrant Hostel Bombed in France|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1988/12/20/world/immigrant-hostel-bombed-in-france.html|accessdate=20 October 2014|publisher=New York Times|date=20 December 1988}}</ref>
On 28 May 2008, members of the neo-Nazi Nomad 88 group fired with machine guns at people from their car in [[Saint-Michel-sur-Orge]].<ref>https://www.lemonde.fr/societe/article/2008/06/03/un-groupuscule-neonazi-a-l-origine-d-une-fusillade_1053066_3224.html</ref><ref>http://www.leparisien.fr/essonne/le-groupuscule-neonazi-decide-de-s-autodissoudre-04-06-2008-3298544168.php</ref>
In 2015, in the aftermath of the [[Charlie Hebdo shooting]], six mosques and a restaurant were attacked in acts deemed as right-wing terrorism by authorities.<ref name="Europol16"/> The acts included grenade throwing, shooting, and use of an [[improvised explosive device]].
=== Germany === {{See also|Far-right politics in Germany|Terrorism in Germany}}
In 1980, a [[Oktoberfest terror attack|right-wing terrorist attack in Munich, Germany]] killed the attacker and 12 other people, injuring 215. Fears of an ongoing campaign of major right-wing terrorist attacks did not materialize.{{sfn|Aubrey|2004|p=45}}
In addition to several bank robberies, the German [[National Socialist Underground]] was responsible for the [[Bosphorus serial murders]] (2000–2006), the [[2004 Cologne bombing]] and the murder of policewoman [[Michéle Kiesewetter]] in 2007. In November 2011, two members of the National Socialist Underground committed suicide after a bank robbery and a third member was arrested some days later.
Right-wing extremist offenses in Germany rose sharply in 2015 and 2016.<ref name="Bleiker">Carla Bleiker, [http://www.dw.com/en/sharp-rise-in-right-wing-crime-in-germany-just-the-tip-of-the-iceberg/a-19041652 Sharp rise in right-wing crime in Germany just 'the tip of the iceberg'], [[Deutsche Welle]] (February 11, 2016).</ref> Figures from the German government tallied 316 violent xenophobic offences in 2014 and 612 such offenses in 2015.<ref name="Bleiker"/>
In August 2014, a group of four Germans founded a [[Munich]]-based far-right terrorist group, the {{ill|Oldschool Society|de}}. The group, which held racist, antisemitic, and anti-Muslim views, eventually attracted 30 members.<ref name="APOldschoolsentence">Associated Press, [https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/mar/15/germany-far-right-terrorist-group-four-jailed Four jailed in Germany for forming far-right terrorist group] (March 15, 2017).</ref> They stockpiled weapons and explosives and plotted to attack a refugee shelter in [[Saxony]],<ref name="APOldschoolsentence"/> but the group's leaders were arrested in May 2015 before carrying out the attack.<ref>Kate Brady, [http://www.dw.com/en/oldschool-society-neo-nazis-go-on-trial-for-refugee-home-attacks/a-19217024 'Oldschool Society' neo-Nazis go on trial for refugee home attacks], [[Deutsche Welle]] (April 27, 2016).</ref> In March 2017 four of the group's leaders were sentenced to prison terms.<ref name="APOldschoolsentence"/> The perpetrator of the [[2016 Munich shooting]] also had far-right views.
=== Italy === In the 1970s and 1980s, Italy endured the [[Years of Lead (Italy)|Years of Lead]], a period characterized by frequent terrorist attacks: between 1969 and 1982, the nation suffered 8,800 terrorist attacks, in which a total of 351 people were killed and 768 were injured.<ref name="Hof">Tobias Hof, "The Success of Italian Anti-terrorism Policy" in ''An International History of Terrorism: Western and Non-Western Experiences'' (editors Jussi M. Hanhimäki & Bernhard Blumenau: Routledge, 2013), p. 100.</ref> The terrorist attacks have been both ascribed to the far-left and the far-right, yet a lot of terrorist attacks remain without a clear culprit and a lot of people have claimed the authorship of them is to be ascribed to rogue members of the Italian secret service. Even some of the terrorist attacks ascribed to a particular political group may be in reality the work of these rogue agents: this has been claimed, among many others, by [[Francesco Cossiga]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lastampa.it/2006/11/21/italia/politica/cossiga-le-spie-ve-le-racconto-io-pAUXKv2TCn4Yp824sScL1O/pagina.html |title=Cossiga: «Le spie? Ve le racconto io» - La Stampa |publisher=Lastampa.it |date=2006-11-21 |accessdate=2018-04-15}}</ref> who was the President of the Italian Republic during the years of lead, and by [[Giulio Andreotti]],<ref>{{cite web|author=Di Stefano Marroni |url=http://ricerca.repubblica.it/repubblica/archivio/repubblica/2000/08/03/andreotti-servizi-segreti-si-sentivano-alla-guerra.html |title=Andreotti: I servizi segreti si sentivano alla guerra santa - la Repubblica.it |language={{it icon}} |publisher=Ricerca.repubblica.it |date=2000-08-03 |accessdate=2018-04-15}}</ref> who, during the same period of time held the Prime Minister office more than once.
The [[Years of Lead]] are considered to have begun with the [[Piazza Fontana bombing]] in [[Milan]] in December 1969,<ref name="Hof"/> perpetrated by [[Ordine Nuovo]], a right-wing [[neofascist]] group.<ref name="McHugh">Richard McHugh, "Ordine Nuovo" in ''The SAGE Encyclopedia of Terrorism'', 2d ed. (editor Gus Martin: SAGE Publications, 2011), pp. 451-52.</ref> Sixteen people were killed, and 90 injured, in the bombing.<ref name="McHugh"/>
In July 1970, this same group carried out a bombing on a train going from Rome to Messina, killing six and wounding almost 100. The group also carried out the [[Piazza della Loggia bombing]] in 1974, killing eight antifascist activists.<ref name="McHugh"/> Perhaps the most infamous right-wing terrorist attack in post-war Italy is the [[August 1980 Bologna bombing]], in which neo-fascist [[Nuclei Armati Rivoluzionari]] ("Armed Revolutionary Nuclei"), an Ordine Nuovo offshoot, killed 85 people and injured 200 at the [[Bologna Centrale railway station|Bologna railroad station]].<ref name="McHugh"/><ref name="1988Convictions">[http://www.apnewsarchive.com/1988/Four-Convicted-Of-Mass-Murder-In-Italian-Bombing-That-Killed-85/id-370c14ae3f77e87d266b0257bf7d2f62 Four Convicted of Mass Murder in Italian Bombing that Killed 85], Associated Press (July 11, 1988).</ref> [[Valerio Fioravanti]], Francesca Mambro, and two others were convicted of mass murder in the attacks,<ref name="1988Convictions"/> although both have always denied any connection with them.<ref>Anna Cento Bull & Philip Cooke, ''Ending Terrorism in Italy'' (Routledge, 2013), pp. 141-42.</ref><ref>Anne Hanley, [https://www.independent.co.uk/news/the-accidental-terrorist-1259973.html The accidental terrorist], ''Independent'' (May 5, 1997).</ref>
In December 2011, a gunman targeted Senegalese peddlers in [[Florence]], killing two and injuring three others before killing himself.<ref name="LinksFarRight">{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-19366000 | publisher=BBC News | title=Viewpoint: Killer Breivik's links with far right | date=August 27, 2012}}</ref><ref name="Kington">{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/dec/23/ezra-pound-daughter-italian-fascist | location=London | work=The Guardian | first=Tom | last=Kington | title=Ezra Pound's daughter aims to stop Italian fascist group using father's name | date=December 23, 2011}}</ref> The perpetrator was a sympathizer of [[CasaPound]],<ref name="LinksFarRight"/><ref name="Kington"/> which is a neo-fascist party that Italian judges have recognized as not posing a threat to public or private safety.<ref>{{cite web|author=Altri articoli dalla categoria » |url=http://www.repubblica.it/politica/2016/02/01/news/casapound_polizia-132480295/ |title=La polizia "promuove" CasaPound: "La violenza? Colpa dei centri sociali" |publisher=Repubblica.it |date=2016-02-01 |accessdate=2018-04-15}}</ref>
=== Norway === On July 22, 2011, Norwegian right-wing extremist with Nazi<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dagbladet.no/2012/04/18/nyheter/terrorsaken/nazismen/breivik/21171974/|title=Close to Nazism|author=Leif Stang|newspaper=Dagbladet|date=18 April 2012|language=Norwegian}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://expo.se/2014/breivik-vill-deportera-illojala-judar_6336.html|title=Breivik vill deportera "illojala judar"|newspaper=Expo Idag|language=Swedish|date=10 January 2014|author=Daniel Vergara}}</ref> and fascist<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.vg.no/nyheter/innenriks/22-juli/artikkel.php?artid=10103118|title=Breivik seeks to start the fascist party|date=10 May 2013|newspaper=VG Nett|author=Eva-Therese Grøttum|author2=Marianne Vikås|language=Norwegian}}</ref> sympathies, [[Anders Behring Breivik]], carried out the [[2011 Norway attacks]], the largest mass killing of people in [[Norway]] by a single person during peacetime, excluding use of bombs. First he bombed several government buildings in [[Oslo]], killing eight people and injuring more than 30. After the bombings, he went to [[Utøya]] island in a fake police uniform and began firing on people attending a political youth camp for the [[Workers' Youth League (Norway)|Worker's Youth League]] (AUF), a left-wing political party, killing 68 and injuring more than 60.
===Poland=== {{See also|Far-right politics in Poland}} Despite the country being nearly ethnically and religiously homogenous, Polish far-right targets, via propaganda or physical violence, religious and ethnic minorities such as Jews, [[Romani people]], people with darker complexion or Middle Eastern appearance. In 1991, an [[Mława riot|anti-Romani pogrom broke out in Mława]]. During the [[UEFA Euro 2012]], Polish hooligans targeted random Russian football supporters. There have been reports of hate crimes targeting the [[Islam in Poland|Muslim minority in Poland]]. [[Far-right politics|Far-right]] and [[Right-wing populism|right-wing populist]] political parties and organizations fuel fear and hatred towards Islam and Muslims.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.vice.com/story/poland-populist-government-far-right-extremism|title=Poland's populist government let far-right extremism explode into mainstream|first=Tim|last=Hume|date=9 May 2017|publisher=|via=news.vice.com}}</ref> Hate crimes such as arson and physical violence have occurred in Poland (despite having a Muslim population of only 0.1%, that is 30,000 out of 38 million).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.opendemocracy.net/can-europe-make-it/kasia-narkowicz-konrad-pedziwiatr/why-are-polish-people-so-wrong-about-muslims-in|title=Why are Polish people so wrong about Muslims in their country?|date=13 January 2017|publisher=openDemocracy}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.islamophobiaeurope.com/reports/2015/en/EIR_2015_POLAND.pdf|title=European Islamophobia Report|date=2015|publisher=SETA}}</ref> In 2016, police arrested a man who they say tried to burn down a [[mosque]] in [[Gdansk]].<ref name="Europol16">{{cite web|title=EUROPEAN UNION TERRORISM SITUATION AND TREND REPORT (TE-SAT) 2016|url=https://www.europol.europa.eu/activities-services/main-reports/european-union-terrorism-situation-and-trend-report-te-sat-2016|year=2016|publisher=[[Europol]]|page=41}}</ref> The man belonged to the neo-nazi group called [[Blood & Honour]].
=== Russia === [[The Savior (paramilitary organization)|The Savior]] was a [[neo-Nazi]] militant [[nationalist]] organization which claimed credit for the August [[2006 Moscow market bombing]], which killed 13. Media reports indicate that the market, located near [[Cherkizovsky]], was targeted due to its high volume of [[Central Asia]]n and [[Caucasus|Caucasian]] clientele.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/8CE01B4F-F6C4-4769-9CF0-1CE5C47ADDF0.htm|title=Russian court jails market bombers|date=15 May 2008|publisher=Al Jazeera}}</ref><ref>Marcel Van Herpen ''Putinism: The Slow Rise of a Radical Right Regime in Russia'' 2013 "On August, 21, 2006, members of The Savior, a neo-Nazi group led by Nikolai Korolev, a former FSB officer, bombed the Cherkizovsky market in Moscow, the largest market of Russia, frequented by many merchants from Central Asia."</ref> Four members of The Saviour were sentenced to life imprisonment, while four others received lesser prison terms.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.russiatoday.ru/news/news/24782|title=Racist bombers sentenced to life for market blast|publisher=Russia Today}}</ref>
On 22 April 2017, A gunman 'with hatred for ethnic minorities' shot and killed two people in an attack in a Federal Security Service office in the Russian city of Khabarovsk. The gunman was also killed. The Russian Federal Security Service says the native 18-year-old perpetrator was a known member of a neo-nazi group.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://siberiantimes.com/other/others/news/murderous-attack-on-fsb-office-in-khabarovsk-was-by-a-neo-nazi-not-an-is-terrorist/|title=Murderous attack on FSB office in Khabarovsk 'was by a neo-Nazi - not an IS terrorist'|website=siberiantimes.com|language=en|access-date=2018-03-10}}</ref>
=== Sweden === Both the [[2009–10 Malmö shootings]] and the [[Trollhättan school attack]] were conducted by right-wing terrorists along with a refugee centre bombing in 2017. A notable serial killer motivated by far-right motives is [[John Ausonius]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/donald-trump-terror-attack-claim-sweden-neo-nazis-refugee-centre-florida-rally-a7588516.html|title=Donald Trump is right, there was a recent attack in Sweden. By neo-Nazis on a refugee centre|date=19 February 2017|publisher=}}</ref> Far-rightists were also responsible for attacking an anti-racist demonstration [[December 2013 Stockholm riots|in Stockholm in December 2013]].
=== United Kingdom === In April 1999, David Copeland, a neo-Nazi, planted a [[1999 London nail bombings|series of nail bombs]] over 13 days. His attacks, which were aimed at London's [[Black people|black]], [[British Bangladeshi|Bangladeshi]] and [[Homosexual|gay]] communities, resulted in three dead and more than 100 injured.<ref name=Buncombe>Buncombe, Andrew; Judd, Terri; and Bennett, Jason. [https://web.archive.org/web/20091201133942/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/this-britain/hatefilled-nailbomber-is-jailed-for-life-706785.html "'Hate-filled' nailbomber is jailed for life"], ''The Independent'', 30 June 2000.</ref> Copeland was a former member of two far right political groups, the [[British National Party]] (BNP) and the [[National Socialist Movement (United Kingdom)|National Socialist Movement]]. Copeland told police, "My aim was political. It was to cause a racial war in this country. There'd be a backlash from the ethnic minorities, then all the white people will go out and vote BNP."<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/hi/english/static/audio_video/programmes/panorama/transcripts/transcript_30_06_00.txt "The Nailbomber"], BBC Panorama, 30 June 2000.</ref>
In July 2007, Robert Cottage, a former BNP member, was convicted for possessing explosive chemicals in his home – described by police at the time of his arrest as the largest amount of chemical explosive of its type ever found in that country.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newstatesman.com/2009/07/mehdi-hasan-muslim-terrorism-white-british|title=Know your enemy|publisher=}}</ref> In June 2008, Martyn Gilleard, a British Nazi sympathizer, was jailed after police found nail bombs, bullets, swords, axes and knives in his flat.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/7471128.stm | work=BBC News | title=Man guilty over nail bombs plot | date=June 24, 2008}}</ref> Also in 2008, Nathan Worrell was found guilty of possession of material for terrorist purposes and racially aggravated harassment. He was described by anti-terror police as a "dangerous individual". The court heard that police found books and manuals containing "recipes" to make bombs and detonators using household items, such as weedkiller, at Worrell's flat.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2008/dec/13/uk-security-nazi-terrorist-jailed | location=London | work=The Guardian | title=Racist who had bomb kit jailed for campaign against couple | date=December 13, 2008}}</ref> In July 2009, Neil Lewington was planning on waging a terror campaign using weapons made from tennis balls and weedkiller against those he classified as "non British".<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/8124449.stm | work=BBC News | title=Man 'on cusp' of bombing campaign | date=June 29, 2009}}</ref>
In 2012, the British Home Affairs Committee warned of the threat of far right terrorism in the UK, claiming it had heard "persuasive evidence" about the potential danger and cited the growth of similar threats across Europe.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-16900108 | work=BBC News | title=Home Affairs Committee warns of far-right terror threat | date=February 6, 2012}}</ref>
Members of [[Combat 18]] (C18), a [[Neo-Nazism|neo-Nazi]] organisation based on the concept of "[[leaderless resistance]]", have been suspected in numerous deaths of immigrants, non-whites and other C18 members.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/programmes/panorama/1672100.stm | work=BBC News | title=Ex-Combat 18 man speaks out | date=25 November 2001}}</ref> Between 1998 and 2000, dozens of members were arrested.<ref>[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/htmlContent.jhtml?html=/archive/1999/03/07/narm07.html "MI5 swoops on Army 'neo-Nazis'"], ''Sunday Telegraph'', 7 March 1999</ref><ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/hi/english/static/in_depth/programmes/2001/bnp_special/membership/organisers/adrian_marsden.stm BNP Under the skin: Profile of Adrian Marsden], ''BBC News''</ref> A group calling itself the [[Racial Volunteer Force]] split from C18 in 2002, retaining close links to its parent organization.<ref>[http://www.meta-religion.com/Extremism/White_extremism/Combat_18/combat_18.htm "Combat 18"] at www.metareligion.com</ref> Some journalists believed that the [[White Wolves]] were a C18 splinter group, alleging that the group had been set up by [[Del O'Connor]], the former second-in-command of C18 and member of [[Skrewdriver]] Security.<ref>Stuart Millar, [https://www.theguardian.com/bombs/Story/0,2763,204778,00.html "Anti-terror police seek White Wolf racist over bombs"]</ref> C18 attacks on immigrants continued through 2009.<ref>[http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/local-national/belfast-racists--threaten-to-cut-romanian-babys-throat-14341494.html "Belfast racists threaten to cut Romanian baby's throat"], ''Belfast Telegraph'', 17 June 2009</ref> Weapons, ammunition and explosives were seized by police in the UK and almost every country in which C18 was active.
In 2016, [[Jo Cox]], the [[Member of parliament|Member of Parliament]] (MP) for the [[Batley and Spen (UK Parliament constituency)|Batley and Spen]] constituency [[Murder of Jo Cox|was murdered]] by Thomas Mair, who was motivated by far-right political views and had connections to several far-right organisations in the UK, US, and South Africa.<ref>Ian Cobain and Matthew Taylor, [https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2016/nov/23/thomas-mair-found-guilty-of-jo-cox-murder Far-right terrorist Thomas Mair jailed for life for Jo Cox murder], ''Guardian'' (November 23, 2017).</ref>
On 16 December 2016 [[Home Secretary]] [[Amber Rudd]] designated the far-right, neo-Nazi [[National Action (UK)|National Action]] group as a terrorist organisation which criminalises membership or support for the organisation.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/dec/12/neo-nazi-group-national-action-banned-by-uk-home-secretary|title=Neo-Nazi group National Action banned by UK home secretary|first=Jessica|last=Elgot|date=12 December 2016|publisher=|via=The Guardian}}</ref> On 12 June 2018, [[Jack Renshaw (far-right activist)|Jack Renshaw]], 23, a former spokesperson for [[National Action (UK)|National Action]], admitted in a guilty plea to buying a 48 cm (19 in) replica [[Ancient Rome|Roman]][[Gladius]] sword (often wrongly referred to in the media as a [[machete]]) to murder Rosie Cooper, the [[Member of parliament|Member of Parliament]] (MP) for the [[West Lancashire (UK Parliament constituency)|West Lancashire]] constituency.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2018/jun/12/man-pleads-guilty-to-plot-to-labour-mp-rosie-cooper|title=Alleged neo-Nazi admits plotting murder of MP Rosie Cooper|last=Khomami|first=Nadia|date=2018-06-12|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-10-04}}</ref>
In March 2018 [[Mark Rowley]], the outgoing head of UK counter-terror policing, revealed that four far-right terror plots had been foiled since the Westminster attack in March 2017.<ref>{{url="https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/crime/terror-attacks-uk-threat-far-right-national-action-isis-nazis-westminster-finsbury-park-a8229876.html|date=26 February 2|title=Four far-right UK terrorist plots foiled since Westminster attack, police reveal}}</ref>

== Oceania == === Australia === In August 2016 Phillip Galea was charged with several terrorist offences. Galea had conducted "surveillance" of "left-wing premises" and planned to carry out bombings. Explosive ingredients were found at his home. Galea had links with organisations such as [[Combat 18]] and the [[United Patriots Front]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2016/oct/31/victorian-extremist-phillip-galea-planned-to-bomb-leftwing-premises-police-say|title=Victorian extremist Phillip Galea planned to bomb leftwing premises, police say|first=Australian Associated|last=Press|date=31 October 2016|publisher=|via=The Guardian}}</ref> In 2017 the ''[[Sydney Morning Herald]]'' reported on the conviction of neo-Nazi Michael James Holt, 26 who had threatened to carry out a mass shooting attack and considered [[Westfield Tuggerah]] as a target. He had manufactured home-made guns, knuckle dusters and slingshots in his grandfather's garage. Raids on his mother's home and a hotel room discovered more weapons including several firearms, slingshots and knuckle dusters.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.smh.com.au/nsw/white-supremacist-threatened-to-shoot-up-sydney-shopping-centre-20170120-gtvod0.html|title=White supremacist threatened to shoot up Central Coast shopping centre|first=Rachel|last=Olding|date=28 January 2017|publisher=|via=The Sydney Morning Herald}}</ref>

revision.text:
{{Politics of Switzerland}} The '''right of foreigners to vote in Switzerland''' is an ongoing political issue in the country. [[Switzerland]] is a [[Federalism|federal nation]]. As such, the [[Cantons of Switzerland|cantons]] have extensive powers to enact their own legislation (similar to the arrangement in the [[List of states and territories of the United States|states of the United States]]). For this reason, the rules regarding the [[Right of foreigners to vote|rights of foreign residents to vote]] differ considerably throughout Switzerland.
At federal level, exercising one's political rights in the strictest sense (the right to stand for election and to vote in [[Popular initiative (Switzerland)|popular initiatives]] and [[referendum]]s) is limited to Swiss citizens aged 18 or over, as prescribed by Articles 136, 143 and 150 of the [[Swiss Federal Constitution]]. A bill proposing granting foreign residents the right to vote in federal elections was submitted to the [[Swiss Federal Council|Federal Council]] on 4 October 2000 but was rejected on 4 October 2011.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.parlament.ch/f/suche/pages/geschaefte.aspx?gesch_id=20003512|title=Geschäft Ansehen|website=www.parlament.ch|access-date=2016-03-02}}</ref>
Under Article 36(1) of the Federal Constitution, the cantons have the power to grant political rights in cantonal and municipal elections which go beyond the minimum federal threshold (such as lowering the [[voting age]] and extending the right to vote to foreign nationals). The cantons also have the option to delegate these powers to the [[Municipalities of Switzerland|communes]]. Therefore, in theory, foreigners can be elected to the [[Council of States (Switzerland)|Council of States]], as Article 150(3) of the Constitution states: "The Cantons determine the rules for the election of their representatives to the Council of States."<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.admin.ch/opc/en/classified-compilation/19995395/201506140000/101.pdf|title=English version of the Swiss Federal Constitution|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=2 March 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.afpr.ch/pdf/afpr3635a.pdf|title=Problèmes d'intégration des ressortissants étrangers en Suisse|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=Office fédéral des migrations sur mandat du chef du Département fédéral de justice et police|access-date=2 March 2016}}</ref>
Only the cantons of [[Canton of Jura|Jura]] and [[Canton of Neuchâtel|Neuchâtel]] grant foreigners the right to vote in cantonal elections, but neither allow foreigners to stand for election at cantonal level.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.avenir-suisse.ch/wp-content/uploads/2015/09/2015-09_as_eligibilite-des-etrangers_hp.pdf|title=Pour la participation des étrangers au niveau local. L’extension du droit d’éligibilité dans les communes suisses|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=2 March 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303234616/http://www.avenir-suisse.ch/wp-content/uploads/2015/09/2015-09_as_eligibilite-des-etrangers_hp.pdf |archivedate=3 March 2016|df=}}</ref> At municipal level, 600 communes across six cantons ([[Appenzell Ausserrhoden]], [[Canton of Fribourg|Fribourg]], [[Graubünden]], Jura, Neuchâtel and [[Vaud]]) grant foreigners the right to stand for election.<ref name=":0" />
== Aargau == In 1996, a referendum was held to decide whether to grant to foreigners the right to vote and stand for election in the [[Aargau|Canton of Aargau]]. The proposal was rejected by voters.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.federalism.ch/files/Newsletter/742_12/JU-NE-etrangers-f.pdf|title=Jura et Neuchâtel : L’extension du droit d’éligibilité des étrangers se poursuit|last=Gassmann|first=Jean-Luc|date=June 2007|website=|publisher=University of Fribourg|access-date=4 March 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120210103657/http://www.federalism.ch/files/Newsletter/742_12/JU-NE-etrangers-f.pdf|archivedate=10 February 2012|df=}}</ref>
== Appenzell Ausserrhoden == Article 105(2) of the [[Appenzell Ausserrhoden]] Cantonal Constitution of 30 April 1995 gives the communes of this canton the freedom to grant (or not) political rights to foreigners, provided that such foreigners have been resident in Switzerland for at least ten years and have lived in the canton for at least five years.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.admin.ch/ch/d/sr/131_224_1/a105.html|title=SR 131.224.1 Verfassung des Kantons Appenzell A. Rh., vom 30. April 1995|last=P|first=Bundeskanzlei -|website=www.admin.ch|access-date=2016-03-04}}</ref> Three of the twenty communes have granted foreigners voting rights: [[Wald, Appenzell Ausserrhoden|Wald]] (1999), [[Speicher, Switzerland|Speicher]] (2002) and [[Trogen]] (2004).<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=http://www.strabon.ch/elections/voteetrangers.htm|title=Droit de vote des étrangers|website=www.strabon.ch|access-date=2016-03-04}}</ref> In Speicher, Switzerland’s first foreigner was elected to political office – a [[Netherlands|Dutchman]] who has since naturalised as a Swiss citizen.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.swissinfo.org/fre/a_la_une/detail/Un_ressortissant_etranger_parmi_les_elus.html|title=Un ressortissant étranger parmi les élus|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=4 March 2016}}{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
== Basel-Stadt == The [[Basel-Stadt|Canton of Basel-Stadt]] has a large foreign population – 50,000 people, who make up 30% of the total population. In 2005, the canton inserted a clause into its constitution (which entered into force on 13 November 2006) giving each of its three communes ([[Basel]], [[Bettingen]] and [[Riehen]]) the power to extend the right to vote and stand for election at municipal level to “residents other than those who hold Swiss nationality who are at least 18 years of age”.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.admin.ch/ch/f/rs/131_222_1/a40.html|title=RS 131.222.1 Constitution du canton de Bâle-Ville, du 23 mars 2005|last=P|first=Bundeskanzlei -|website=www.admin.ch|access-date=2016-03-04}}</ref> In reality, only the two autonomous communes (Bettingen and Riehen) have this power, as Basel is administered directly by the canton.<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=http://www.ge.ch/constituante/doc/presse/CoT2_Rapport_complet_DPE_251109.pdf|title=Les droits politiques des étrangers Rapport préliminaire no 1|last=|first=|date=25 November 2009|website=|publisher=Assemblée constituante de la République et Canton de Genève|access-date=4 March 2016}}</ref>
== Bern == In April 2005, the Grand Council (parliament) of the [[Canton of Bern]] refused by 98 votes to 86 a bill from the cantonal government to grant the communes the freedom to grant (or not) foreigners the right to vote at municipal level. Had this bill been approved, it would have allowed foreigners the right to vote provided that they had lived in Switzerland for at least ten years, in the canton for at least five years and in the same commune for at least three months.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.minorites.org/article.php?IDA=8525|title=Le Grand Conseil bernois refuse le droit de vote aux étrangers|last=|first=|date=18 April 2005|website=Swissinfo|publisher=|access-date=4 March 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050501015758/http://www.minorites.org/article.php?IDA=8525|archivedate=1 May 2005|df=}}</ref>
A similar bill, brought by the Bern [[Social Democratic Party of Switzerland|Social Democratic Party]] and the Independent Socialist Party, was rejected on 25 January 2007 by 77 votes to 73, although it was again supported by the cantonal government. Opponents to the bill primarily came from the bourgeois bloc, the [[Swiss People's Party|Swiss People’s Party]] and the [[Free Democratic Party of Switzerland|Free (or “Radical”) Democratic Party]], although the latter had been in favour of the 2005 bill.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.swissinfo.org/fre/recherche/detail/A_Berne_les_etrangers_resteront_muets.html|title=A Berne, les étrangers resteront muets|last=|first=|date=23 January 2007|website=Swissinfo|publisher=|access-date=4 March 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=http://archive.wikiwix.com/cache/20110224113254/http://www.swissinfo.org/fre/recherche/detail/A_Berne_les_etrangers_resteront_muets.html |archivedate=24 February 2011|df=}}</ref>
In August 2008, a popular initiative supported by the socialists, the [[Green Party of Switzerland|Green Party]] and the [[Swiss Federation of Trade Unions]] gained enough signatures (12,500) to amend the Bern Cantonal Constitution to allow each commune to decide whether to grant voting rights to foreign residents.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.rfj.ch/rjb/Actualite/Regionale/11808Initiative-pour-le-droit-de-vote-des-etrangers-dans-le-canton-de-Berne-.html|title=Initiative pour le droit de votes des étrangers dans le canton de Berne|last=|first=|date=11 August 2008|website=Radio Jura bernois|publisher=|access-date=4 March 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=http://archive.wikiwix.com/cache/20110224055259/http://www.rfj.ch/rjb/Actualite/Regionale/11808Initiative-pour-le-droit-de-vote-des-etrangers-dans-le-canton-de-Berne-.html |archivedate=24 February 2011|df=}}</ref> The subsequent referendum was rejected by voters on 26 September 2010.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.lematin.ch/actu/suisse/berne-bale-ville-refusent-droit-vote-etrangers-327789|title=Le Matin, l'actualité en direct: sports, people, politique, économie, multimédia|website=www.lematin.ch|access-date=2016-03-04}}</ref>
== Fribourg == The new constitution of the [[Canton of Fribourg]], adopted on 16 May 2004, states in Article 48: “The following have the right to vote and stand for election at municipal level, providing that they are of voting age: […] foreigners and foreigners resident in their respective commune who have been resident in the canton for at least five years and who have a residence permit.”
The Law of 16 March 2005 granting political rights to foreigners and to Swiss citizens living abroad amended the Law on the exercising of political rights, bringing the latter into conformity with the new constitution. This law also states: “any person who enjoys political rights at municipal level may stand for election.”
== Geneva == On 24 April 2005, 52.3% of voters in the [[Canton of Geneva]] approved an initiative granting voting rights at municipal level to foreigners who have lived in the canton for at least eight years. Another initiative granting foreigners the right to stand for election gained only 47.2% support. Geneva became the sixth canton in Switzerland to grant political rights to foreign residents.
This vote came after four unsuccessful earlier attempts. On 17 June 1979, 56.3% of voters rejected an initiative to grant foreigners the right to vote and stand for election at industrial-tribunal elections. On 6 June 1993, 71.3% of voters refused an initiative granting foreigners the right to vote and stand for election at municipal level. On 28 November 1993, the same percentage of voters refused a second initiative granting foreigners only the right to vote. On 4 March 2001, 52% of voters refused an initiative to create a constitutional law granting foreigners the right to vote and stand for election at municipal level.
Article 42 of the Cantonal Constitution was amended to allow foreign residents the right to vote at municipal elections provided that they have been legally resident in Switzerland for at least eight years. However, foreign residents do not have the right to stand for election.
The constitutional provision relating to foreigners’ voting rights is directly enforceable and applicable. However, a bill amending the Law on the exercising of political rights was approved on 14 September 2005 to bring legislation in line with the constitution.
== Glarus == At a [[Landsgemeinde]] on 2 May 2010, the voters of the [[Canton of Glarus]] rejected a proposal to grant foreigners the right to vote.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.tdg.ch/actu/suisse/glaris-refuse-droit-vote-etrangers-2010-05-02|title=Glarus refuse le droit de vote aux étrangers|last=|first=|date=2 May 2010|website=Agence télégraphique suisse|publisher=|access-date=4 March 2016}}</ref>
== Graubünden == Article 9 of the Constitution of the [[Graubünden|Canton of Graubünden]] of 14 September 2003 enshrines Swiss citizens’ right to vote at cantonal level, but does not exclude this right being extended to foreigners, as it is up to the legislator to determine the details. No actual law was adopted to grant voting rights to foreigners.
Article 9 also states that the communes have the discretion to decide (or not) to grant foreigners both the right to vote and the right to stand for election. Ten of the canton’s 208 communes have made use of this power: [[Bever, Switzerland|Bever]], [[Bonaduz]], [[Calfreisen|Calfreise]], [[Cazis]], [[Conters im Prättigau]], [[Fideris]], [[Lüen]], [[Masein]], [[Portein]] (which merged into the commune of Cazis on 1 January 2010) and [[Schnaus]].<ref name=":3" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.auslaenderstimmrecht.ch/jyvis-jyvote/deja-une-realite.php|title=Cantons et communes en Suisse accordant le droit actif de vote aux étrangers|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=4 March 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080412210827/http://www.auslaenderstimmrecht.ch/jyvis-jyvote/deja-une-realite.php|archivedate=12 April 2008|df=}}</ref>
== Jura == When the [[Canton of Jura]] was formed in 1978, it immediately granted foreigners the right to vote.
The Cantonal Constitution grants voting rights to citizens “holding Swiss nationality” and states in Article 73: “the law defines and regulates the right to vote and other political rights of foreigners.”
Article 3 of the Law of 26 October 1978 on political rights states that foreigners may vote in municipal elections provided that they have been resident in the canton for at least ten years and in their respective commune for at least 30 days. It states that foreigners enjoying the right to vote can also stand for election at municipal level.
This law also grants foreigners the right to vote at cantonal elections, under the sole condition that they have been resident in the canton for at least ten years.
On 21 February 2007, the cantonal parliament passed a law (by 51 votes to 4) granting foreigners the right to stand for election as mayor. All such candidates must have lived regularly in Switzerland for at least ten years, including at least one year in the Canton of Jura.
On 17 June 2007, the voters of Jura voted against a law allowing foreigners to stand for election, therefore revoking the earlier law.
On 28 September 2014, the cantonal government approved (by 54% of votes) a proposal re-granting foreigners the right to stand for election to all municipal offices except that of mayor.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.rts.ch/info/regions/jura/6179408-les-etrangers-pourront-etre-elus-au-plan-communal-dans-le-jura.html|title=Les étrangers pourront être élus au plan communal dans le Jura|website=rts.ch|access-date=2016-03-04}}</ref>
== Lucerne == Article 15(2) of the draft of the new constitution of the [[Canton of Lucerne]] allowed communes the discretion to grant (or not) foreigners the right to vote in municipal elections. However, this clause did not appear in the version of the constitution that was approved by popular vote on 17 June 2007.<ref name=":1" />
== Neuchâtel == The [[Canton of Neuchâtel]] has allowed foreigners to vote in municipal elections since 1849. It briefly abolished this right but then reinstated it in 1875.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Christ|first=Thierry|date=June 2002|title=" Il est juste que ceux qui paient puisse voir ce qu'on fait de leur argent ": Le droit de vote des étrangers dans les débats politiques neuchâtelois de la seconde moitié du XIXe siècle|journal=Revue Historique Neuchâteloise|doi=|pmid=}}</ref>
The Law of 17 October 1984 on political rights allows foreigners to vote in municipal elections provided that they are “in a regular situation” and have been resident in the canton for at least a year. Foreigners are also allowed to stand for election.
An amendment to the Cantonal Constitution in 2000 granted foreigners the right to vote in cantonal elections provided that they have been resident in the canton for at least five years.
In 1850, Neuchâtel granted foreign residents the right to vote, but not to stand for election, in municipal elections. During the [[19th century]], not even Swiss citizens were automatically guaranteed the right to stand for election if they originated from a different canton.
In June 2007, voters rejected a cantonal initiative that proposed granting foreigners the right to stand for election.
2016 saw the rules changed for both municipal and cantonal elections. At municipal level, foreigners and stateless persons who have been resident in a commune of the canton, have a residence permit (“Permis C”) and have been resident in the canton for at least one year are now allowed to stand for election. They may now also stand for election at cantonal level under the same requirements except they must have been resident in the canton for at least five years.
== Schaffhausen == In 2001, the voters of the [[Canton of Schaffhausen]] rejected a popular initiative proposing granting foreigners the right to vote.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Stimm- und Wahlrecht für Ausländerinnen und Ausländer|last=Heusser|first=Pierre|publisher=Schulthess Juristische Medien|year=2001|isbn=9783725542567|location=Zurich|pages=}}</ref>
On 28 September 2014, voters again rejected (by 85% of the vote) a proposal allowing foreigners to vote.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.swissinfo.ch/fre/le-projet-de-fusion-entre-les-deux-b%25C3%25A2le-a-une-nouvelle-fois-%25C3%25A9chou%25C3%25A9/40804708|title=Le projet de fusion entre les deux Bâle a une nouvelle fois échoué - SWI swissinfo.ch|website=SWI swissinfo.ch|access-date=2016-03-04}}</ref>
== Solothurn == In 1997, the voters of the [[Canton of Solothurn]] rejected (by 88.5% of the vote) a proposal allowing foreigners to vote.<ref name=":2" />
== Thurgau == Article 19 of the Constitution of the [[Thurgau|Canton of Thurgau]] and Article 2(1) of the Law on political rights allows the communes to grant (or not) foreigners the right to vote at municipal level. As of 2009, only two communes – [[Langrickenbach]] and [[Lengwil]] – had taken up this option.<ref name=":3" />
== Uri == The voters of the [[Canton of Uri]] rejected a popular initiative (by 84% of votes) proposing allowing foreigners complete political rights at both municipal and cantonal level.
== Vaud == Article 142 of the new Constitution of the [[Vaud|Canton of Vaud]], of 14 April 2003, specifies: “the following make up the electorate: […] foreigners who have been resident in commune anywhere in Switzerland and held a residence permit for at least ten years and have also been resident in the canton for at least three years.” In order to transpose the constitutional provision, the Law on the exercising of political rights was amended in 2003 to grant foreigners the right to vote. As the right to vote and the right to stand for election are indivisible rights in the law of Vaud, foreigners are also allowed to stand for election at municipal level. Only Swiss citizens have the right to vote and stand for election at cantonal level.
== Zug == An amendment providing for the possibility for the communes of the [[Canton of Zug]] to grant foreigners the right to vote at municipal elections was presented in September 2006 during debates surrounding the amendment of the Law on political rights. However, this provision was not retained in the final version of the amended law.<ref name=":1" />
== Zurich == In 1993, the voters of the [[Canton of Zürich|Canton of Zurich]] voted against a popular initiative (by 74.5% of votes) proposing granting foreigners political rights in the canton.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.geneve.ch/grandconseil/memorial/data/540310/44/540310_44_partie3.asp|title=Session 540310 - Séance 44 - PL - 7913-A|website=www.geneve.ch|access-date=2016-03-04|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160308034302/http://www.geneve.ch/grandconseil/memorial/data/540310/44/540310_44_partie3.asp |archivedate=2016-03-08|df=}}</ref> An individual initiative launched by a citizen (“Einzelinitiative”) which proposed introducing voting rights for foreigners in municipal elections was rejected in February 2007.<ref name=":1" />
