revision.text:
[[File:Ronald Reagan TV Address 1981.ogv|thumb|thumbtime=4|right|alt=President Reagan and his line chart titled "Your taxes" which shows rising taxes.|[[Ronald Reagan]] gives a televised address from the [[Oval Office]], outlining his plan for tax reductions in July 1981 (excerpt)]] This '''timeline of modern American conservatism''' lists important events, developments, and occurrences which have significantly affected [[conservatism in the United States]]. With the decline of the conservative wing of the Democratic Party after 1960, the movement is most closely associated with the [[History of the Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]] (GOP). [[Fiscal conservatism|Economic conservatives]] favor less government regulation, lower taxes, and weaker labor unions, while [[Social conservatism in the United States|social conservatives]] focus on moral issues and neoconservatives focus on democracy worldwide. Conservatives generally distrust the United Nations (UN) and Europe and, apart from the [[Libertarian Republican|libertarian wing]], favor a strong military and give enthusiastic support to Israel.<ref>Michael T. Thomas (2007). ''American policy toward Israel: the power and limits of beliefs.'' Routledge. pp. 42–43.</ref>
Although conservatism has much older roots in American history, the modern movement began to gel in the mid–1930s when intellectuals and politicians collaborated with businessmen to oppose the liberalism of the [[New Deal]], led by President [[Franklin D. Roosevelt]] (FDR), newly energized [[Labor unions in the United States|labor unions]], and big city Democratic machines. After World War II that coalition gained strength from new philosophers and writers who developed an intellectual rationale for conservatism.<ref>Patrick Allitt (2009). ''The Conservatives: Ideas and Personalities Throughout American History.'' Yale University Press. ch 1–6 covers the story down to 1945.</ref>
Richard Nixon's victory in the 1968 presidential election is often considered a realigning election in American politics. From 1932 to 1968, the Democratic Party was obviously the majority party. During that time period, the Democrats had won seven out of nine presidential elections, and their agenda gravely affected that undertaken by the Republican Eisenhower administration. The election of 1968 reversed the situation completely. The Vietnam war split the Democratic Party. White ethnics in the North and white Southerners felt the national Democratic Party had deserted them. The white South has voted Republican at the presidential level since the mid-1960s, and at the state and local level since the 1990s.
In the 1980s President [[Ronald Reagan]] solidified conservative Republican strength with [[tax cuts]], greatly increased [[Military budget of the United States|defense spending]], [[deregulation]], a policy of [[Reagan Doctrine|rolling back communism]] (rather than just containing it), a greatly strengthened military, and appeals to [[family values]] and conservative Judeo-Christian morality. His impact has led historians to call the 1980s the "[[Reagan Era]]".<ref>Sean Wilentz ''The Age of Reagan: A History, 1974–2008.'' (2009); John Ehrman ''The Eighties: America in the Age of Reagan.'' (2008) pp. 3–8.</ref> The Reagan model remains the conservative standard for social, economic and foreign policy issues. In recent years social issues such as abortion, gun control, and [[Same-sex marriage|gay marriage]] have become important. Since 2009 the [[Tea Party Movement]] has energized conservatives at the local level against the policies made by the [[presidency of Barack Obama]], leading to a Republican landslide in 2010 and again in 2014, eventually culminating in the [[United States presidential election, 2016|election of Republican Donald Trump as president in 2016]].
==Chronology of events== {{main|Conservatism in the United States|History of the United States Republican Party}}
===1930s=== As the nation plunges into its [[Great Depression in the United States|deepest depression ever]], Republicans and conservatives fall into disfavor in 1930, 1932, and 1934, losing more and more of their seats. Liberals (mostly Democrats with a few Republicans and independents) come to power with the [[United States presidential election, 1932|landslide 1932 election]] of liberal Democrat Franklin D. Roosevelt. In his first 100 days Roosevelt pushes through a series of dramatic economic programs known as the [[New Deal]].<ref>Anthony J. Badger (2009). ''FDR: the first hundred days''. Hilland Wang. pp. 3–22, 74.</ref>
The major metropolitan newspapers generally opposed the New Deal, as typified by [[William Randolph Hearst]] and his chain (Hearst had supported FDR in 1932 but parted ways in 1934.)<ref>{{cite book|author=Graham J. White|title=FDR and the Press|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Q2_HXgc4u_4C&pg=PA51|year=1979|publisher=University of Chicago Press|pages=51–52|isbn=978-0226895123}}</ref> [[Robert R. McCormick]], owner of the ''[[Chicago Tribune]]'', compared the New Deal to communism. He was also an [[America First Committee|America First]] [[isolationist]] who strongly opposed entering World War II to rescue the [[British Empire]]. McCormick also railed against the [[League of Nations]], the [[World Court]], socialism and communism.<ref>{{cite book|author=Richard Norton Smith|title=The Colonel: The Life and Legend of Robert R. McCormick, 1880–1955|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0tIW6XTGsOAC&pg=PA349|year= 2003|publisher=Northwestern University Press|page=349|isbn=978-0810120396}}</ref>
;1934 * Opposition to New Deal policies first takes shape as the [[American Liberty League]]. Led by conservative Democrats such as [[Al Smith]], it fades after [[United States presidential election, 1936|Roosevelt's 1936 landslide]] and disbands in 1940.<ref>{{cite journal | author = Rudolph Frederick | year = 1950 | title = The American Liberty League, 1934–1940 | journal = American Historical Review | volume = 56 | issue = 1| pages = 19–33 | jstor=1840619}}</ref><ref>George Wolfskill (1962). ''The Revolt of the Conservatives: A History of the American Liberty League, 1934–1940.'' Houghton Mifflin. p. 249.</ref> Businessmen begin organizing their opposition especially to labor unions.<ref>{{cite book|author=Kim Phillips-Fein|title=Invisible Hands: The Businessmen's Crusade Against the New Deal|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=g0tCwOhyl7MC&pg=PA15|year=2010|publisher=W. W. Norton|page=15|isbn=978-0393337662}}</ref> ;1935 * Former President [[Herbert Hoover]] develops his critique of New Deal liberalism based on the values of liberty, limited government, and constitutionalism.<ref>Gordon Lloyd and David Davenport, ''The New Deal and Modern American Conservatism: A Defining Rivalry'' (2013) [https://www.amazon.com/Deal-Modern-American-Conservatism-ebook/dp/B00EXC1EGA/ excerpt and text search]</ref> ;1936 [[File:Oliver twist.gif|210px|thumb|alt=Cartoon of a greedy FDR and diminutive Congress.|1937 cartoon by Joseph L. Parrish in the ''Chicago Tribunes'' warning FDR's executive branch reorganization plan is a power grab.]] * President Roosevelt calls his opponents "conservatives" as a term of abuse, they reply that they are "true liberals".<ref>{{cite book|author=Brendon O'Connor|title=A Political History of the American Welfare System: When Ideas Have Consequences|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=GOfdvp_GQ34C&pg=PA38|year=2004|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield|page=38|isbn=978-0742526686}}</ref> * Most publishers favor Republican moderate [[Alf Landon]] for president. In the nation's 15 largest cities the newspapers that editorially endorsed Landon represented 70% of the circulation, while Roosevelt won 69% of the actual voters.<ref>Charles W. Smith Jr. (1939). ''Public Opinion in a Democracy.'' Prentice-Hall. pp. 85–86.</ref> * FDR [[United States presidential election, 1936|carries 46 of the 48 states]] and liberals gain in both the [[United States House of Representatives elections, 1936|House]] and the [[United States Senate elections, 1936|Senate]], thanks to newly energized labor unions, city machines, and the WPA.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Sternsher | first1 = Bernard | year = 1984 | title = The New Deal Party System: A Reappraisal | journal = Journal of Interdisciplinary History | volume = 15 | issue = 1| pages = 53–81 | jstor=203594 | doi = 10.2307/203594}}</ref> Since 1928 the GOP has lost 178 House seats, 40 Senate seats, and 19 governorships; it retains a mere 89 seats in the House and 16 in the Senate.<ref>{{cite book|author=Michael Kazin, eta al, eds.|title=The Concise Princeton Encyclopedia of American Political History|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7hScNkRpePoC&pg=PA203|year=2011|publisher=Princeton University Press|page=203|isbn=978-0691152073}}</ref> ;1937 * Roosevelt's plan to [[Judicial Procedures Reform Bill of 1937|pack the Supreme Court]] alienates conservative Democrats; most newspapers which supported FDR in 1936 oppose the plan, with many warning it was a prelude to dictatorship.<ref>{{cite book|author=Jeff Shesol|title=Supreme Power: Franklin Roosevelt Vs. The Supreme Court|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PtBJOuXmGf8C&pg=PA299|year=2011|publisher=W. W. Norton|pages=299, 301–03|isbn=978-0393338812}}</ref> * Conservative Republicans (nearly all from the North) and conservative Democrats (most from the South), form the [[Conservative Coalition]] and block most new liberal proposals until the 1960s.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Patterson | first1 = James T. | year = 1966 | title = A Conservative Coalition Forms in Congress, 1933–1939 | journal = Journal of American History | volume = 52 | issue = 4| pages = 757–72 | jstor=1894345 | doi = 10.2307/1894345}}</ref> * The [[Conservative Manifesto]] (originally titled "An Address to the People of the United States") rallies the opposition to Roosevelt. It is drafted by Senators [[Josiah Bailey]] (D-NC) and [[Arthur H. Vandenberg]] (R-MI).<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = John Robert | first1 = Moore | year = 1965 | title = Senator Josiah W. Bailey and the "Conservative Manifesto" of 1937 | journal = Journal of Southern History | volume = 31 | issue = 1| pages = 21–39 | jstor=2205008 | doi = 10.2307/2205008}}</ref> * The liberal [[American Federation of Labor]] (AFL) and more leftist [[Congress of Industrial Organizations]] (CIO) labor federations are both growing and both support FDR. Their bitter feud over jurisdiction, however, produces numerous strikes, angers public opinion and weakens their political power.<ref>Walter Galenson (1960). ''The CIO challenge to the AFL.'' Harvard University Press. p. 542.</ref> ;1938 * Opponents of conservatism weaken sharply. FDR's allies in the AFL and CIO battle each other; his court-packing plan is rejected; his attempt to purge the conservatives from the Democratic Party fails and strengthens them; the sharp [[recession of 1937–1938]] discredits his argument that New Deal policies would lead to full recovery.<ref>William E. Leuchtenburg (1963). ''Franklin D. Roosevelt and the New Deal: 1932–1940.'' HarperCollins. pp. 231–74.</ref> * The Republicans make major gains in the [[United States House of Representatives elections, 1938|House]] and [[United States Senate elections, 1938|Senate]] in the 1938 elections.<ref>Milton Plesur, "The Republican Congressional Comeback of 1938," ''Review of Politics,'' Oct 1962, Vol. 24 Issue 4, pp. 525–62 [https://www.jstor.org/stable/1405361 in JSTOR]</ref> * [[Leo Strauss]] (1899–1973), a refugee from Nazi Germany, teaches political philosophy at the [[New School for Social Research]] in New York (1938–49) and the University of Chicago (1949–1958). He was not an activist but his ideas have been influential.<ref>John P. East, "Leo Strauss and American Conservatism," [http://www.mmisi.org/ma/21_01/east.pdf ''Modern Age,'' (1977) 21:1 pp. 2–19 online]</ref> ;1939 [[File:RobertATaft.jpg|thumb|140px|alt=photograph of|Robert A. Taft]] * As Republican senator from Ohio (1939–53), [[Robert A. Taft]] leads the conservative opposition to liberal policies (apart from public housing and aid to education, which he supported). Taft opposed most of the New Deal, entry into World War II, NATO, and sending troops to the [[Korean War]]. He was not so much an "isolationist" as a staunch opponent of the ever-expanding powers of the White House. The growth of this power, Taft feared, would lead to dictatorship or at least spoil American democracy, [[republicanism in the United States|republicanism]] and civil virtue.<ref>Geoffrey Matthews, "Robert A. Taft, the Constitution and American Foreign Policy, 1939–53," ''Journal of Contemporary History,'' July 1982, Vol. 17 Issue 3, pp. 507–22</ref>
===1940s=== ;1943 * Medical missionary [[Walter Judd (politician)|Walter Judd]] (1898–1994) enters Congress (1943–63) and defines the conservative position on China as all-out support for the Nationalists under [[Chiang Kai-shek]] and opposition to the Communists under Mao. Judd redoubled his support after the Nationalists in 1949 fled to Formosa (Taiwan).<ref>Lee Edwards (1990). ''Missionary for Freedom: The Life and Times of Walter Judd.'' Paragon House. p. 210.</ref> * The [[American Enterprise Institute for Public Policy Research|American Enterprise Institute]] (AEI) is founded in Washington "to defend the principles and improve the institutions of American freedom and democratic capitalism—limited government, private enterprise, individual liberty and responsibility, vigilant and effective defense and foreign policies, political accountability, and open debate."<ref>Murray L. Weidenbaum (2009). ''The competition of ideas: the world of the Washington think tanks.'' Transaction Publishers. p. 23.</ref> ;1944 [[File:80 us house changes.png|thumb|alt=map shows GOP landslide in 1946|Party change of House seats in the 1946 GOP landslide]] * March: [[Friedrich Hayek]], an Austrian-born British economist, publishes ''[[The Road to Serfdom]]'', which is widely read in America and Britain. He warns that well-intentioned government intervention in the economy is a slippery slope that will lead to tight government controls over people's lives, just as medieval serfdom had done.<ref>F. A. Hayek (1944; 2nd ed. 2010). ''The Road to Serfdom.'' University of Chicago Press. 2nd ed. by Bruce Caldwell with prepublication reports on Hayek's manuscript, and forewords to earlier editions by [[John Chamberlain (journalist)|John Chamberlain]], Milton Friedman, and Hayek himself.</ref> * The weekly magazine ''[[Human Events]]'' is founded by [[Frank Hanighen]] and [[Felix Morley]] with a significant contribution from ex-New Dealer [[Henry Regnery]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/23/us/henry-regnery-84-ground-breaking-conservative-publisher.html |title=Henry Regnery, 84, Ground-Breaking Conservative Publisher |author=Robert McG. Thomas, Jr. |date=June 23, 1996 |work=New York Times |publisher= |accessdate=April 23, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nationalreview.com/nrd/article/?q=ZTQ2MjE1MTYzYjQ3Mjk0MWU5MTE4YmQzMDkyMjE2NzM= |title=Turning the Tide |author=Richard V. Allen |date=June 2, 2008 |work=National Review Online |publisher= |accessdate=April 23, 2012}}</ref> Ronald Reagan later says that the magazine "helped me stop being a liberal Democrat."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.humanevents.com/article.php?id=41609 |title=Reagan's Newspaper |author=Lee Edwards |date=February 5, 2011 |work=Human Events |publisher= |accessdate=April 23, 2012}}</ref> ; 1945 * [[Ludwig von Mises]] (1881–1973), having fled the Nazis, becomes professor of economics at New York University (1945–1969) where he disseminates [[Austrian School]] libertarianism.<ref>Israel M. Kirzner (2001). ''Ludwig von Mises: the man and his economics.'' ISI Books. p. 25.</ref> ;1946 * [[Milton Friedman]] (1912–2006) is appointed professor of economics at the University of Chicago.<ref>He retired in 1977 and moved to the [[Hoover Institution]] at Stanford. Milton and Rose Friedman (1999). ''Two Lucky People: Memoirs.'' University of Chicago Press. p. 559.</ref> Previously a [[Keynesian]], Friedman moves right under the influence of his close friend [[George Stigler]] (1911–1991). He founds the market-oriented [[Chicago School of Economics]] which reshapes conservative economic theory. Stigler opposes regulation of industry as counterproductive; Friedman undermines Keynesian macroeconomics.<ref>[[Alan O. Ebenstein]] (2009). ''Milton Friedman: A Biography'' Palgrave Macmillan. p. 259.</ref> Friedman wins the Nobel Prize in 1976 and Stigler in 1982. * November 5: Republicans score landslide victories in the [[United States House of Representatives elections, 1946|House]] and [[United States Senate elections, 1946|Senate]] in off-year elections and set about enacting a conservative agenda in the [[80th Congress]].<ref>Susan M. Hartmann (1971). ''Truman and the 80th Congress.'' University of Missouri Press. p. 7.</ref> [[File:Is this tomorrow.jpg|thumb|140px|alt=Cartoon book warning of Communist aggression|Warning against communism, 1947]] ;1947 * June: Congress passes the [[Taft-Hartley Act]], designed by conservatives to create what they consider a proper balance between the rights of management and the rights of labor. Unions call it a slave labor law; Truman vetoes it and both houses override the veto.<ref>James T. Patterson (1972). ''Mr. Republican: a biography of Robert A. Taft.'' Houghton Mifflin Company. pp. 352–68.</ref> ;1948 * Deep South Democrats led by [[Strom Thurmond]] split from the National Democratic Party to form the pro-[[Racial segregation|segregation]] [[States' Rights Democratic Party]] or Dixiecrat party. They are protesting support for civil rights legislation in the party platform and make Thurmond their nominee for president in the [[United States presidential election, 1948|1948 election]]. Nearly all return to the Democratic party in 1949.<ref>Kari A. Frederickson (2000). ''The Dixiecrat Revolt and the End of the Solid South, 1932–1968.'' The University of North Carolina Press. passim.</ref> * Scholar [[Richard M. Weaver]] publishes ''[[Ideas Have Consequences]]'', which influences intellectuals to question sophistic interpretations of literature.<ref>Fred D. Young (1995). ''Richard M. Weaver, 1910–1963: a life of the mind.'' University of Missouri. p. 9.</ref> * June: Liberal Republican Thomas Dewey again wins the [[1948 Republican National Convention|Republican nomination]], to the frustration of conservatives.<ref>Michael Bowen (2011). ''The Roots of Modern Conservatism: Dewey, Taft, and the Battle for the Soul of the Republican Party.'' The University of North Carolina Press. p. 66.</ref> * November: Pundits are astonished when Dewey loses to incumbent Democrat [[Harry S. Truman]] in the [[United States presidential election, 1948|presidential election]].<ref>{{Cite news| url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,853326,00.html | work=Time | title=The Nation: Independence Day | date=1948-11-08 | accessdate=2010-05-26}}</ref>
===1950s=== After the war, businessmen opposed to New Deal liberalism read Hayek, fight labor unions, and fund politicized think tanks such as [[American Enterprise Institute]] (founded 1943). They promote statewide [[Right-to-work law|right-to-work]] campaigns.<ref>Kim Phillips-Fein (2009). ''Invisible Hands: The Businessmen's Crusade Against the New Deal.'' W. W. Norton & Company. ch 2.</ref> ;1950 * The intellectual reputation of conservatism reaches a low ebb; [[Lionel Trilling]] observes that "liberalism is not only the dominant but even the sole intellectual tradition" and dismisses conservatism as a series of "irritable mental gestures which seek to resemble ideas."<ref>{{cite book|author=Russell Kirk|title=The Conservative Mind: From Burke to Eliot|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mGBn2fOdp7gC&pg=PA476|year= 2001|publisher=Regnery|page=476|isbn=978-0895261717}}</ref> * February: Republican Senator [[Joseph McCarthy]] gives a speech saying, "While I cannot take the time to name all the men in the State Department who have been named as members of the Communist Party and members of a spy ring, I have here in my hand a list of 205." The speech marks the beginning of McCarthy's anti-communist pursuits.<ref> {{cite web|title = 'Communists in Government Service', McCarthy Says |publisher = United States Senate|url = https://www.senate.gov/artandhistory/history/minute/Communists_In_Government_Service.htm|accessdate =March 9, 2007}}</ref> ; 1951 * Political philosopher [[Francis Wilson (political scientist)|Francis Wilson]] in ''The Case for Conservatism'' (1951) defines conservatism as "a philosophy of social evolution, in which certain lasting values are defended within the framework of the tension of political conflict. And when given values are at stake the conservative can even become a revolutionary."<ref>{{cite book|author1=Charles W. Dunn|author2=J. David Woodard|title=American conservatism from Burke to Bush: an introduction|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Yw-CAAAAMAAJ|year=1991|publisher=Madison Books|page=29|isbn=978-0819180698}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|author=Francis Graham Wilson|title=The Case for Conservatism|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vKG30tSqDr8C&pg=PA2|year=2011|publisher=Transaction Publishers|page=2|isbn=978-1412842341}}</ref> ; 1952 * In securing the [[History of the Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]] presidential nomination, [[Dwight D. Eisenhower|Dwight D. "Ike" Eisenhower]] leads moderate and liberal Republicans to victory over Sen. [[Robert A. Taft]], the conservative champion.<ref>James T. Patterson ''Mr. Republican: A Biography of Robert A. Taft.'' (1972). ch 32–35.</ref> Ike then wins the presidency in a landslide by denouncing the failures of the [[Truman Administration]] in terms of "Korea, Communism and Corruption."<ref>{{cite book|author=[[William Lee Miller]]|title=Two Americans: Truman, Eisenhower, and a Dangerous World|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bTm8rbc-Q14C&pg=PA272|year=2012|publisher=Random House Digital|page=272|isbn=978-0307957542}}</ref> [[File:Russell Kirk.jpg|thumb|alt=photograph|Russell Kirk]] * Four major works of intellectual history that would influence conservatism are published: [[Daniel J. Boorstin]]'s ''The Genius of American Politics'', [[Peter Viereck]]'s ''Conservatism: From John Adams to Churchill'', [[Russell Kirk]]'s ''The Conservative Mind'', and [[Robert Nisbet]]'s ''Quest for Community''<ref>Reba N. Sofer (2009). ''History, historians, and conservatism in Britain and the United States.'' Oxford University Press. p. 232.</ref> * [[Intercollegiate Studies Institute]] (ISI) is founded by libertarian journalist [[Frank Chodorov]] (1887–1966) to counter the growing spread of collectivism; its original name was ''Intercollegiate Society of Individualists''.<ref>Lee Edwards (2003). ''Educating for Liberty: The first Half-century of the Intercollegiate Studies Institute'' Regnery. ch 1.</ref> ;1953 * President Eisenhower works closely with Senator Taft, the new GOP majority leader, on domestic issues; they differ on foreign policy.<ref>{{cite book|author=Clarence E. Wunderlin|title=Robert A. Taft: Ideas, Tradition, and Party in U.S. Foreign Policy|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1ROi1-O5uxkC&pg=PA191|year=2005|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield|page=191|isbn=978-0742544901}}</ref> ;1955 * The ''[[National Review]]'' weekly magazine is founded by [[William F. Buckley, Jr.]] (1925–2008). The editors include representative traditionalists, Catholics, libertarians and ex-communists. The most notable were [[Russell Kirk]], [[James Burnham]], [[Frank Meyer (political philosopher)|Frank Meyer]], [[Willmoore Kendall]], [[L. Brent Bozell, Jr.]], and [[Whittaker Chambers]].<ref>John B. Judis (1990). ''William F. Buckley, Jr.: Patron Saint of the Conservatives.'' Simon & Schuster. pp. 121–24, 152.</ref> * In ''The Liberal Tradition in American'', [[Louis Hartz]] claims that there has never been a European-style conservative tradition in America and that the sole mainstream tradition is Lockean liberalism.<ref>James T. Kloppenberg, "Review: In Retrospect: Louis Hartz's ''The Liberal Tradition in America''," ''Reviews in American History'' Vol. 29, No. 3 (Sept 2001), pp. 460–78 [https://www.jstor.org/stable/30030991 in JSTOR]</ref> ;1957 * Russian-born philosopher [[Ayn Rand]] (1905–1982) publishes her novel ''[[Atlas Shrugged]]''; it attracts the libertarian wing of [[Conservatism in the United States|American conservatism]] by promoting aggressive entrepreneurship and rejecting religion and altruism. She influences even those conservative intellectuals who reject her ethical system such as Buckley and Whittaker Chambers.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Burns | first1 = Jennifer | year = 2004 | title = Godless Capitalism: Ayn Rand and the Conservative Movement | url = | journal = Modern Intellectual History | volume = 1 | issue = 3| pages = 359–85 | doi = 10.1017/S1479244304000216 }}</ref><ref>Jennifer Burns (2009). ''Goddess of the Market: Ayn Rand and the American Right.'' Oxford University Press. pp. 174–76.</ref> ;1958 [[File:Barry Goldwater photo1962.jpg|thumb|140px|alt=photograph|Barry Goldwater]] * [[Vermont C. Royster]] (1914–1996) becomes editor of the editorial page of ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'' (1958 to 1971). He wins two Pulitzer Prizes for his conservative interpretation of economic and political news.<ref>{{cite book|author=Richard J. Tofel|title=Restless Genius: Barney Kilgore, The Wall Street Journal, and the Invention of Modern Journalism|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xRN0L8DybPgC&pg=PA157|year=2009|publisher=Macmillan|page=157|isbn=978-0312536749}}</ref> * Conservatives try economic populism to appeal to blue collar workers forced to join labor unions. The GOP pushes "right-to-work" laws in California and elsewhere, but the unions counter-organize for the Democrats. Conservatives try again in 2011.<ref>Kim Phillips-Fein, "'As Great an Issue as Slavery or Abolition': Economic Populism, the Conservative Movement, and the Right-to-Work Campaigns of 1958," ''Journal of Policy History,'' (Oct 2011), 23:4 pp. 491–512 [http://muse.jhu.edu/journals/journal_of_policy_history/v023/23.4.phillips-fein.html online]</ref><ref>Nelson Lichtenstein and Elizabeth Tandy Shermer, eds. (2012). ''The American Right and U.S. Labor: Politics, Ideology and Imagination.'' University of Pennsylvania Press. ch. 1.</ref> * November: In a deep [[Recession of 1958|economic recession]] the Democrats score a [[United States elections, 1958|landslide victory]], defeating many old-guard conservative Republicans. The new Congress has large Democratic majorities: 282 Democrats to 154 GOP in the [[United States House of Representatives elections, 1958|House]], 64 to 34 in the [[United States Senate elections, 1958|Senate]]. Nevertheless, the new Congress fails to pass any major liberal legislation as most committee chairs are Southern Democrats who support the [[Conservative Coalition]].<ref>''Congress and the Nation: 1945–1964'' (1965). Congressional Quarterly. pp. 28–34.</ref> Two Republicans score upsets in the face of the landslide—liberal [[Nelson Rockefeller]] as Governor of New York,<ref name="People & Events: Nelson A. Rockefeller">{{cite web|url=https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/amex/rockefellers/peopleevents/p_rock_n.html|title=People & Events: Nelson A. Rockefeller, 1908–1979|publisher=[[Public Broadcasting Service]] (PBS)|accessdate=20 April 2012}}</ref> and [[Barry Goldwater]] as Senator from Arizona;<ref name="AZ Senate Race, Nov 4, 1958">{{cite web|url=http://www.ourcampaigns.com/RaceDetail.html?RaceID=3282|title=Our Campaigns – AZ Senate Race, Nov 04, 1958|publisher=OurCampaigns.com|accessdate=20 April 2012}}</ref> both become presidential prospects.<!--Sourcing note: this is discussed and cited a few lines further down, as well as passing WP:CK --> * December: Businessman [[Robert W. Welch, Jr.]] (1899–1985) and twelve others found the [[John Birch Society]], an anti-communist advocacy group with chapters across the country. Welch uses an elaborate control system that enables him to keep a very tight rein on each chapter. Its major activities are circulating petitions and supporting the local police. It becomes a favorite target of attack from the left and is disowned by many of the prominent conservatives of the day.<ref>Jonathan Schoenwald (2002). ''A Time for Choosing: The Rise of Modern American Conservatism.'' Oxford University Press. pp. 62–99.</ref> ; 1959 * As late as 1959 William Buckley complains that conservatives were "bound together for the most part by negative response to liberalism," and that, philosophically, "there [is] no commonly-acknowledged conservative position."<ref>{{cite book|author=Hyrum S. Lewis|title=Sacralizing the Right: William F. Buckley Jr., Whittaker Chambers, Will Herberg and the Transformation of Intellectual Conservatism, 1945–1964|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QviaoxgkmFwC&pg=PA8|year=2007|publisher=ProQuest: PhD dissertation U. of Southern California|page=8|isbn=978-0549389996}}</ref>
===1960s=== Liberalism made major gains after the assassination of [[John F. Kennedy]] in 1963, as [[Lyndon B. Johnson]] (LBJ) pushed through his liberal [[Great Society]] as well as civil rights laws. An unexpected bonanza helped conservatism in the late 1960s as liberalism came under intense attack from the [[New Left]], especially in academe. This new element, says liberal historian Michael Kazin, worked to "topple the corrupted liberal order."<ref>Michael Kazin (1998). ''The populist persuasion: an American history.'' Cornell University Press. p. 197.</ref> For the New Left "liberal" became a nasty epithet. Liberal commentator [[E. J. Dionne]] finds that, "If liberal ideology began to crumble intellectually in the 1960s it did so in part because the New Left represented a highly articulate and able wrecking crew."<ref>{{cite book|author=E. J. Dionne|title=Why Americans Hate Politics|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pQMAsT7HlEsC&pg=PA37|year=2004|publisher=Simon and Schuster|page=37|isbn=978-0743265737}}</ref>
{{Infobox event | title = "A Time for Choosing" Speech | image = A Time for Choosing by Ronald Reagan.ogv | image_size = | caption = In support of Goldwater in 1964, Reagan delivers the TV address, "A Time for Choosing." The speech made Reagan the leader of movement conservatism | date = {{start date|1964|10|27}} | time = | duration = {{Duration|m=29|s=33}} | venue = | place = Los Angeles, CA, United States | also known as = "The Speech" | participants = [[Ronald Reagan]] | type = Televised campaign speech | website = [http://www.americanrhetoric.com/speeches/ronaldreaganatimeforchoosing.htm Video clip, audio, transcript] }}
[[Movement conservatism]] emerges as grassroots activists react to liberal and [[New Left]] agendas. It develops a structure that supports Goldwater in 1964 and [[Ronald Reagan]] in 1976–80. By the late 1970s, local evangelical churches join the movement.<ref>Rick Perlstein, "Thunder on the Right: The Roots of Conservative Victory in the 1960s," ''OAH Magazine of History,'' Oct 2006, Vol. 20 Issue 5, pp. 24–27</ref><ref>James A. Hijiya, "The Conservative 1960s," ''Journal of American Studies,'' Aug 2003, Vol. 37 Issue 2, pp. 201–28</ref> Liberalism faces a racial crisis nationwide. Within weeks of the passage of the [[Civil Rights Act of 1964|1964 Civil Rights law]], "long hot summers" begin, lasting until 1970, with the [[Long Hot Summer of 1967|worst outbreaks coming in the summer of 1967]]. Nearly 400 racial disorders in 298 cities saw blacks attacking shopkeepers and police, and looting stores.<ref>Michael Omi and Howard Winant (1994). ''Racial formation in the United States: from the 1960s to the 1990s.'' Routledge. p. 196.</ref> Meanwhile, the urban crime rates shoot up. Demands for "[[Law and order (politics)|law and order]]" escalate and the backlash causes disillusionment among working class whites with the liberalism of the Democratic Party.<ref>Michael W. Flamm (2007). ''Law and Order: Street Crime, Civil Unrest, and the Crisis of Liberalism in the 1960s.'' Columbia University Press. ch. 9.</ref>
In the mid-1960s the GOP debates race and civil rights intensely. Republican liberals, led by Nelson Rockefeller, argue for a strong federal role because it was morally right and politically advantageous. Conservatives call for a more limited federal presence and discount the possibility of significant black voter support. Nixon avoids race issues in 1968.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Thurber | first1 = Timothy N. | year = 2007 | title = Goldwaterism Triumphant? Race and the Republican Party, 1965–1968 | url = | journal = Journal of the Historical Society | volume = 7 | issue = 3| pages = 349–84 | doi = 10.1111/j.1540-5923.2007.00221.x }}</ref> [[File:1960-07-25 republican convention highlights.ogv|thumb|thumbtime=1|alt=title screen|Highlights of the [[1960 Republican National Convention|1960 Republican convention]] in Chicago, Illinois. July 1960.]]
;1960 [[File:Modern age fall 1960.jpg|thumb|140px|alt=magazine cover|Cover of ''Modern Age'', Fall 1960.]] * Conservatives are angered when GOP presidential nominee [[Richard Nixon]] strikes a deal with liberal leader Nelson Rockefeller. Nixon agrees to put all 14 of Rockefeller's demands in the party platform, including promises that the executive branch be totally reorganized and that Rockefeller's liberal policies on economic growth, medical care for the aged and civil rights be included.<ref>{{cite book|author=Theodore H. White|title=The Making of the President 1960|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pIeSn5gtRqMC&pg=PA198|year=1961|publisher=HarperCollins|pages=197–99|isbn=978-0061900600}}</ref> Led by Goldwater, conservatives vow to organize at the grass roots and take control of the GOP.<ref>Laura Jane Gifford (2009). ''The Center Cannot Hold: The 1960 Presidential Election and the Rise of Modern Conservatism.'' Northern Illinois Univ Press. p. 17.</ref> * [[Barry Goldwater]] publishes ''[[The Conscience of a Conservative]]''. The book helps the Arizona Senator reignite the conservative movement which rallies behind the charismatic Arizona Senator.<ref>Robert Alan Goldberg (1995). ''Barry Goldwater.'' Yale University Press. pp. 138–43, 179.</ref> * Fall: [[Frank S. Meyer]]'s article, "Freedom, Tradition, Conservatism", is published in ''[[Modern Age (periodical)|Modern Age]]'', argues that traditional conservatism and libertarianism share a common philosophical heritage. The concept comes to be known as "[[fusionism]]" and unites the two strands of thought.<ref>John R. E. Bliese (2002). ''The Greening Of Conservative America.'' Westview Press. pp. 4–5.</ref> * September: William F. Buckley, Jr., forms a youth group called the [[Young Americans for Freedom]]; it helps Goldwater win the 1964 nomination but is otherwise ineffective and collapses in internal bickering.<ref>Gregory L. Schneider (1998). ''Cadres for Conservatism: Young Americans for Freedom and the Rise of the Contemporary Right.'' NYU Press. pp. 154, 167, 172.</ref> * November: Nixon loses a close [[United States presidential election, 1960|election]] to liberal Democrat [[John F. Kennedy]].<ref>{{cite book|author=W. J. Rorabaugh|title=Kennedy and the Promise of the Sixties|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dAI7yeY67NYC&pg=PA18|year=2002|publisher=Cambridge U.P.|page=18|isbn=978-0521816175}}</ref>
;1961 * [[Christian Broadcasting Network]] (CBN) is founded by [[Pat Robertson]]; its signature program ''[[The 700 Club]]'' launches in 1966.<ref>David Marley (2007). ''Pat Robertson: an American life.'' Rowman & Littlefield Publishers. p. 97.</ref> * May: Texas elects Senator [[John Tower]]; he is the first Republican from the former Confederacy ever to win popular election and begins the growth of the GOP in that state.<ref>{{cite book|author=Sean P. Cunningham|title=Cowboy Conservatism: Texas and the Rise of the Modern Right|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Fv8jCQZdBPQC&pg=PA53|year=2010|publisher=University Press of Kentucky|page=53|isbn=978-0813125763}}</ref> ;1962 * Buckley and the ''National Review'' launch denunciations of the John Birch Society; Goldwater agrees; the attack limits its influence to the conspiracy-minded.<ref>William F. Buckley, Jr., "Goldwater, the John Birch Society, and Me". [http://www.commentarymagazine.com/article/goldwater-the-john-birch-society-and-me/ ''Commentary'' (March 2008) online]</ref> ;1963 [[File:Commercial-LBJ1964ElectionAdDaisyGirl.ogv|thumb|thumbtime=3|alt=young girl picking flowers|The controversial "[[Daisy (advertisement)|Daisy]]" Johnson TV commercial in 1964 attacks Goldwater foreign policy as inviting nuclear war<ref name="Daisy Petals and Mushroom Clouds">{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052970204777904576653070396452408 |title=Book Review: Daisy Petals and Mushroom Clouds|last=Kurson|first=Ken|date=November 5, 2011|work=[[The Wall Street Journal]]|accessdate=24 April 2012}}</ref>]] * January: Governor of Alabama, Democrat [[George Wallace]], electrifies the white South by proclaiming "[[George Wallace's 1963 Inaugural Address|segregation now, segregation tomorrow, segregation forever!]]" Wallace's angry populist rhetoric appeals to the poor farmers and workers who comprise a major part of the [[New Deal Coalition]]. He does well in Democratic primaries in the industrial North as well as the rural South. He exploits distrust of government, racial fear, anti-communism and a yearning for "traditional" American values.<ref>Dan T. Carter (2000). ''The politics of rage: George Wallace, the origins of the new conservatism, and the transformation of American politics'' LSU Press. p. 12.</ref> [[File:A Time for Choosing by Ronald Reagan.ogv|thumb|thumbtime=25|alt=Reagan speaks for Goldwater 1964|In support of Goldwater, Reagan delivers the address, "[[A Time for Choosing]]." The speech launches Reagan to national prominence.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://millercenter.org/president/speeches/detail/3405|title='A Time for Choosing' (October 27, 1964)|publisher=Miller Center|accessdate=April 28, 2012}}</ref>]] ;1964 * June: Senator [[Everett Dirksen]] (R-IL) plays a key role in passage of the [[1964 Civil Rights Act]] to end segregation, but Goldwater joins Southern Democrats in voting against it.<ref>Robert D. Loevy (1997). ''The Civil Rights Act of 1964: the passage of the law that ended racial segregation.'' State University of New York Press. p. 359.</ref> [[File:ElectoralCollege1964.svg|thumb|alt=electoral map |Presidential Election, 1964. Goldwater only won his home state of Arizona and five states in the Deep South.]] * Jul: George Wallace gives a speech condemning the [[Civil Rights Act of 1964]], claiming that it would threaten individual liberty, free enterprise and private property rights and that "The liberal left-wingers have passed it. Now let them employ some pinknik social engineers in Washington, D.C., to figure out what to do with it."<ref>{{cite speech |last=Wallace |first=George C. |date=July 4, 1964|title=The Civil Rights Movement: Fraud, Sham, and Hoax |url=http://www.vlib.us/amdocs/texts/wallace64.html |accessdate=April 26, 2012 }}</ref> * July: Goldwater defeats liberal Republicans Rockefeller to win the [[1964 Republican National Convention|GOP presidential nomination]] and launch a conservative crusade. * July: Under attack as an "extremist," Goldwater lashes back in his speech accepting the GOP nomination: {{quote|I would remind you that extremism in the defense of liberty is no vice! And let me remind you also that moderation in the pursuit of justice is no virtue!<ref>{{cite book|author=William Safire|title=Safire's Political Dictionary|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=c4UoX6-Sv1AC&pg=PA229|year=2008|publisher=Oxford U.P.|page=229|isbn=978-0195343342}}</ref>}} * November: In the [[United States presidential election, 1964|presidential election]], Goldwater is defeated in a landslide, and many GOP congressmen are defeated with him.<ref>Rick Perlstein (2004). Hill and Wang. ch. 22.</ref> * December: The [[American Conservative Union]], the oldest conservative lobbying organization in the United States, is founded by William F. ;1965 * William F. Buckley, Jr., gains national attention by [[New York City mayoral elections#1965|running for mayor of New York City]] on the ticket of the new [[Conservative Party of New York State]]. He loses the election but gains visibility and respectability for the cause in the aftermath of Goldwater's defeat.<ref>Jonathan Schoenwald (2002). ''A Time for Choosing: The Rise of Modern American Conservatism.'' Oxford University Press. pp. 162–89.</ref> ;1966 * April: Socialist [[Norman Thomas]] appears on the premiere episode of ''[[Firing Line (TV series)|Firing Line]]'' with host William F. Buckley. The program remains on the air for 33 years and is the longest running television program with the same host.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/books/00/07/16/specials/buckley-transformed.html|author=Laurence Zuckerman|title=How 'Firing Line' Transformed the Battleground|work=The New York Times|date=December 18, 1999|accessdate=April 27, 2012}}</ref> * November: Republicans score major gains in the [[United States House of Representatives elections, 1966|off-year elections]], emphasizing issues of law and order. Liberal candidates endorsed by the [[AFL–CIO]] do poorly.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Draper | first1 = Alan | date = Winter 1989 | title = Labor and the 1966 Elections | url = | journal = Labor History | volume = 30 | issue = 1| pages = 76–92 | doi = 10.1080/00236568900890031 }}</ref> [[Ronald Reagan]] is [[California gubernatorial election, 1966|elected governor]] of California.<ref>Matthew Dallek (2004). ''The Right Moment: Ronald Reagan's First Victory and the Decisive Turning Point in American Politics.'' Oxford University Press. p. ix.</ref>
;1967 * New Left students hold highly publicized rallies chanting, "Hey– Hey– LBJ– How many kids did you kill today?" Their confrontational rhetoric and efforts to disrupt the draft alienates millions of voters, who move to the right.<ref>{{cite book|author=Steven M. Gillon|title=The Pact: Bill Clinton, Newt Gingrich, and the Rivalry That Defined a Generation|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wAXDgQPHCscC&pg=PA20|year= 2008|publisher=Oxford U.P.|pages=20–22|isbn=978-0199886579}}</ref> * A generational rift opens as leftist students espouse Marxism, sexual freedom, marijuana, rock music and long hair that outrages the older generation. Elite colleges and universities come under heavy pressure (but not the smaller state schools and community colleges that generally remain calm).<ref>{{cite book|author=John T. Bethell|title=Harvard observed: an illustrated history of the university in the twentieth century|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hxpvsfxjfMAC&pg=PA218|year=1998|publisher=Harvard U.P.|pages=218–32|isbn=978-0674377332}}</ref> [[File:ElectoralCollege1968.svg|thumb|alt=electoral map of the United States|1968 presidential election results. <span style="color:#C20;">Red</span> denotes states won by Nixon/Agnew, <span style="color:darkblue;">Blue</span> denotes those won by Humphrey/Muskie. <span style="color:orange;">Orange</span> denotes states won by Wallace/LeMay.]] * ''[[The American Spectator]]'' monthly political magazine is founded by [[Emmett Tyrrell]]; its name until 1977 was ''The Alternative: An American Spectator''.<ref>R. Emmett Tyrrell, Jr. ed. (1987). ''Orthodoxy: The American Spectator's 20th Anniversary Anthology.'' Harper & Row. ch. 1.</ref> * [[Phyllis Schlafly]] launches the Eagle Trust Fund, a precursor to the conservative think tank [[Eagle Forum]].<ref>{{cite book |title=Encyclopedia of Women and American Politics |last=Ford |first=Lynne E. |year=2010 |publisher=Infobase Publishing|page=158 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=cVtFJ5tvINsC&lpg=PA158&dq=eagle%20trust%20fund%20-black&pg=PA158#v=onepage&q=eagle%20trust%20fund%20-black&f=false |isbn=978-1438110325 |accessdate=February 23, 2015}}</ref>
; 1968 * Liberalism collapses politically as the Democratic Party splits into five factions over issues of Vietnam, race and attacks from New Left.<ref>Lewis L. Gould (1993). ''1968: The Election That Changed America.'' Ivan R. Dee. pp. 7–30.</ref> [[Richard Nixon]] is [[United States presidential election, 1968|elected president]] over [[Hubert Humphrey]] and George Wallace ([[American Independent Party]]), emphasizing the need for law and order.<ref>Michael Flamm, "Politics and Pragmatism: The Nixon Administration and Crime Control," ''White House Studies,'' Feb 2006, 6:2 pp. 151–62</ref> The New Left denounced Humphrey as a war criminal, Nixon attacked him as the New Left's enabler—a man with "a personal attitude of indulgence and permissiveness toward the lawless."<ref>{{cite book|author=Rick Perlstein|title=Nixonland: The Rise of a President and the Fracturing of America|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dM_enWzoghoC&pg=PA349|year=2008|publisher=Simon and Schuster|page=349|isbn=978-0743243025}}</ref> Beinart observes that "with the country divided against itself, contempt for Hubert Humphrey was the one thing on which left and right could agree."<ref>{{cite book|author=Peter Beinart|title=The Good Fight: Why Liberals – and Only Liberals – Can Win the War on Terror and Make America Great Again|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IxjqV5rpgNEC&pg=PA49|year=2008|publisher=HarperCollins|page=49|isbn=978-0060841607}}</ref> ;1969 * Libertarian economists, especially Milton Friedman and [[Walter Oi]], lead the intellectual charge against the draft. RAND Corporation. pp. 66–70, 749.</ref> * Young Americans for Freedom splits into competing, irreconcilable factions.<ref>Kenneth J. Heineman (2001). ''Put your bodies upon the wheels: student revolt in the 1960s.'' Ivan R. Dee. p. 160.</ref> The libertarians, influenced by Ayn Rand, split from the traditionalists and form the [[Society for Individual Liberty]].<ref>{{cite book|author=Jennifer Burns|title=Goddess of the market: Ayn Rand and the American Right|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=z6e9X6JxHpMC&pg=PA257|year=2009|publisher=Oxford University Press|page=257|isbn=978-0195324877}}</ref>
===1970s=== Historians Meg Jacobs and Julian Zelizer argue that the 1970s were characterized by "a vast shift toward social and political conservatism," as well as a sharp decline in the proportion of voters who identified with liberalism.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Jacobs | first1 = Meg | last2 = Zelizer | first2 = Julian E. | year = 2008 | title = Comment: Swinging Too Far to the Left | journal = Journal of Contemporary History | volume = 43 | issue = 4| pages = 689–93 | jstor=40543230 | doi = 10.1177/0022009408095423}}</ref> [[Neoconservatism]] emerges as liberals become disenchanted with Lyndon B. Johnson's [[Great Society]] welfare programs. They increasingly focus on foreign policy, especially anti-communism, and support for Israel and for democracy in the Third World.<ref>Justin Vaïsse (2010). ''Neoconservatism: The Biography of a Movement'' Harvard University Press. passim.</ref>
While Nixon continues to antagonize and anger liberals, many of his programs upset conservatives. His foreign policy with [[Henry Kissinger]] focuses on détente with the USSR and China, and becomes a main target of conservatives. Nixon is uninterested in tax cuts or deregulation, but he does use executive orders and presidential authority to impose price and wage controls, expand the welfare state, require Affirmative Action, grow the [[National Endowment for the Humanities]] and the [[National Endowment for the Arts]], and create the [[Environmental Protection Agency]] (EPA).<ref>{{cite book|author=Joan Hoff|title=Nixon Reconsidered|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uzBPnPPcoSoC&pg=PA117|year=1995|publisher=Basic Books|page=118|isbn=978-0465051052}}</ref>
;1970 * November: [[James L. Buckley]] [[New York state election, 1970|is elected]] Senator for New York with 39% of the vote, running as a candidate for the [[Conservative Party of New York]].<ref>{{cite book |first=Timothy J. |last=Sullivan |year=2009 |title=New York State and the rise of modern conservatism: redrawing party lines |location= |publisher=State University of New York Press |page=135 |isbn=978-0791476437 }}</ref>
;1971 [[File:CPACattendeeChart.PNG|thumb|alt=line chart showing logarithmic increase|Number of CPAC attendees over time]] * Socialist [[Michael Harrington]] popularizes the term "neoconservative" for liberals who switch on foreign policy and domestic issues.<ref>{{cite book|author=Justin Vaïsse|title=Neoconservatism: The Biography of a Movement|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=z3b7syYOqskC|year=2010|publisher=Harvard U.P.|page=298|isbn=978-0674050518}}</ref><ref>see [http://neoconservatism.vaisse.net/doku.php?id=dissent_and_the_attack_on_neoconservatives_1973 his article]</ref> * December 11: Libertarians meeting at the home of [[David Nolan (libertarian)|David Nolan]] organize the [[Libertarian Party (United States)|Libertarian Party]] which nominates [[John Hospers]] for president in 1972. Novak|url=http://www.weeklystandard.com/Content/Public/Articles/000/000/002/073tvfpw.asp|title=Who Is Robert Bartley?|work=Weekly Standard|date=January 13, 2003|accessdate=April 23, 2012}}</ref> ;1973 * Traditional conservative [[Jesse Helms]] of North Carolina takes his Senate seat; he retires in 2002. His [[National Congressional Club]] uses state-of-the-art direct mail operation to raise millions for conservative candidates and for Helms' own sharply contested reelections.<ref>{{cite book |last=Link |first=William A. | publisher=St. Martin's Press|title=Righteous Warrior: Jesse Helms and the Rise of Modern Conservatism |url=https://books.google.com/?id=Q7CrGwAACAAJ |year=2008 |isbn=978-0312356002 }}</ref> * The [[American Conservative Union]] and [[Young Americans for Freedom]] start the [[Conservative Political Action Conference]] (CPAC) as a "small gathering of dedicated conservatives."<ref>{{cite book |first=John B. |last=Judis |year=1988 |title=William F. Buckley, Jr.: Patron Saint of the Conservatives |location=New York |publisher=Simon & Schuster |pages=356–57 |isbn=0743217977 }}</ref> * The [[Heritage Foundation]] is founded by [[Paul Weyrich]], [[Edwin Feulner]] and [[Joseph Coors]].<ref>{{cite book|author=Gregory L.
