Wade]]'', the [[National Right to Life Committee]] is formed, the oldest and largest pro-life organization in the United States.<ref>{{cite book |first=Donald T. |last=Critchlow |year=1995 |title=The politics of abortion and birth control in historical perspective |location= |publisher=Pennsylvania State University Press |isbn=0271015705 |page=140 }}</ref>
;1974 * [[Robert Grant (Christian leader)|Robert Grant]] founds the American Christian Cause as an effort to institutionalize the [[Christian right]] as a politically active social movement.<ref>Glenn H. Utter and John Woodrow Storey (2001). ''The religious right: a reference handbook.'' Grey House Publishing. p. 88.</ref> * January: The first [[March for Life (Washington, D.C.)|March for Life]] attracts 20,000 supporters in Washington.<ref>{{cite web|title=About Us|publisher=March For Life|year=2012|url=http://www.marchforlife.org/content/view/13/26/|accessdate=2012-02-17|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080509191120/http://www.marchforlife.org/content/view/13/26/|archivedate=2008-05-09|df=}}</ref> * August: Conservatives, led by Goldwater, desert Nixon when the "smoking gun" is discovered that proves Nixon covered up the crimes of the [[Watergate scandal]]. Nixon resigns in disgrace, but his Secretary of State [[Henry Kissinger]] stays on in the moderately conservative administration of [[Gerald R. Ford]].<ref>{{cite book|author1=John W. Dean|author2=Barry M. Goldwater, Jr.|title=Pure Goldwater|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JUkuQwT0cAwC&pg=PA296|year=2009|publisher=Macmillan|pages=296–98|isbn=978-0230611337}}</ref> [[File:William F. Buckley, Jr. with President Reagan 1986.jpg|thumb|alt=photograph of two men|William Buckley (left) and Ronald Reagan were two of the most visible conservatives of the 1970s and 1980s; 1986 photo]] * November: Liberal Democrats attack Watergate and score major victories in the [[United States House of Representatives elections, 1974|off-year elections]].<ref>{{cite book|author1=Michael Kazin|author2=Rebecca Edwards|author3=Adam Rothman, eds|title=The Concise Princeton Encyclopedia of American Political History|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7hScNkRpePoC&pg=PA222|year=2011|publisher=Princeton U.P.|page=222|isbn=978-0691152073}}</ref>
;1976 * [[Commentary (magazine)|''Commentary'']], a monthly Jewish magazine on politics, foreign policy, society and cultural issues that began as a liberal voice in the 1940s moves sharply to the right in the 1970s under editor [[Norman Podhoretz]]. It becomes an influential voice for Israel, anti-communism and neoconservatism by 1976, and supports Reagan in the 1980s.<ref>Benjamin Balint (2010). ''Running Commentary: The Contentious Magazine That Transformed the Jewish Left Into the Neoconservative Right.'' PublicAffairs. passim.</ref> * [[George H. Nash]] publishes ''The Conservative Intellectual Movement in America Since 1945;'' he argues that Buckley's ''[[National Review]]'' fused together the traditional, libertarian and anti-Communist traditions to forge a conservative intellectual movement.<ref>{{cite journal |first=Jennifer |last=Burns |title=In Retrospect: George Nash's The Conservative Intellectual Movement in America Since 1945 |journal=Reviews in American History |volume=32 |issue=3 |year=2004 |pages=447–62 |doi=10.1353/rah.2004.0053 }}</ref> ;1977 * [[Focus on the Family]] is founded by psychologist [[James Dobson]].<ref>{{cite book|author=Dan Gilgoff|title=The Jesus Machine: How James Dobson, Focus on the Family, and Evangelical America Are Winning the Culture War|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=okQ-4YOQ4kAC&pg=PA19|year=2008|publisher=Macmillan|page=19|isbn=978-0312378448}}</ref> The ''New York Times'' later calls Dobson "the nation's most influential evangelical leader."<ref>James McEnteer (2006). ''Shooting the truth: the rise of American political documentaries.'' Praeger. p. 146.</ref> * The [[Save Our Children]] movement is formed by celebrity singer [[Anita Bryant]] to oppose the [[LGBT social movements|gay rights movement]].<ref>Roger Chapman, ed. (2010). ''Culture wars: an encyclopedia of issues, viewpoints, and voices.'' M. E. Sharpe. vol. 1, p. 55.</ref>
;1978 * [[Robert Grant (Christian leader)|Robert Grant]], [[Paul Weyrich]], [[Terry Dolan (activist)|Terry Dolan]], [[Howard Phillips (politician)|Howard Phillips]], and [[Richard Viguerie]] found [[Christian Voice (USA)|Christian Voice]], to recruit, train, and organize evangelical Christians to participate in elections. Grant later ousts the others.<ref>Glenn H. Utter and John Storey, eds. (2001). ''The religious right: a reference handbook.'' ABC-Clio Inc. p. 123.</ref> * June: California unleashes a tax revolt, with [[Proposition 13]] to limit property taxes, promoted by [[Howard Jarvis]] (1903–1986), a long-time activist. The movement was backed by the United Organizations of Taxpayers, the Los Angeles Apartment Owners Association and realtors' associations.<ref>{{Cite journal| last1 = Smith | first1 = D. A.| title = Howard Jarvis, Populist Entrepreneur: Reevaluating the Causes of Proposition 13| journal = Social Science History| volume = 23| issue = 2| pages = 173–210| jstor = 1171520| year = 1999 | doi = 10.1017/s0145553200018058 }}</ref> Preconditions included steadily rising property taxes, "[[stagflation]]" and growing anger at government waste. California's tax revolt was followed by 30 other states.<ref>{{cite journal |first=Ballard C. |last=Campbell |title=Tax Revolts and Political Change |journal=Journal of Policy History |year=1998 |volume=10 |issue=1 |pages=153–78 |doi=10.1017/S089803060000556X }}</ref>
;1979 * In reaction against liberal and presidential support for the UN's [[International Women's Year]], conservative women meet in Houston to coordinate their grass roots work. Led by Phyllis Schlafly, they block passage of the ERA and work to nominate Ronald Reagan as the Republican candidate for president.<ref>{{cite book |first=Marjorie J. |last=Spruill |chapter=Gender and America's Right Turn |editor-first=Bruce J. |editor-last=Schulman |editor2-first=Julian E. |editor2-last=Zelizer |year=2008 |title=Rightward Bound: Making America Conservative in the 1970s |location= |publisher=Harvard University Press |isbn=978-0674027572 |pages=71–89 }}</ref> * [[Beverly LaHaye]] and eight other women found [[Concerned Women for America]] (CWA) to oppose the Equal Rights Amendment. It later expands its scope to address socially conservative issues.<ref>{{cite book|author=Sarah Slavin|title=U.S. Women's Interest Groups: Institutional Profiles|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=It0XSBZz2wEC&pg=PA138|year=1995|publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group|page=138|isbn=0313250731}}</ref> CWA has been described as "a key player in conservative evangelical politics" and according to CWA it is the largest women's organization in the United States.<ref>{{cite book |title=Crisis of Conservatism?: The Republican Party, the Conservative Movement, and American Politics After Bush |last=Aberbach, ed. |first=Joel D. |authorlink= |year=2011 |publisher=Oxford University Press |at=Ch. 7 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=QE7U4-Ion7kC&pg=PT149 |accessdate=April 22, 2012 |isbn=978-0199831364}}</ref> * February: [[Irving Kristol]] is featured on the cover of ''[[Esquire (magazine)|Esquire]]'' under the caption, "the godfather of the most powerful new political force in America – [[neoconservatism]]."<ref>{{cite book |first=R. Emmett |last=Tyrrell |year=2010 |title=After the Hangover: The Conservatives' Road to Recovery |location= |publisher=Thomas Nelson |page=36 |isbn=978-1595552723 }}</ref> * June: [[Jerry Falwell]] founds [[Moral Majority]], marking the reentry of Fundamentalists into partisan politics.<ref>{{cite book |first=Susan |last=Harding |year=2001 |title=The book of Jerry Falwell: fundamentalist language and politics |location= |publisher=Princeton University Press |page=285 |isbn=0691059896 }}</ref> [[File:Washington for Jesus 1980 TL.jpg|thumb|alt=picture of 1000s of people|Washington For Jesus, Washington D.C., 1980]] {{multiple image | direction = vertical | width = 220 | align = | footer = | image1 = Reagan delivers inaugural address 1981.jpg | alt1 = | caption1 = | image2 = Ronald Reagan First Inaugural.ogg | alt2 = Ronald Reagan at podium with dignartaries behind | caption2 = [[:File:Ronald Reagan First Inaugural.ogg|First inaugural address of Ronald Reagan, 1981]] (audio only) | link2 = }}
===1980s=== The decade is marked by the rise of the [[Christian right]] and the [[Reagan Revolution]].<ref>{{cite book|author1=Michael Kazin|author2=Rebecca Edwards|author3=Adam Rothman, eds.|title=The Princeton Encyclopedia of American Political History|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4hqpJEJp7cUC&pg=PA288|year=2009|publisher=Princeton U.P.|page=288|isbn=978-0691129716}}</ref> A priority of Reagan's administration is the [[Reagan Doctrine|rollback of Soviet communism]] in Latin America, Africa and worldwide.<ref>{{cite book|author=Eric J. Schmertz eds.|title=President Reagan and the World|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=i_zvztYvwBgC&pg=PA146|year=1997|publisher=Greenwood |page=146|isbn=978-0313301155|displayauthors=etal }}</ref> Reagan bases his economic policy, dubbed "[[Reaganomics]]", on [[supply-side economics]].<ref>{{Cite web |last=Niskanen |first=William A.|last2 =Moore| first2 =Stephen|year=1996 |title=Supply-Side Tax Cuts and the Truth about the Reagan Economic Record |publisher=Cato Institute |publication-place= |page=1 |url=https://www.scribd.com/fullscreen/31267964 |accessdate=April 21, 2002}}</ref>
;1980 * April: [[Washington for Jesus]] marches in support of Reagan's positions on social issues as Pat Robertson brings together a theologically diverse coalition of charismatics, Pentecostals, Southern Baptists, and other evangelicals.<ref>Daniel K. Williams (2010). ''God's Own Party: the making of the Christian right.'' Oxford University Press. pp. 181–2.</ref> * November: After denouncing Jimmy Carter's failed presidency, Reagan is [[United States presidential election, 1980|elected president]] running on a "[[peace through strength]]" platform.<ref name="Politics Starts at the Water's Edge">{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/09/15/opinion/15skinner.html?_r=2|title=Politics Starts at the Water's Edge|last1=Skinner|first1=Kiron K.|authorlink1=Kiron Skinner|last2=Kudelia|first2=Serhiy|last3=Bueno de Mesquita|first3=Bruce|last4=Rice|first4=Condoleezza|date=September 15, 2007|work=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=20 April 2012}}</ref> Republicans [[United States Senate elections, 1980|capture the Senate]] for the first time since 1953.<ref>{{cite book|author=Kenneth F. Warren|title=Encyclopedia of U.S. Campaigns, Elections, and Electoral Behavior|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zP4wDcT3PeQC&pg=PA100|year=2008|publisher=SAGE|page=100|isbn=978-1412954891}}</ref> ; 1981 * Reagan promotes "[[supply side economics]]", arguing that tax cuts will stimulate the economy, which suffers high unemployment and high inflation (called "stagflation").<ref>{{cite book|author=Bruce S. Jansson|title=The Reluctant Welfare State: Engaging History to Advance Social Work Practice in Contemporary Society|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WSRALTDECQ4C&pg=PA332|year=2011|publisher=Cengage Learning|pages=332–33 |isbn=978-0840034403}}</ref> * Reagan forms a [[Reagan coalition|coalition in Congress]] with [[Reagan Democrats|conservative Democrats]] and passes his [[Economic Recovery Tax Act of 1981|major tax cuts]] and increases in defense spending. He fails to cut welfare spending.<ref>{{cite book|author=Karl Gerard Brandt|title=Ronald Reagan and the House Democrats: gridlock, partisanship, and the fiscal crisis|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ozQxs1Q619AC&pg=PA10|year=2009|publisher=U. of Missouri Press|pages=10–15|isbn=978-0826218353}}</ref> * The Cold War heats up as Reagan pursues a [[rollback]] strategy in Latin America and Africa. He supports the anti-Communist "[[Contras|Contra]]" rebels who attempt to overthrow the pro-Communist [[Sandinista National Liberation Front|Sandinista]] regime in Nicaragua.<ref>{{cite book|author=Michael Kort|title=The Columbia Guide to the Cold War|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qM3z4yLPy2cC&pg=PA79|year=2001|publisher=Columbia U.P. |pages=79–80|isbn=978-0231107730}}</ref> Liberal Democrats in Congress try to block his moves and undercut the Contras, leading to a series of battles in the halls of Congress in which Reagan (mostly) prevails.<ref>{{cite book|author=Mary Beth Norton|title=A People and a Nation: A History of the United States. Since 1865|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MdWxPDvsqaIC&pg=PA862|year=2009|publisher=Cengage |page=862|isbn=978-0547175607}}</ref> The Sandinistas are forced to hold fair elections in 1990, which they lose by 41%–55%.<ref>{{cite book|author=Tim Merrill|title=Nicaragua: a country study|url=http://lcweb2.loc.gov/frd/cs/nitoc.html|year=1994|publisher=Library of Congress|chapter=3}}</ref> ; 1982 * June: President Reagan tells the British Parliament that "the march of freedom and democracy will leave Marxism and Leninism on the [[ash heap of history]]"<ref>{{cite web | last = Pipes | first = Richard | title = Ash Heap of History: President Reagan's Westminster Address 20 Years Later | work = | date = June 3, 2002 | url = http://www.reagansheritage.org/reagan/html/reagan_panel_pipes.shtml | publisher = [[Heritage Foundation]] | doi = | accessdate = 2007-02-13 }}</ref> and calls for a "crusade for freedom."<ref>{{cite book|author=Andrew Busch|title=Ronald Reagan and the politics of freedom|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=42xNQiK9Tp4C&pg=PA196|year=2001|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield|isbn=978-0742520530}}</ref>
;1983 * March: President Reagan in a speech delivered to the [[National Association of Evangelicals]] denounces the Soviet Union (USSR) as an "[[Evil Empire speech|Evil Empire]]".<ref>{{cite book|author=James Mann|title=The Rebellion of Ronald Reagan: A History of the End of the Cold War|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BgZyXNIrvB4C&pg=PT37|year=2010|publisher=Penguin|pages=37–38|isbn=978-0143116790}}</ref> {{listen | filename = Evil Empire.ogg | title = "Evil Empire" | plain = yes |type=speech | description = Ronald Reagan delivers "Evil Empire" speech on March 8, 1983}} * The [[International Democrat Union]], also called the Conservative International, a transnational alliance of conservative and [[liberal conservative]] political parties, is founded in London. Officers of the [[Konrad Adenauer Foundation]] and Vice President [[George H. W. Bush]] are instrumental in the founding.<ref>{{cite book |title=The Future Catches Up: Transnational Parties and Democracy |last=Goldman |first=Ralph Morris |year=2002 |publisher=Taylor & Francis |location=London |page=418 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yJWlDYuoT5sC |accessdate= |isbn=978-0595228881}}</ref>
;1984 * November: proclaiming it's "[[Morning in America]]!" Reagan [[United States presidential election, 1984|is reelected]] in a 49-state landslide victory over liberal Democrat [[Walter Mondale]].<ref>Gil Troy (2005). ''Morning in America: how Ronald Reagan invented the 1980s.'' Princeton University Press. pp. 147–74.</ref>
;1986 * September : Associate Justice [[William Rehnquist]] is confirmed as Chief Justice of the Supreme Court.<ref>{{cite book|author=Steven F. Hayward|title=The Age of Reagan: The Conservative Counterrevolution: 1980–1989|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AORr5--U-MgC&pg=PA417|year=2010|publisher=Random House Digital, Inc.|page=417|isbn=978-1400053582}}</ref> Reagan chooses Rehnquist in a deliberate effort to move the Court to the right, knowing he has the conservative constitutional agenda firmly in mind.<ref>{{cite book|author=Mark V. Tushnet|title=A Court Divided: The Rehnquist Court and the Future of Constitutional Law|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=N6Z6AP_edKAC&pg=PA13|year=2005|publisher=W. W. Norton |page=13|isbn=978-0393327571}}</ref> * Replacing Rehnquist as Associate Justice, [[Antonin Scalia]] is confirmed by the Senate 90–0. He has been called "the creative, brilliant, and outspoken intellectual leader of the Court's conservative majority."<ref>{{cite book|author=Christopher E. Smith|title=Justice Antonin Scalia and the Supreme Court's Conservative Moment|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=A7hMrIXzKkMC&pg=PA20|year=1993|publisher=ABC-CLIO|page=20|isbn=978-0275947057}}</ref> * October: Congress enacts the [[Tax Reform Act of 1986]], the second of the "Reagan Tax Cuts". The act simplifies the tax code, reduces the marginal income tax rate on the wealthiest Americans from 50% to 28%, and increases the marginal tax rate on the lowest-earning taxpayers from 10% to 15%.<ref>{{cite book|author1=Jeffrey H. Birnbaum|author2=Alan S. Murray|title=Showdown at Gucci Gulch: Lawmakers, Lobbyists, and the Unlikely Triumph of Tax Reform|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yJg_aWMv9FMC|year=1988|publisher=Random House Digital, Inc.|pages=3–22|isbn=978-0394758114}}</ref> * November: the [[Iran Contra scandal]] draws national attention and threatened to derail Reagan's progress. Working with the CIA Reagan had authorized National Security Council officials to engage in a complicated sale of missiles to Iran with the goal of funding the Contras fighting Nicaragua. Blame increasingly centered on the key operative, [[Oliver North]]. However, in week-long dramatic testimony North emerges a conservative hero. North is convicted on minor counts but the conviction is reversed on appeal because he did not receive a fair trial. Reagan's reputation survives and he leaves office more popular than he began.<ref>{{cite book|author=William E. Pemberton|title=Exit With Honor: The Life and Presidency of Ronald Reagan|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pvQtMzEa890C|year=1998|publisher=M.E. Sharpe|pages=172–90|isbn=978-0765600967}}</ref> ;1987 * June: In Berlin, President Reagan announces American terms for ending the [[Cold War]], challenging Soviet leader [[Mikhail Gorbachev]] to "[[Tear down this wall!]]"; Gorbachev allows the Berlin Wall to come down in November 1989, [[Revolutions of 1989|ending Soviet control]] over Eastern European satellites.<ref>Romesh Ratnesar (2009). ''Tear down this wall: a city, a president, and the speech that ended the Cold War.'' Simon & Schuster. p. 6.</ref> {{Listen |filename = Reagan Brandenburg Gate speech.ogg |title = "Tear down this wall" |plain = yes |description = Complete speech by [[Ronald Reagan]] at the [[Brandenburg Gate]], June 12, 1987. |format = [[Ogg]]}} * August: The Federal Communications Commission abolishes the [[Fairness Doctrine]]. Talk radio becomes dominated by [[conservative talk radio|conservative hosts]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Back to the Fairness Doctrine? |first=William |last=Rusher |url=http://townhall.com/columnists/williamrusher/2007/07/05/back_to_the_fairness_doctrine/page/full/ |newspaper=Townhall.com |date=July 5, 2007 |accessdate=April 20, 2012}}</ref> * August: [[Pat Robertson]] (b. 1930), an Evangelical minister, founds the [[Christian Coalition of America|Christian Coalition]], which becomes a prominent voice in the Christian right. Robertson also telecasts news and commentary on his own network, the [[Christian Broadcasting Network]] (CBN), founded in 1961. He runs poorly in the [[Republican Party presidential primaries, 1988|1988 GOP presidential race]] and withdraws.<ref>David Harrell Jr. (2010). ''Pat Robertson: A Life and Legacy.'' Wm. B. Eerdmans Publishing Company. passim.</ref>
;1988 * August: ''[[The Rush Limbaugh Show]]'' debuts on [[Premiere Radio Networks]] and will become the [[List of most-listened-to radio programs|highest-rated talk radio show in the United States]].<ref>Joseph Turow (4th ed. 2011). ''Media Today.'' Routledge. p. 376.</ref> * November [[George H. W. Bush]] is [[United States presidential election, 1988|elected president]].<ref name="bbc">{{cite news|publisher=BBC News Online: On This Date|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/onthisday/hi/dates/stories/november/9/newsid_3655000/3655368.stm|title=1988: Bush wins with 'no new taxes' promise|year=|accessdate=April 24, 2012 | date=November 9, 1988}}</ref> ; 1989 * November: the [[Berlin Wall]] falls as the satellite states free themselves from Soviet control. West Germany absorbs East Germany in 1990, and in late 1991 [[Dissolution of the Soviet Union|Communism collapses in Russia]] as the red flag is lowered for the last time. Reagan becomes a hero in Eastern Europe.<ref>{{cite book|author=Charles W. Dunn|title=The Enduring Reagan|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jFEFZyaT37gC&pg=PA100|year=2009|publisher=University Press of Kentucky|page=100|isbn=978-0813125527}}</ref>
===1990s=== [[File:Clarence Thomas official SCOTUS portrait.jpg|140px|thumb|alt=photograph of a man in judge robe|Clarence Thomas]] Conservative think tanks 1990–97 mobilize to challenge the legitimacy of [[global warming]] as a social problem. They challenge the scientific evidence, argue that global warming will have benefits, and warn that proposed solutions would do more harm than good.<ref>Aaron M. McCright and Riley E. Dunlap, "Defeating Kyoto: The Conservative Movement's Impact on U.S. Climate Change Policy," ''Social Problems,'' Aug 2003, Vol. 50 Issue 3, pp. 348–73 [https://www.jstor.org/pss/10.1525/sp.2003.50.3.348 in JSTOR]</ref> ;1991 * October: [[Clarence Thomas]], a [[Black conservatism in the United States|black Republican]], is confirmed as an Associate Justice of the Supreme Court after [[Clarence Thomas Supreme Court nomination|controversial hearings]] that focus less on his strongly conservative beliefs than his relationship with one of his aides, Anita Hill, who accuses him of sexual harassment.<ref>Dan Thomas, Craig McCoy and Allan McBride, "Deconstructing the Political Spectacle: Sex, Race, and Subjectivity in Public Response to the Clarence Thomas/Anita Hill "Sexual Harassment" Hearings," ''American Journal of Political Science'' Vol. 37, No. 3 (Aug., 1993), pp. 699–720 [https://www.jstor.org/stable/2111571 in JSTOR]</ref> ;1992 * November: George H. W. Bush is defeated by [[Bill Clinton]] in the [[United States presidential election, 1992|presidential election]]. Bush had alienated much of his conservative base by breaking his [[United States presidential election, 1988|1988 campaign]] pledge: "[[Read my lips: no new taxes]]" He also seemed much more interested in remote foreign affairs than the domestic issues that concerned most voters.<ref>Joel D. Aberbach and Gillian Peele (2011). ''Crisis of Conservatism?: The Republican Party, the Conservative Movement and American Politics After Bush.'' Oxford University Press. p. 31.</ref> {{listen | filename = George Bush 1988 No New Taxes.ogg | title = "Read my lips: no new taxes" | plain = yes |type=speech | description = George H.W. Bush speaking about taxes at the [[1988 Republican National Convention]]}}
;1994 * September: The [[Contract with America]] is released on the steps of the Capitol.<ref>{{cite book|author=Gary Donaldson|title=Modern America: a documentary history of the nation since 1945|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bawwNGkEWAcC&pg=PA308|year=2007|publisher=M.E. Sharpe|pages=308–10 for original text|isbn=978-0765615374}}</ref> Designed by GOP House Whip [[Newt Gingrich]], it had the effect of "nationalizing" the off-year election, as most Republican candidates endorsed it and used it as a template to promote a conservative agenda in economic policy. The ''Contract'' avoided divisive social issues.<ref>{{cite book|author=Nicol C. Rae|title=Conservative reformers: the Republican freshmen and the lessons of the 104th Congress|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gTVgaIHHgfMC&pg=PA37|year=1998|publisher=M.E. Sharpe|pages=37–39|isbn=978-0765601292}}</ref> * November: in the [[Republican Revolution]], Republicans [[United States House of Representatives elections, 1994|take control]] of the House of Representatives for the first time in 40 years. The Democrats lose 52 seats in the House and [[United States Senate elections, 1994|8 in the Senate]], giving the GOP margins of 230 to 204 and 53 to 47.<ref>{{cite book|author1=James W. Ceaser|author2=Andrew Busch|title=Losing to win: the 1996 elections and American politics|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qJEZH54W8gQC&pg=PA6|year=1997|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield|pages=6–12|isbn=978-0847684069}}</ref> ;1995 * January: [[Newt Gingrich]] becomes Speaker of the House. His "Contract with America" scores mixed results in Congress. Its main points (and their fate in Congress) were:<ref>{{cite book|author=Peter B. Levy|title=Encyclopedia of the Clinton presidency|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vEzWlAvDEf0C|year=2002|publisher=Greenwood|pages=78–79|isbn=978-0313312946}}</ref> ::{| class="wikitable" style="font-size:90%;" |- ! scope="col" |Legislation ! scope="col" |Result |- | Welfare reform | Passed |- | Term limits for Congressmen | Did not pass |- | Balanced budget amendment | Did not pass |- | Increase rights of victims of crime | Passed |- | Pro-family tax credits | Passed |- | Decrease United States role in UN | Did not pass |- | Capital gains tax cut | Passed |- | Limit punitive damages on product liability | Passed, but vetoed |} * September: ''[[The Weekly Standard]]'', founded by [[William Kristol]], [[Fred Barnes (journalist)|Fred Barnes]] and [[John Podhoretz]], publishes its first issue.<ref name="William Kristol">{{cite web|url=http://www.weeklystandard.com/author/william-kristol |title=William Kristol|work=[[The Weekly Standard]]|publisher=Terry Eastland|accessdate=24 April 2012}}</ref> It is known as "a redoubt of 'conservatism'".<ref name="What the Heck Is a Neocon?">{{cite web|url=http://www.cfr.org/world/heck-neocon/p5343|title=What the Heck Is a 'Neocon'?|last=Boot|first=Max |authorlink=Max Boot |date=December 30, 2002|work=The Wall Street Journal|publisher=[[Council on Foreign Relations]]|accessdate=24 April 2012}}</ref> ;1996 [[File:Fox News 6th 48 jeh.JPG|thumb|alt=photograph of building at street level|Fox News building on 48th Street, New York City]] * September: Congress passes and Clinton signs the [[Defense of Marriage Act]]. Senate Democrats try to repeal it in 2011.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://articles.cnn.com/2011-11-10/politics/politics_senate-doma_1_defense-of-marriage-act-couples-marriage-between-one-man?_s=PM:POLITICS |title=Senate panel passes repeal of Defense of Marriage Act |author=Tom Cohen |date=November 10, 2011 |work=CNN Politics |publisher= |accessdate=April 23, 2012}}</ref> * October: Australian media mogul [[Rupert Murdoch]] launches [[Fox News Network]]. Its strong appeal to conservative viewers on cable television soon gives it more viewers than arch-rival [[Cable News Network]] (CNN).<ref>Stephen L. Vaughn, ed. (2009). ''Encyclopedia of American Journalism.'' Routledge. pp. 76, 177–78.</ref> ;1997 * [[Matt Drudge]] launches his news website the ''[[Drudge Report]]''.<ref name="Matt Drudge">{{cite web|url=http://www.scotsman.com/news/profile-matt-drudge-webmaster-of-pork-pies-1-1430717|title=Profile: Matt Drudge – Webmaster of pork pies|date=March 1, 2008|work=Scotsman.com|publisher=Johnston Publishing Ltd.|accessdate=24 April 2012}}</ref> His first assistant is [[Andrew Breitbart]] (1969–2012), who later becomes a prominent conservative voice on the web.<ref name=sappell>{{cite news|last=Sappell| first=Joel|title= Hot links served up daily|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|publisher=[[Tribune Company]]|date=August 4, 2007|url=http://www.latimes.com/business/la-fi-drudge4aug04,0,4136919,full.story?coll=la-home-center |accessdate = 2007-08-04 }}</ref> The ''Drudge Report'' achieves national prominence on January 17, 1998, when it publishes a story which comes to be known as the [[Monica Lewinsky scandal]].<ref name="Matt Drudge"/> * September: [[Christopher W. Ruddy]] starts conservative news website [[Newsmax Media|Newsmax.com]]. Its hourly updates provided timely ammunition to conservative talk show hosts.<ref>{{cite book|author1=Dick Morris and Eileen McGann|title=Condi Vs. Hillary: The Next Great Presidential Race|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nIPDnuqHYugC&pg=PA194|year=2006|publisher=HarperCollins|pages=194–95|isbn=978-0060859848}}</ref>
===2000s=== The terror attack on September 11, 2001 reorients the administration towards foreign policy and terrorism issues, providing an opportunity for neoconservatives to have a greater influence on foreign policy. The [[Bush Doctrine]] leads to long-term interventions in Afghanistan (2001 to present) and Iraq (2003–2011).<ref>{{cite book|author=Heiko Meiertöns|title=The Doctrines of Us Security Policy: An Evaluation Under International Law|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-ZQrT7il4NcC&pg=PA179|year=2010|publisher=Cambridge University Press|pages=182–87|isbn=978-0521766487}}</ref>
On the domestic front Bush promises [[compassionate conservatism]] and works to improve education, address poverty nationwide, increase financial aid to poor countries and help alleviate AIDS in Africa.<ref>{{cite press release |title=Fact Sheet: Compassionate Conservatism |url=https://georgewbush-whitehouse.archives.gov/news/releases/2002/04/20020430.html |publisher=The White House |date=April 30, 2002 |accessdate=April 22, 2012}}</ref> {{multiple image | direction = vertical | width = 220 | align = | footer = | image1 = President George W. Bush address to the nation and joint session of Congress Sept. 20.jpg | alt1 = | caption1 = | image2 = Bush Addresses Congress 9-20-01.ogg | alt2 = man at lectern in front of an American flag | caption2 = At a joint session of Congress President Bush pledges to defend America's freedom against the fear of terrorism, a policy known as the [[Bush Doctrine]]. September 20, 2001. (audio only) | link2 = }} ;2000 * December: [[George W. Bush]] wins the [[United States presidential election, 2000|2000 presidential election]] after the Supreme Court halts a [[United States presidential election in Florida, 2000|highly contentious recount in Florida]].<ref>Richard A. Posner (2001). ''Breaking the Deadlock: The 2000 Election, the Constitution, and the Courts.'' Princeton University Press. passim.</ref> ;2001 * June: President Bush signed his [[Economic Growth and Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2001|10-year tax cut]] into law; in 2000 he had promised to return the federal budget surplus through an across-the-board reduction in federal income taxes.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Wattenberg | first1 = Martin P. | year = 2004 | title = Elections: Tax Cut Versus Lockbox: Did the Voters Grasp the Tradeoff in 2000? | url = | journal = Presidential Studies Quarterly | volume = 34 | issue = 4| pages = 838–48 | doi = 10.1111/j.1741-5705.2004.00227.x }}</ref> * September: [[September 11 attacks|9-11 terrorists attacks]] redefine the conservative role in foreign policy.<ref>{{cite book |first=Joel D. |last=Aberbach |first2=Gillian |last2=Peele |year=2011 |title=Crisis of conservatism?: the Republican Party, the conservative movement and American politics after Bush |location= |publisher=Oxford University Press |isbn=978-0199764013 |page=205 }}</ref> ;2002 * Scott McConnell, [[Patrick Buchanan]], and [[Taki Theodoracopulos]] found the [[paleoconservative]] magazine, ''[[The American Conservative]]''.<ref>Adam L. Fuller (2011). ''Taking the Fight to the Enemy: Neoconservatism and the Age of Ideology.'' Lexington Books. p. 264.</ref> ;2003 * November: The [[Partial-Birth Abortion Ban Act]] is enacted.<ref>Dorothy E. McBride (2008). ''Abortion in the United States: a reference handbook.'' ABC-CLIO. p. 185.</ref> ;2004 * November: Conservatives mobilize to reelect President Bush; he [[United States presidential election, 2004|defeats]] [[John F. Kerry]].<ref>John C. Green, Mark J. Rozell and Clyde Wilcox (2006). ''The Values Campaign?: The Christian Right and the 2004 Elections.'' Georgetown University Press. ch. 1.</ref> ;2005 [[File:Palin waving-RNC-20080903 cropped.jpg|thumb|alt=photograph of woman at lectern|Sarah Palin addresses the [[2008 Republican National Convention]]]] * Bush pushes for a [[Social Security debate in the United States#George W. Bush's privatization proposal|private dimension to Social Security]]—allowing workers to invest a portion of their Social Security taxes in stocks and bonds—but it goes nowhere.<ref>{{cite book|author1=Alec Gallup|author2=Frank Newport|title=The Gallup Poll: Public Opinion – 2005|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WOug0pzW6_IC&pg=PA130|year=2007|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield|page=130|isbn=978-0742552586}}</ref> ;2006 * January: [[Samuel Alito]], nominated by George W. Bush, is confirmed as an Associate Justice of the United States Supreme Court on a party-line vote in the Senate.<ref>{{cite news|last=Babington|first=Charles|title=Alito Is Sworn In On High Court: Senators Confirm Conservative Judge Largely on Party Lines|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/08/14/AR2007081401015.html|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=February 1, 2006}}</ref> * November: Democrats make major gains in [[United States elections, 2006|off-year elections]], attacking the unpopular war in Iraq and the bungling of Hurricane Katrina relief.<ref>David B. Magleby and Kelly D. Patterson, eds. (2008). ''The Battle for Congress: Iraq, Scandal, and Campaign Finance in the 2006 Election.'' Paradigm. ch. 1.</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Schier | first1 = Steven E. | year = 2006 | title = Frustrated Ambitions: The George W. Bush Presidency and the 2006 Elections | url = | journal = Forum | volume = 4 | issue = 3| pages = 1–8 | doi=10.2202/1540-8884.1142}}</ref> [[File:Fresno - Prop 8 Rally.jpg|thumb|alt=photograph of a throng of people holding signs|YES on 8 rally in Fresno, California]] ;2007 * May: [[Christian right]] leader and founder of the [[Moral Majority]], [[Jerry Falwell]] dies in his office in [[Lynchburg, Virginia]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2007/US/05/15/jerry.falwell/|title=Rev. Jerry Falwell dies at age 73|work=CNN|date=15 May 2007|accessdate=6 November 2013}}</ref> * [[conservative talk radio|Conservative talk show]] hosts mobilize fierce public opposition to the [[Comprehensive Immigration Reform Act of 2007|McCain–Kennedy immigration reform bill]], which eventually fails.<ref>{{cite web|first=Duncan |last=Currie |url=http://www.weeklystandard.com/Content/Public/Articles/000/000/014/628wcxju.asp |title=Beyond the Border |work=The Weekly Standard |date=2008-01-22}}</ref> ;2008 * August: Little-known Alaska Governor [[Sarah Palin]] becomes the first woman on a national GOP ticket as [[Sarah Palin's Vice Presidential candidacy|nominee for Vice President]].<ref>{{cite book|author1=Daniel J. Balz|author2=Haynes Johnson|title=The Battle for America 2008: The Story of an Extraordinary Election|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Id7H0vxIK7QC&pg=PT288|year= 2009|publisher=Penguin|page=288|isbn=978-0670021116}}</ref> * November: Democrat [[Barack Obama]] defeated Republican [[John McCain]] by 53% to 46%. Barack Obama was elected and officially inaugurated as president of the United States of America on January 20, 2009. He was re-elected president in November 2012 and was sworn in for a second term on January 20, 2013. The national exit poll shows self-identified conservatives comprise 34% of the voters and support McCain 78% to 20%. Liberals comprise 22% of the voters and support Obama 89% to 10%. Moderates comprise 44% of the voters and support Obama 60% to 39%.<ref>See [http://www.cnn.com/ELECTION/2008/results/polls/#USP00p1 Exit Poll details]</ref> [[File:TeaPartyByFreedomFan.JPG|thumb|alt=photograph of thousands of people some holding American flags|Taxpayer March on Washington, 2009]] * November: [[California Proposition 8 (2008)|Proposition 8]] which prescribes that marriage is between a man and a woman in California is passed with 52.2% of the vote.<ref>Stanley D. Brunn, et al. eds. (2011). ''Atlas of the 2008 Elections.'' Rowman and Littlefield. p. 265.</ref> ;2009 * The [[Tea Party movement]] is founded, in part emerging from [[libertarian conservative]] [[Ron Paul]]'s [[Ron Paul presidential campaign, 2008|2008 campaign]] for the Republican nomination.<ref>{{cite book|author1=Mark Meckler|authorlink1=Mark Meckler|author2=Jenny Beth Martin|title=Tea Party Patriots: The Second American Revolution|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=H9wHT3TdT-IC&pg=PA9|year=2012|publisher=Macmillan|page=9|isbn=978-1429942690}}</ref><ref>Scott Rasmussen and Doug Schoen (2010). ''Mad As Hell: How the Tea Party Movement Is Fundamentally Remaking Our Two-Party System.'' Harper. ch. 1.</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.foxnews.com/opinion/2011/05/10/juan-williams-surprising-rise-rep-ron-paul/ |publisher=Fox News | title=Juan Williams: The Surprising Rise of Rep. Ron Paul|first=Juan|last=Williams| date=May 10, 2011}}</ref> The loosely organized conservative movement demands rigorous adherence to the Constitution, lower taxes, lower deficits, restrictions on illegal immigrants, and opposes Obama's health care proposals.<ref>{{cite book |first=Theda |last=Skocpol |first2=Vanessa |last2=Williamson |year=2012 |title=The Tea Party and the Remaking of Republican Conservatism |location= |publisher=Oxford University Press |isbn=978-0199832637 |pages=45–82 }}</ref> * Activists [[Hannah Giles]] and [[James O'Keefe]] make sting videos compromising the integrity of [[Association of Community Organizations for Reform Now]] (ACORN); ACORN soon dissolves.<ref>{{cite book|author1=Scott Rasmussen|author2=Doug Schoen|title=Mad As Hell: How the Tea Party Movement Is Fundamentally Remaking Our Two-Party System|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UfTmmBmUhbcC&pg=PA228|year=2010|publisher=HarperCollins|page=228|isbn=978-0062016720}}</ref>
===2010s=== Numerous historians after 1990 re-examined the role of conservatism in recent American history, according it much greater importance than before.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Phillips-Fein | first1 = Kim | year = 2011 | title = Conservatism: A State of the Field | url = | journal = Journal of American History | volume = 98 | issue = 3| pages = 723–43 | doi = 10.1093/jahist/jar430 }}, with commentary by Wilfred M. McClay, Alan Brinkley, Donald T. Critchlow, Martin Durham, Matthew D. Lassiter, and Lisa McGirr, and response by Phillips-Fein, pp. 744–73 [http://jah.oxfordjournals.org/content/98/3.toc online]</ref> One school of thought rejects the older consensus that liberalism was the dominant ethos. Instead it argues conservatism dominated American politics since the 1920s, with the brief exceptions of the New Deal era (1933–36) and the Great Society (1963–66).<ref>Labor historians Jefferson Cowie, and Nick Salvatore, "The Long Exception: Rethinking the Place of the New Deal in American History," ''International Labor & Working-Class History,'' (2008) 74:3–32, argue the New Deal was a short-term response to depression and did not mark a permanent commitment to a welfare state because America has always been too individualistic and too hostile to labor unions</ref> However Historian Julian Zelizer argues that "liberalism survived the rise of conservatism."<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Zelizer | first1 = Julian E. | year = 2010 | title = Reflections: Rethinking the History of American Conservatism | url = | journal = Reviews in American History | volume = 38 | issue = 2| pages = 367–92, quote p. 380 | doi = 10.1353/rah.0.0217 }}</ref>
;2010 * Supreme Court decision in ''[[Citizens United v. FEC]]'' holds that the free speech clause of the First Amendment applies to political speech during elections, making spending limits unconstitutional in certain cases. The Court majority upheld the libertarian approach to free speech, while the dissenters took an egalitarian approach.<ref>{{cite journal |first=Yasmin |last=Dawood |title=Campaign Finance and American Democracy |journal=Annual Review of Political Science |year=2015 |ssrn=2528587 |volume=18 |issue= |pages=329–48 |doi=10.1146/annurev-polisci-010814-104523 }}</ref> [[File:2010 House elections.svg|thumb|alt=electoral map of the United States|[[United States House of Representatives elections, 2010|2010 House election]] results. <span style="color:#000080;">Dark blue</span> denotes Democratic hold, <span style="color:#00F;">Blue</span> denotes Democratic gain, <span style="color:#800000;">Dark red</span> denotes Republican hold, <span style="color:#F00;">Red</span> denotes Republican gain.]] * November: in the largest GOP gain since 1938, 2010 became one of the most important elections in conservative history<ref>{{cite book |first=Theda |last=Skocpol |first2=Vanessa |last2=Williamson |year=2012 |title=The Tea Party and the Remaking of Republican Conservatism |location= |publisher=Oxford University Press |pages=138, 149 |isbn=978-0199832637 }}</ref> as GOP candidates, fired up by Tea Party support, make major gains in [[United States elections, 2010|midterm elections]] across the country for Congress, governorships and state legislatures. Conservative voters (self-identified) comprise 42% of the voters and support GOP House candidates 84% to 13%. Liberals comprise 20% of the voters and support Democrats 90% to 8%. Moderates comprise 38% of the voters and support the GOP 55% to 42%.<ref name="Election Center">{{cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/ELECTION/2010/results/polls/#val=USH00p1%202010|title=Election Center|work=[[CNN]]|publisher=[[Turner Broadcasting System]]|accessdate=24 April 2012}}</ref> Republicans gain 63 seats in the House of Representatives and six seats in the U.S. Senate. ;2012 * A central concern for conservatives in the 2012 GOP primaries was whether front-runner [[Mitt Romney]] is conservative enough. Numerous other challengers on the right rose and fell, notably [[Herman Cain]], [[Rick Santorum]], [[Newt Gingrich]], [[Rick Perry]], and [[Michele Bachmann]].<ref>{{cite news|author=James Hohmann|title=Romney doubles down, wins CPAC, Maine caucuses|url= http://www.politico.com/news/stories/0212/72757.html|work=[[Politico]] |date=February 12, 2012 |accessdate=2012-05-04}}</ref> Romney moved sharply to the right and chose deficit hawk Representative [[Paul Ryan]] of Wisconsin as his running mate.<ref>{{cite news |author1=Murray, Sarah |author2=Nelson, Colleen McCain |author3=O'Connor, Patrick |date=August 12, 2012 |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10000872396390443404004577582112521141598 |title=Romney Picks Ryan as Vice-Presidential Running Mate |work=[[The Wall Street Journal]] |accessdate=2012-08-15}}</ref> Obama, however, successfully mobilized his base and won reelection, as Democrats made small gains in the House and Senate. ; 2014 * November: Republicans win majorities in both houses of Congress, and flip several governorships in the [[United States elections, 2014|2014 midterm elections]]. ; 2016 * November: Republicans continue to hold both houses of Congress as well as take the [[White House]]. [[Donald Trump]] is elected as [[President of the United States]], causing many{{whom|date=September 2017}} to question the direction of conservatism in the United States' future. '''2017''' * April: [[Neil Gorsuch]], nominated by Donald Trump, is confirmed as associate justice to the Supreme Court.

The '''Willy Brandt Prize''' is an annual prize awarded by the Norwegian-German Willy Brandt prize foundation (in German: ''Norwegisch-Deutsche Willy-Brandt-Stiftung'') since 2000. It is awarded to persons or institutions that make significant contributions to German-Norwegian relations.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.berlinglobal.org/index.php?willy-brandt-foundation-awards-ceremony-20141|title=Willy Brandt Foundation Awards Ceremony 2014|date=2014-11-03|accessdate=18 September 2015}}</ref> It is named after the former German ''Bundeskanzler'' [[Willy Brandt]] and comprises a Willy Brandt statuette by [[Nils Aas]] and a certificate.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.royalcourt.no/nyhet.html?tid=34612|title=The State Visit Continues|date=2007-10-17|publisher=The Royal House of Norway|accessdate=18 September 2015}}</ref> It is separate from the International Willy-Brandt Prize founded in 2011 by the [[Social Democratic Party of Germany]].
==Prize winners==

{{Use American English|date=November 2016}} {{Use mdy dates|date=November 2016}} The '''Working Group on Financial Markets''' (also, '''President's Working Group on Financial Markets''', the '''Working Group''', and colloquially the '''Plunge Protection Team''') was created by [[Executive order (United States)|Executive Order]] 12631,{{cite web|url=https://www.archives.gov/federal-register/codification/executive-order/12631.html|title=Executive Orders|author=|date=March 18, 1988|publication-date=August 15, 2016|publisher=| accessdate=August 10, 2018}}, which appears and purports to be a copy of the original: {{cite journal |url= https://www.loc.gov/item/fr053055/ |journal=Federal Register |volume= 53 |issue=55| page= 9421 |title= Executive Order 12631 of March 18 1988: Working Group on Financial Markets |author= National Archives And Records Administration |date=March 18, 1988|publication-date=March 22, 1988|publisher=[[Library of Congress]] |accessdate=August 10, 2018 |id=FR Doc. 88-6380}} signed on March 18, 1988, by [[United States]] [[President of the United States|President]] [[Ronald Reagan]]. As established by the executive order, the Working Group has three purposes and functions: "(a) Recognizing the goals of enhancing the integrity, efficiency, orderliness, and competitiveness of our Nation's financial markets and maintaining investor confidence, the Working Group shall identify and consider: :(1) the major issues raised by the numerous studies on the events in the financial markets surrounding [[Black Monday (1987)|October 19, 1987]], and any of those recommendations that have the potential to achieve the goals noted above; and :(2) the actions, including governmental actions under existing laws and regulations (such as policy coordination and contingency planning), that are appropriate to carry out these recommendations. (b) The Working Group shall consult, as appropriate, with representatives of the various exchanges, clearinghouses, self-regulatory bodies, and with major market participants to determine private sector solutions wherever possible.
(c) The Working Group shall report to the President initially within 60 days (and periodically thereafter) on its progress and, if appropriate, its views on any recommended legislative changes." The Working Group consists of: * The [[United States Secretary of the Treasury|Secretary of the Treasury]], or his or her designee (as Chairperson of the Working Group); * The Chairperson of the [[Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System]], or his or her designee; * The Chairperson of the [[Securities and Exchange Commission]], or his or her designee; and * The Chairperson of the [[Commodity Futures Trading Commission]], or his or her designee. ==Plunge Protection Team== "Plunge Protection Team" was originally the headline for an article in ''[[The Washington Post]]'' on February 23, 1997,{{cite news | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/business/longterm/blackm/plunge.htm | work=The Washington Post | author= | date=February 23, 1997 | title=Plunge Protection Team | access-date=}} and has since been used by some as an informal term to refer to the Working Group.{{cite news|url-access=subscription |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/money/main.jhtml?view=DETAILS&amp;amp;amp;grid=&xml=/money/2006/10/30/ccview30.xml|title=Monday view: Paulson re-activates secretive support team to prevent markets meltdown|last=Evans-Pritchard|first=Ambrose|date=October 30, 2006|publisher=Telegraph UK|access-date=September 15, 2008 | location=London}}{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/Archive/Article/0,4273,4258005,00.html|title=Fed to prop up Wall St|last=Wachman|first=Richard|author2=Jamie Doward Observer |date=2001-09-16|publisher=Guardian Unlimited|access-date=September 15, 2008 | location=London}} Initially, the term was used to express the opinion that the Working Group was being used to prop up the [[stock market]]s during downturns.{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/business/longterm/blackm/plunge.htm|title=Plunge Protection Team |last=Fromson|first=Brett. D.|date=February 23, 1997|publisher=Washington Post| access-date=September 15, 2008}}{{cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601039&sid=a87VERwuZP8c&refer=home|title=Rubin Should Teach Paulson Secret PPT Handshake|last=Baum|first=Carolyn|date=July 31, 2007|publisher=Bloomberg|access-date=September 15, 2008}} Financial writers for British newspapers ''[[The Observer]]'' and ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'', along with U.S. Congressman [[Ron Paul]], writers [[Kevin Phillips (political commentator)|Kevin Phillips]] (who claims "no personal firsthand knowledge" {{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/08/03/books/review/Gross-t.html | work=The New York Times | title=Riches to Rags | first=Daniel | last=Gross | date=August 3, 2008|access-date=}}) and [[John Crudele]],{{cite news |url-access=subscription |url=http://www.boston.com/bostonglobe/ideas/articles/2008/09/21/the_operators/?p1=Well_MostPop_Emailed4|title=The Operators Behind a seductive Wall Street conspiracy theory|last=Bennett |first=Drake|date=September 21, 2008|publisher=The Boston Globe|access-date=September 21, 2008}} have charged the Working Group with going beyond their legal mandate.{{Failed verification |date=August 2018| reason=Source talks of a conspiracy theory and does not appear to make claim about legality}} Charles Biderman, head of TrimTabs Investment Research, which tracks money flow in the equities market, suspected that following the 2008 financial crisis the Federal Reserve or U.S. government was supporting the stock market. He stated that "If the money to boost stock prices did not come from the traditional players, it had to have come from somewhere else" and "Why not support the stock market as well? Moreover, several officials have suggested the government should support stock prices."{{cite news|url=http://www.moneynews.com/StreetTalk/CharlesBiderman-Fed-government-Rigging/2010/01/06/id/345497|title=Biderman: Fed, Gov't Likely Rigging Market Rally|last=Crawshaw |first=Julie|date=2010-01-10|publisher=Money News|access-date=April 24, 2012}} In August 2005, Sprott Asset Management released a report that argued that there is little doubt that the PPT intervened to protect the stock market.{{cite web|url=http://www.sprott.com/Docs/SpecialReports/08_2005_TheVisibleHand.pdf|title=Sprott Asset Management|author=|date=|publisher=|access-date=November 13, 2016}} However, these articles usually refer to the Working Group using moral suasion to attempt to convince banks to buy stock index futures.[http://registeredrep.com/mag/finance_stock_markets_da/ Federal Government Manipulating Equities Market?] Former Federal Reserve Board member Robert Heller, in the ''Wall Street Journal'', opined that "Instead of flooding the entire economy with liquidity, and thereby increasing the danger of inflation, the Fed could support the stock market directly by buying market averages in the futures market, thereby stabilizing the market as a whole." {{Citation needed span|date=August 2018|text=His statement has been used to claim that the Fed actually did act in that way.}} Some{{who|date=May 2014}} mainstream analysts call those claims a [[conspiracy theory]], explaining that such claims are simplistic and unworkable.Bennett, ''The Boston Globe''.{{Full citation needed|date=August 2018}} Author [[Kevin Phillips (political commentator)|Kevin Phillips]] wrote in his 2008 book ''Bad Money'' that while he had no interest "in becoming a conspiracy investigator", he nevertheless drew the conclusion that "some kind of high-level decision seems to have been reached in Washington to loosely institutionalize a rescue mechanism for the stock market akin to that pursued...to safeguard major U.S. banks from exposure to domestic and foreign loan and currency crises."{{Cite book| last=Phillips | first=K. | year=2008 | title=Bad Money: Reckless Finance, Failed Politics, and the Global Crisis of American Capitalism | publisher=Viking | isbn=978-0-670-01907-6 }} Phillips infers that the simplest way for the Working Group to intervene in market plunges would be through buying [[stock market index]] [[futures contracts]], either in cooperation with major banks or through [[trading room|trading desks]] at the U.S. Treasury or Federal Reserve. ==Market crisis of 2008== On October 6, 2008, the working group issued a statement indicating that it was taking multiple actions available to it in order to attempt to stabilize the financial system, although purchase of stock shares was not part of the statement.{{cite web|url=http://www.treasury.gov/press-center/press-releases/Pages/hp1177.aspx|title=Statement by the President's Working Group on Financial Markets|publisher=[[United States Department of the Treasury]]|access-date=October 6, 2008}} The government may wind up owning shares in the firms to which it provided loans, as they will receive warrants as collateral for these loans. ==See also== *
